name: Additional Weld Test Pay
rule_text: Any welder who is required to do additional testing by the Employer, shall be paid for weld time of four (4) hours per successful test
summary: A welder who successfully passes an additional weld test required by the employer is entitled to four hours of pay for the test time.
logical_representation: IF test_type == 'additional' AND test_result == 'success' -> PAY(4_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule specifies a fixed amount of paid time (4 hours) for a specific work-related task (a successful weld test), which falls under the category of how work time is compensated.

name: Single Plate Weld Test Pay
rule_text: (excluding the boiler ¼ Down Hand Plate or other single ¼ plate test, will be paid two (2) hours).
summary: As an exception to the standard additional test pay, a welder who successfully completes a boiler 1/4 Down Hand Plate test or a similar single 1/4 plate test will be paid for two hours.
logical_representation: IF (test_type == 'boiler_1/4_down_hand_plate' OR test_type == 'other_single_1/4_plate') AND test_result == 'success' -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific payment amount (2 hours) for a particular type of work task (a specific weld test), which is a core component of worked time compensation.

name: Multi-Plate Test Pay Cap
rule_text: Additional test consists of three plates welded in the vertical, horizontal and overhead positions and will be paid a maximum of four (4) hours total, upon successful completion.
summary: For a multi-plate additional test involving vertical, horizontal, and overhead positions, the total payment is capped at a maximum of four hours upon successful completion.
logical_representation: IF test_type == '3_plate_additional' AND test_result == 'success' -> MAX(4_HOURS_PAY_TOTAL)
reasoning: This rule establishes a maximum payment threshold for a specific work activity, which is a calculation rule for worked time.

name: Abbreviated Weld Test Pay
rule_text: Those requested to take an abbreviated version of the plate test will be compensated at one and a half (1.5) hours for each successful plate test.
summary: Welders who successfully pass an abbreviated plate test will receive one and a half hours of pay for each test.
logical_representation: IF test_type == 'abbreviated_plate' AND test_result == 'success' -> PAY(1.5_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule specifies a payment amount (1.5 hours) for a work-related task (abbreviated test), directly relating to compensation for time worked.

name: No Pay for Failed Tests
rule_text: In any event a welder will not be paid for a failed test.
summary: A welder will not receive any payment for a welding test that they do not pass.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'fail' -> FORFEIT(pay_for_test_time)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition for non-payment for time spent on a task, which is a fundamental rule of worked time compensation.

name: Discretionary Second Test
rule_text: At the sole discretion of the Weld Test Examiner, the welder may be granted the opportunity to take a second test.
summary: After failing a welding test, a welder may be given a chance to take a second test, but this is entirely up to the discretion of the test examiner.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'fail' AND examiner_discretion == true -> PERMIT(second_test_attempt)
reasoning: This rule governs the process that can lead to a paid work opportunity (a re-test). It is procedural but directly tied to the potential for compensation, placing it within the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category.

name: Travel Allowance for On-Site Tests
rule_text: If a welder is required to test at the job site, the welder shall be paid for any applicable travel allowance, but not for the failed test.
summary: If a welder must test at the job site, they are entitled to receive any applicable travel allowance, even if they fail the test (though the test time itself remains unpaid).
logical_representation: IF test_location == 'job_site' -> PAY(applicable_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule mandates a 'travel allowance', which is a monetary entitlement for travel to a work location, fitting the definition of subsistence and travel-related allowances.

name: Payment for Partial Success (3 of 4 Tests)
rule_text: If an Employer is requesting more than three (3) tests per welder and a welder has successfully completed three (3) of four (4) tests, the Employer may retain the welder and pay for the three (3) successful weld test. If the Employer decides not to retain the welder, he or she will be paid for the three (3) successful weld tests.
summary: If an employer requires more than three tests and the welder passes three out of four, the welder will be paid for the three successful tests, regardless of whether the employer decides to hire them.
logical_representation: IF num_tests_requested > 3 AND num_tests_successful == 3 AND num_tests_attempted >= 4 -> PAY(3_successful_tests)
reasoning: This rule specifies the conditions under which a welder is paid for time spent on multiple tests, making it a rule about compensation for worked time.

name: Pay for Secondary Tests
rule_text: Should a secondary test be required by the Employer, the employee shall be paid for the time required to take such a test.
summary: If an employer requires an employee to take a secondary test, the employee must be paid for the actual time spent taking that test.
logical_representation: IF test_type == 'secondary' -> PAY(actual_time_taken)
reasoning: This rule dictates that time spent on a 'secondary test' is compensable, directly addressing how worked time is paid.

name: Out-of-Town Test Reimbursement
rule_text: Any welder possessing a current Provincial Government welding certificate of qualification, who is instructed to proceed to take tests, necessitating their having to travel outside of the city limits of the city in which they reside or are employed, shall be reimbursed in an amount necessary to compensate them for travel allowance, transportation, travel expenses, subsistence allowance, if applicable.
summary: A certified welder required to travel out of town for a test must be reimbursed for their travel allowance, transportation costs, travel expenses, and any applicable living-out (subsistence) allowance.
logical_representation: IF has_provincial_certificate == true AND test_travel_required == 'outside_city_limits' -> REIMBURSE(travel_allowance, transportation_cost, travel_expenses, subsistence_allowance)
reasoning: This rule explicitly deals with entitlements for 'travel allowance' and 'subsistence allowance' triggered by remote work (traveling for a test), which is the definition of the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Forfeiture for Failure to Report to Work
rule_text: Any welder who successfully completes the welding test, but fails to report for work as notified, without a bona fide reason acceptable to the Employer, will not be eligible for any payment, including testing time and other allowances, as set out in Article 7.00.
summary: If a welder passes a test but then fails to show up for the job without a good, employer-approved reason, they forfeit all payments they would have received for the test, including pay for test time and any allowances.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'success' AND fails_to_report_for_work == true AND reason_unacceptable == true -> FORFEIT(all_article_7_payments)
reasoning: This rule is primarily about the forfeiture of payment for 'testing time' (LABOR_WORKED_TIME), but it also explicitly mentions forfeiting 'other allowances', which could include travel or subsistence, hence the secondary topic.

name: Second Test Opportunity for Pre-Job Failure
rule_text: Any welder required to take a pre-job welding test for employment with an Employer and fails the required weld test, the welder may be granted the opportunity to take a second test.
summary: A welder who fails a required pre-job welding test may be given the chance to take a second test.
logical_representation: IF test_type == 'pre-job' AND test_result == 'fail' -> PERMIT(second_test_attempt)
reasoning: This rule outlines a procedure that can lead to a paid work opportunity (a re-test). It is directly connected to the process of qualifying for paid work, making it relevant to LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Alloy Welder Premium
rule_text: Alloy welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of three dollars and twenty-five cents ($3.25) per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: If an alloy welding certification was a prerequisite for being dispatched to a job, welders holding that certificate will receive an extra $3.25 for every hour they work.
logical_representation: IF has_valid_alloy_certificate == true AND alloy_certification_required_for_dispatch == true -> PREMIUM($3.25/hour)
reasoning: This rule establishes a wage premium, which is a specific rate of pay for hours worked under certain conditions. This is a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Alloy Welder Reclassification and Premium
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to be certified by the Employer and is requested to perform alloy welding, the employee will be reclassified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium from the date of re-classification.
summary: A welder on site who performs alloy welding (either because they already have the certification or are asked to get it) will be reclassified as an alloy welder and will start receiving the alloy premium pay from that date forward.
logical_representation: IF is_requested_to_perform_alloy_welding == true AND ((dispatched_as_alloy_welder == false AND has_alloy_certification == true) OR requested_to_be_certified == true) -> RECLASSIFY('alloy_welder') AND PAY(PREMIUM($3.25/hour_from_reclassification_date))
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions for reclassification and the subsequent application of a wage premium, which directly impacts how an employee's worked time is compensated.

name: Alloy Premium Calculation Rules
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is a flat hourly rate and is not multiplied for overtime hours. However, the premium amount is included when calculating vacation and statutory holiday pay.
logical_representation: IF pay_code == 'alloy_premium' -> DO_NOT_PYRAMID_ON_OT AND INCLUDE_IN_VACATION_PAY_CALC AND INCLUDE_IN_STAT_PAY_CALC
reasoning: This rule specifies how a wage premium interacts with other pay calculations like overtime and vacation pay. These are fundamental rules for categorizing and calculating pay for worked time.

name: No Work Guarantee
rule_text: The Employer does not guarantee to provide work to any employee for regularly assigned hours or any other hours, except as provided for in Article 18.00.
summary: The employer does not guarantee that an employee will be provided work for their regularly scheduled hours or any other hours.
logical_representation: IF has_article_18_provision == false -> CONSTRAINT(work_guarantee == false)
reasoning: This rule establishes a fundamental condition regarding the guarantee of work hours, which is a core concept of worked time and scheduling. It defines the absence of a minimum guarantee.

name: Normal Workday
rule_text: Eight (8) hours per day shall constitute a normal day of work.
summary: A normal workday is defined as eight hours.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(normal_workday_hours == 8)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard length of a workday, which is the basis for calculating daily pay, overtime, and other time-based entitlements. It is a fundamental schedule definition.

name: Normal Hours of Work Window
rule_text: The normal hours of work shall be between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
summary: The standard work hours for a day fall between 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(normal_shift_start_time >= '07:00' AND normal_shift_end_time <= '18:00')
reasoning: This rule defines the standard time window for a shift, which is a core component of schedule definitions within the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Standard Lunch Break
rule_text: an eight (8) hour day with one-half (½) or one (1) hour for lunch at the midpoint of the shift.
summary: An eight-hour workday includes an unpaid lunch break of either 30 minutes or 1 hour, taken around the middle of the shift.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours == 8 -> PROVIDE(unpaid_lunch_break) WHERE lunch_break_duration_hours IN [0.5, 1.0]
reasoning: This rule specifies the duration and timing of an unpaid break within the workday. Since it concerns the structure of the workday and is unpaid, it falls under schedule definitions in LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Normal Work Week
rule_text: Forty (40) hours shall constitute a normal week's work, Monday through Friday inclusive.
summary: A normal work week is defined as 40 hours, worked from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(normal_work_week_hours == 40 AND normal_work_week_days == ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'])
reasoning: This rule defines the standard weekly hours and days, which is the primary threshold for calculating weekly overtime. This is a core schedule definition within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Time Variance Agreement
rule_text: Variances beyond one (1) hour of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. shall be agreed mutually between the Employer and the Local Lodge Business Manager/Secretary-Treasurer. The one (1) hour variance is conditional upon the Employer giving the Local Lodge and affected employees appropriate advance notice.
summary: Start and end times can be adjusted by up to one hour with advance notice. Changes beyond one hour from the standard 7am-6pm window require mutual agreement between the Employer and the Union.
logical_representation: IF shift_start_time < '06:00' OR shift_end_time > '19:00' -> REQUIRES(is_union_agreement_obtained == true); IF shift_start_time < '07:00' OR shift_end_time > '18:00' -> REQUIRES(is_advance_notice_given == true)
reasoning: This rule outlines the conditions and procedures for altering the standard work schedule, which directly relates to how work hours are defined and managed, fitting within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Unilateral Shift Change
rule_text: If the foregoing starting or quitting times are changed without mutual agreement, applicable overtime rates shall be paid for any time worked before or after the above hours as a result of the change of times.
summary: If the employer changes the standard start or end times without mutual agreement, any time worked outside the original schedule must be paid at overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF is_shift_change_mutually_agreed == false -> PAY(hours_worked_outside_standard_schedule, OT)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition under which straight time hours are re-categorized as overtime hours. This is a direct rule about categorizing time buckets and pay rates, which is the core of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Compressed Work Week Schedule Alteration
rule_text: The workdays may be altered (between Monday to Friday inclusive) on any project by mutual agreement in writing between the Local Lodge's Business Manager/Secretary-Treasurer or designate and the Employer. · The hours of work may be altered (between Monday to Friday inclusive) on any project by mutual agreement in writing between the Local Lodge's Business Manager/SecretaryTreasurer or designate and the Employer.
summary: On any project, the workdays and hours (Monday to Friday) can be changed from the standard schedule if the Employer and the Union's representative mutually agree in writing.
logical_representation: IF is_cww_agreement_written == true -> ALLOW(alter_workdays) AND ALLOW(alter_work_hours)
reasoning: This rule specifies the process for establishing a non-standard (compressed) work schedule. Defining work schedules is a key function of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: CWW Make-up Day
rule_text: When working under the four (4) day work week schedule, Friday may be used as a make-up day when weather conditions have caused lost time during the regular work week.
summary: If working a four-day compressed week, Friday can be used as a make-up day if time was lost earlier in the week due to weather.
logical_representation: IF work_schedule_type == '4_day_cww' AND is_time_lost_due_to_weather == true -> ALLOW(work_on_friday_as_makeup)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific type of workday (make-up day) and the conditions for its use, which is a schedule definition rule falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: CWW Make-up Day Timing
rule_text: A make-up day will only be worked during the week in which the time is lost.
summary: A make-up day must be worked in the same week that the original time was lost.
logical_representation: IF is_makeup_day == true -> CONSTRAINT(week_of_makeup_day == week_of_lost_time)
reasoning: This rule places a specific constraint on the scheduling of a make-up day, directly related to how worked time is organized and calculated within a work week. This is a scheduling rule within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Make-up Day Pay Rate
rule_text: Work performed on a make-up day shall be paid at the regular straight time rate for the first ten (10) hours to a maximum of forty (40) hours per week, after which double time (2X) rates shall apply.
summary: Work on a make-up day is paid at straight time for the first 10 hours, as long as total weekly hours don't exceed 40. Any hours worked beyond the 10 daily or 40 weekly hours are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_makeup_day == true -> PAY(hours, ST) WHERE daily_hours <= 10 AND weekly_hours <= 40; IF is_makeup_day == true AND (daily_hours > 10 OR weekly_hours > 40) -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines how hours worked on a specific day type are categorized into pay buckets (ST, DT) based on daily and weekly thresholds. This is a core function of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Make-up Day Minimum Hours
rule_text: In no case shall the time scheduled on a make-up day be less than eight (8) hours except where weather conditions dictate otherwise.
summary: A make-up day must be scheduled for at least eight hours, unless bad weather forces a shorter day.
logical_representation: IF is_makeup_day == true AND is_weather_disruption == false -> MIN(8_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum number of hours for a specific type of shift (make-up day). Minimum guarantees and scheduling parameters are central to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Make-up Day Voluntariness
rule_text: All time worked on a make-up day will be at the employee's choice.
summary: Working on a make-up day is voluntary for the employee.
logical_representation: IF is_makeup_day == true -> CONSTRAINT(employee_work_is_voluntary == true)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition on the scheduling of work, making it voluntary. This relates to hours of work and employee obligations, which is part of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Holiday Week ST Threshold
rule_text: Where a holiday occurs during the normal work week the maximum of thirty (30) hours per week shall form the basis of maximum straight time rate.
summary: In a week that includes a recognized holiday, the weekly straight time maximum is reduced to 30 hours before overtime applies.
logical_representation: IF is_holiday_in_week == true -> MAX(30_HOURS_ST_PER_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule modifies the weekly overtime threshold based on the presence of a holiday. Rules that define thresholds for transitioning between pay buckets (ST, OT) are central to LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Weekend and Holiday Overtime
rule_text: Work performed on Saturday, Sunday, or Recognized Holidays shall be paid at the applicable overtime premium.
summary: All work performed on a Saturday, Sunday, or a Recognized Holiday must be paid at the appropriate overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN'] OR is_recognized_holiday == true -> PAY(hours_worked, OT)
reasoning: This rule categorizes all hours worked on specific days (weekends, holidays) as overtime. This classification of time based on the day it is worked is a fundamental rule type for LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Work Hours Independent of Other Trades
rule_text: Employees will not be required to work less than the regular assigned hours because of the starting or quitting time of any other trade on the job.
summary: An employee cannot be forced to work fewer than their regularly scheduled hours just because another trade on the job starts late or finishes early.
logical_representation: IF other_trade_schedule_conflict == true -> CONSTRAINT(hours_worked >= regularly_assigned_hours)
reasoning: This rule protects an employee's scheduled hours from being reduced due to external factors. It is a form of work guarantee/minimum hours rule, which falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Working Through Lunch Break
rule_text: An employee shall not be required to work during their regular lunch break except in emergency or special circumstances, in which case, they will receive a re-assigned one-half (½) hour lunch break.
summary: Employees cannot be required to work through their lunch break unless there's an emergency or special situation. If they are, they must be given a rescheduled 30-minute lunch break.
logical_representation: IF is_emergency == true OR is_special_circumstance == true -> ALLOW(work_during_lunch) AND PROVIDE(reassigned_lunch_break_30_min)
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions under which an employee can work during a break and the entitlement to a rescheduled break. This is a rule about the structure and conditions of the workday, classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Offset Lunch Break
rule_text: If this break falls outside the regular lunch break established on the job, they shall receive an additional allowance of one-half (½) hour of pay at straight time rates which shall be in addition to their regular straight time hours.
summary: If an employee has to work through their regular lunch and their rescheduled break occurs outside the normal lunch period, they get an extra 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF is_reassigned_lunch_outside_regular_window == true -> PREMIUM(0.5_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary premium (an allowance of pay) for a specific work condition (a displaced lunch break). As it's a direct payment calculated from the straight time rate and added to hours, it's a rule about how time is compensated, fitting it into LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Rest Breaks on 8-Hour Shift
rule_text: When working eight (8) hour work shifts, two (2) rest or coffee breaks of ten (10) minutes each shall be established by the Employer.
summary: On an 8-hour shift, the employer must provide two 10-minute paid rest or coffee breaks.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours == 8 -> PROVIDE(paid_breaks) WHERE break_count = 2 AND break_duration_minutes = 10
reasoning: This rule defines an entitlement to paid breaks during the workday. Paid breaks are a component of the overall compensated work time, making this a rule for LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Pre-Overtime Rest Break
rule_text: If overtime is to follow the regular eight (8) hour work shift, a further ten (10) minute rest or coffee break shall be established before commencing overtime.
summary: If an employee is required to work overtime immediately after their regular 8-hour shift, they must be given an additional 10-minute rest break before the overtime starts.
logical_representation: IF is_overtime_after_8hr_shift == true -> PROVIDE(paid_break) WHERE break_duration_minutes = 10
reasoning: This rule provides for a paid break triggered by working overtime. It is an entitlement related to the structure of the workday and compensated hours, fitting it within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Rest Breaks on 10-Hour Shift
rule_text: At the sole discretion of the Employer, where a scheduled ten (10) hour workday is established, the rest or coffee breaks may be either three (3) breaks of ten (10) minutes each, (described above) or two (2) breaks of fifteen (15) minutes each.
summary: For a scheduled 10-hour workday, the employer can choose to provide either three 10-minute breaks or two 15-minute breaks.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours == 10 -> PROVIDE(paid_breaks) WHERE (break_count = 3 AND break_duration_minutes = 10) OR (break_count = 2 AND break_duration_minutes = 15)
reasoning: This rule details the options for paid rest breaks on a specific shift length. As it concerns paid time within the workday schedule, it belongs to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Alternative Paid Breaks on 10-Hour Shift
rule_text: When working ten (10) hour shifts, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two (2) breaks of one-half (½) hour each, both paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On a 10-hour shift, the employer has the option to replace the standard breaks and lunch with two 30-minute paid breaks, spread out evenly during the shift.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours == 10 AND employer_break_choice == 'option_2' -> PROVIDE(paid_breaks) WHERE break_count = 2 AND break_duration_minutes = 30
reasoning: This rule presents an alternative structure for paid breaks and meals within a 10-hour shift. Since it defines what constitutes paid time during a shift, it is a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Notice for Break Schedule Change
rule_text: A change in the scheduling of a break will normally be communicated to the affected employees prior to the end of the work cycle before the change.
summary: Normally, if the timing of a break is going to be changed, employees will be notified before the end of their previous work cycle.
logical_representation: IF is_break_schedule_changed == true -> REQUIRES(provide_advance_notice)
reasoning: This rule establishes a procedural requirement for changing part of the daily work schedule (breaks). It pertains to the administration of work hours and conditions, which is part of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Work Week Definition
rule_text: For the purpose of clarification and to define Saturday and Sunday work, the work shall be deemed to commence at the starting time of the regular day shift on Monday morning.
summary: The work week officially begins at the start of the regular day shift on Monday morning. This definition is used to determine which work hours fall on a Saturday or Sunday for pay purposes.
logical_representation: `work_week_start` == `monday_day_shift_start_time` -> DEFINE(saturday_work), DEFINE(sunday_work)
reasoning: This rule establishes the temporal framework (the work week) within which hours are categorized for pay (e.g., Saturday/Sunday work), which is a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Start Flexibility
rule_text: Shifts may be commenced on any calendar day provided the appropriate requirements for shift premium and overtime as specified in this Agreement are met.
summary: Shifts are allowed to start on any day of the week, as long as the corresponding rules for shift premium and overtime pay are correctly applied.
logical_representation: IF `shift_start_day` IN [mon, tue, wed, thu, fri, sat, sun] -> TRUE | CONDITION(APPLY(shift_premium_rules)), CONDITION(APPLY(overtime_rules))
reasoning: This rule pertains to work scheduling and directly links the flexibility of shift start days to the application of pay categories like overtime and premiums, which are central to LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: First Shift Definition
rule_text: For the purpose of defining the shifts, the 1st shift shall be the day shift which commences at 7:00 a.m. This starting time may be varied by mutual agreement to suit job requirements.
summary: The first shift is defined as the day shift, which normally begins at 7:00 a.m. However, this start time can be changed if both the employer and employees agree it's necessary for a job.
logical_representation: `shift_number` == 1 -> `shift_name` = 'day_shift', `default_start_time` = '07:00' | ALLOW(VARIATION_BY_MUTUAL_AGREEMENT)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific work schedule (the first/day shift), which is a foundational element for categorizing hours worked and falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Second and Third Shift Definition
rule_text: The second (2 nd ) shift shall be the afternoon shift and shall follow the first (1 st ) shift. The third (3 rd ) shift shall be the night shift and shall follow the second (2 nd ) shift.
summary: The second shift is the afternoon shift which follows the first shift, and the third shift is the night shift which follows the second shift.
logical_representation: `shift_number` == 2 -> `shift_name` = 'afternoon_shift' | `shift_number` == 3 -> `shift_name` = 'night_shift'
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines work schedules (afternoon and night shifts), which is a primary component of categorizing worked time as per LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Transition Time Limit
rule_text: Second (2 nd ) and third (3 rd ) shifts shall commence not later than one (1) hour after the completion of the preceding shift, except where this is prevented by conditions or requirements beyond the control of the Employer.
summary: The second and third shifts must start no more than one hour after the previous shift ends, unless unavoidable circumstances beyond the employer's control prevent it.
logical_representation: IF `shift_number` IN [2, 3] AND `unavoidable_delay` == false -> `start_time` <= `preceding_shift_end_time` + 1_hour
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific scheduling constraint related to the timing of shifts, which falls under the definition and management of work schedules in LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Premium Entitlement
rule_text: A shift premium shall apply on all hours worked on second (2 nd ) and third (3 rd ) shifts at the rates as set out in the Wage and Benefit Schedule.
summary: Employees are entitled to a shift premium for all hours worked during the second (afternoon) and third (night) shifts. The exact rate for this premium is specified in the Wage and Benefit Schedule.
logical_representation: IF `shift_number` IN [2, 3] -> PREMIUM(`wage_and_benefit_schedule_rate`)
reasoning: This rule establishes a pay premium based on the time of day worked (i.e., which shift). Categorizing hours and applying different pay rates based on that categorization is a core function of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Premium Rate
rule_text: All shift premium hours will be paid at a rate of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per hour.
summary: The shift premium rate is a flat $4.50 for each hour that qualifies for the premium.
logical_representation: IF `hour_is_shift_premium_eligible` -> PREMIUM($4.50)
reasoning: This rule provides the specific monetary value for a premium applied to certain categories of worked hours (2nd and 3rd shifts), directly fitting within the scope of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Inadequate Rest Period Penalty
rule_text: When an employee is required to return to work without an eight (8) hour break, all work performed shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rates, until such time as the employee receives an eight (8) hour break.
summary: If an employee is required to return to work with less than an 8-hour rest break since their last shift, all hours they work will be paid at overtime rates. This overtime pay continues until they are finally given an 8-hour break.
logical_representation: IF `hours_of_break_between_work_periods` < 8 -> TRANSITION(OT) UNTIL `hours_of_break_between_work_periods` >= 8
reasoning: This rule re-categorizes hours from straight time to overtime based on the duration of the rest period between work. This modification of hour categorization for pay purposes is a key function of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Schedule Change Process
rule_text: The Local Lodge agrees to discuss the flexibility and options of shift schedules as brought forward at the request of the Employer/Owner. No such changes will be implemented without the mutual consent of both parties. Any and all other Articles, Terms and Conditions shall apply.
summary: The union has agreed to discuss potential changes to shift schedules if requested by the employer. However, no changes can be made unless both parties mutually agree. Any agreed-upon changes are still subject to all other rules in the contract.
logical_representation: IF `employer_request_for_schedule_change` -> ACTION(DISCUSS) | IF `proposed_schedule_change` -> IMPLEMENTATION_REQUIRES(mutual_consent)
reasoning: This rule outlines the procedure for modifying work schedules. Since the definition and rules of work schedules are a core part of LABOR_WORKED_TIME, the process for changing those schedules also falls under this topic.

name: Weekday Overtime Rate (Initial)
rule_text: When an employee is required to work in excess of the regular hours, Monday through Friday inclusive, they shall be paid overtime at the rate of time and one- half (1 ½) the regular rate of pay.
summary: For work on Monday to Friday, hours worked beyond the regular daily hours are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI] AND daily_hours_worked > regular_daily_hours -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the conditions and rate for the first tier of overtime pay, which is a core concept of categorizing worked time.

name: Weekday Double Time Threshold
rule_text: Double (2) time will be paid after ten (10) hours worked.
summary: On weekdays, any work performed after 10 hours in a day is paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI] AND daily_hours_worked > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific threshold for transitioning from one pay category (Overtime) to another (Double Time), which is a key function of worked time classification.

name: Weekend and Holiday Overtime Rate
rule_text: Employees working on a Saturday, Sunday, and Recognized Holidays shall be paid an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or a Recognized Holiday are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN [SAT, SUN] OR is_holiday == TRUE -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, DT)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for special days (weekends, holidays), which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime Calculation, 5x8 Schedule
rule_text:
| Day of Week | Straight Time | Time and One Half (1.5x) | Double Time (2x) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Monday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours |
| Tuesday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours |
| Wednesday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours |
| Thursday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours |
| Friday | 8 hours | Up to 2 hours | After 10 hours |
| Saturday | | | All hours |
| Sunday | | | All hours |
| Stat Holiday | | | All hours |
summary: On a 5-day, 8-hour/day schedule, the first 8 hours Monday-Friday are straight time, the next 2 are time-and-a-half, and any hours after 10 are double time. All hours on weekends and holidays are double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' -> { IF day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU,FRI] -> PAY(FIRST(8), ST) | PAY(NEXT(2), OT) | PAY(AFTER(10), DT) }; { IF day_of_week IN [SAT,SUN] OR is_holiday == TRUE -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, DT) }
reasoning: This rule provides a complete definition of how hours are categorized into different pay buckets for a specific work schedule, which is central to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Overtime Calculation, 4x10 Schedule (Mon-Thu)
rule_text:
| Day of Week | Straight Time | Time and One Half (1.5x) | Double Time (2x) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Monday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Tuesday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Wednesday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Thursday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Friday | | Up to 10 hours | After 10 hours |
| Saturday | | | All hours |
| Sunday | | | All hours |
| Stat Holiday | | | All hours |
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour/day (Mon-Thu) schedule, the first 10 hours on workdays are straight time, with hours after 10 paid at double time. On Friday, the first 10 hours are time-and-a-half, and hours after 10 are double time. Weekends and holidays are all double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' -> { IF day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU] -> PAY(FIRST(10), ST) | PAY(AFTER(10), DT) }; { IF day_of_week == FRI -> PAY(FIRST(10), OT) | PAY(AFTER(10), DT) }; { IF day_of_week IN [SAT,SUN] OR is_holiday == TRUE -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, DT) }
reasoning: This rule provides a complete definition of how hours are categorized into different pay buckets for a specific work schedule, which is central to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Overtime Calculation, 4x10 Schedule (Tue-Fri)
rule_text:
| Day of Week | Straight Time | Time and One Half (1.5x) | Double Time (2x) |
|---|---|---|---|
| Monday | | Up to 10 hours | After 10 hours |
| Tuesday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Wednesday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Thursday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Friday | 10 hours | | After 10 hours |
| Saturday | | | All hours |
| Sunday | | | All hours |
| Stat Holiday | | | All hours |
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour/day (Tue-Fri) schedule, the first 10 hours on workdays are straight time, with hours after 10 paid at double time. On Monday, the first 10 hours are time-and-a-half, and hours after 10 are double time. Weekends and holidays are all double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' -> { IF day_of_week IN [TUE,WED,THU,FRI] -> PAY(FIRST(10), ST) | PAY(AFTER(10), DT) }; { IF day_of_week == MON -> PAY(FIRST(10), OT) | PAY(AFTER(10), DT) }; { IF day_of_week IN [SAT,SUN] OR is_holiday == TRUE -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, DT) }
reasoning: This rule provides a complete definition of how hours are categorized into different pay buckets for a specific work schedule, which is central to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Voluntariness
rule_text: Any unscheduled overtime will be voluntary and worked at the employees' discretion.
summary: Employees are not required to work unscheduled overtime; they can choose whether or not to accept it.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == UNSCHEDULED -> CONSTRAINT(VOLUNTARY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition related to the assignment of overtime hours, which falls under the management and classification of worked time.

name: Shift Premium on Overtime
rule_text: Employees working overtime shall continue to receive their shift premium for all hours worked.
summary: Shift premiums are paid for all overtime hours worked, in addition to the overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF is_overtime == TRUE AND has_shift_premium == TRUE -> PAY(PREMIUM(shift_premium))
reasoning: This rule specifies how a pay premium is applied to worked hours categorized as overtime, making it a worked time rule.

name: No Compounding of Shift Premium
rule_text: The shift premium shall not be compounded for overtime hours worked.
summary: Shift premiums are calculated based on the straight-time rate, not the overtime rate (e.g., it is not multiplied by 1.5x or 2x).
logical_representation: IF is_overtime == TRUE -> CONSTRAINT(shift_premium_not_compounded)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific calculation constraint on pay for overtime hours, which is part of how worked time is costed and categorized.

name: Initial Overtime Meal Entitlement
rule_text: When an employee works beyond ten (10) hours per day, they shall be entitled to a meal break and meal supplied by the Company.
summary: An employee is entitled to a company-provided meal and a meal break after working more than 10 hours in a day.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours_worked > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL) AND PROVIDE(MEAL_BREAK)
reasoning: This rule establishes the primary trigger (working beyond 10 hours) for an employee to receive a meal benefit, which is the core definition of a meal allowance rule.

name: Subsequent Overtime Meal Entitlement
rule_text: The meal break will be provided after ten (10) hours of work and subsequent meal breaks each four (4) hours thereafter.
summary: After the first meal break at 10 hours, an employee is entitled to another meal break every four hours they continue to work.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours_worked > 10 -> MEAL_TRIG(1) | IF overtime_hours_worked_after_first_meal % 4 == 0 -> MEAL_TRIG(NEXT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the recurring conditions under which an employee is entitled to a meal benefit, making it a meal allowance rule.

name: Meal Break Scheduling Prerogative
rule_text: However, it will be the prerogative of the Company in conjunction with the Job Steward to arrange meal breaks for efficiency and convenience of the job.
summary: The exact timing of meal breaks can be adjusted by the company and the Job Steward to suit job site needs.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(meal_break_timing_flexible_by_agreement)
reasoning: This rule governs the administration and scheduling of a meal benefit, directly relating it to the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Meal Break Exception for 4x10 Schedule
rule_text: When the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is worked, recognizing emergency situations will arise, if the Company has not scheduled in excess of the ten (10) hour shift, the Company shall be granted a one (1) hour extension where a meal and meal break are not required.
summary: On a 4x10 schedule, if overtime beyond the 10-hour shift was not pre-scheduled, the company can extend the workday by one hour (to 11 hours) without providing a meal or meal break.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND overtime_is_scheduled == FALSE AND daily_hours_worked <= 11 -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ENTITLEMENT)
reasoning: This rule specifies an exception condition where a meal entitlement, which would normally be triggered, is forfeited. This directly modifies a meal allowance rule.

name: Meal Break on Scheduled Overtime
rule_text: When an employee works Scheduled Overtime (work performed on Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays) they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds ten (10) hours).
summary: During scheduled overtime on weekends or holidays, an employee gets a meal break after working more than 10 hours of overtime.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == SCHEDULED AND overtime_hours_worked > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_BREAK)
reasoning: This rule defines the trigger condition (over 10 hours of a specific overtime type) for a meal benefit entitlement, classifying it as a meal allowance rule.

name: Meal Break on Emergency Call-Out
rule_text: When an employee works Short Notice Emergency Call-Out Overtime (overtime work performed other than continuous with the regular work day or Scheduled Overtime) they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds four (4) hours.
summary: For emergency call-outs that are not connected to a regular shift, an employee gets a meal break after working more than 4 hours.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == EMERGENCY_CALL_OUT AND overtime_hours_worked > 4 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_BREAK)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific trigger condition (over 4 hours of emergency call-out work) for a meal benefit, clearly placing it within the meal allowance category.

name: No Meal Entitlement at Overtime Conclusion
rule_text: No entitlement shall occur at the conclusion of overtime.
summary: An employee is not entitled to a final meal or break right when their overtime work ends.
logical_representation: IF work_status == END_OF_OVERTIME -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ENTITLEMENT)
reasoning: This rule places a specific constraint on meal entitlements, defining when they do not apply. This makes it a meal allowance rule.

name: Overtime Meal Break Duration and Pay
rule_text: All overtime meal breaks will be thirty (30) minutes in duration and will be paid for at straight time rates.
summary: Overtime meal breaks are 30 minutes long and are paid at the employee's regular straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF is_overtime_meal_break == TRUE -> DURATION(30_MINUTES) AND PAY(30_MINUTES, ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the properties (duration and pay rate) of a meal benefit, which falls under the administration of meal allowances.

name: Meal Break Not Counted for Entitlement
rule_text: However, in calculating entitlement to a meal, the thirty (30) minute break shall not count as overtime work.
summary: The 30-minute paid meal break does not count as 'hours worked' when determining eligibility for the next meal break.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(meal_break_time_excluded_from_meal_entitlement_calculation)
reasoning: This is a calculation rule that directly affects how and when subsequent meal entitlements are triggered, making it a LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE rule.

name: Supervisor Meal Exclusion for Short Extensions
rule_text: When a supervisor is required to: a) Start up to one (1) hour earlier, or b) Finish up to one (1) hour later, or c) Start up to one-half (1/2) hour earlier and finish up to one-half (1/2) hour later than the foreperson's crews...the foreperson shall not be entitled to a meal or meal break as per article 13.02
summary: A supervisor who starts up to an hour early or stays up to an hour late for prep/wrap-up is not entitled to an overtime meal break for that extra time.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == SUPERVISOR AND (extra_hours_start <= 1 OR extra_hours_end <= 1) -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ENTITLEMENT)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific condition under which a meal entitlement is forfeited for a particular role, which is a key aspect of meal allowance rules.

name: Supervisor Meal Exclusion Override
rule_text: ...unless those provisions are applicable to the rest of the crew or the supervisor works more than two (2) hours beyond the end of their scheduled shift.
summary: A supervisor does get a meal break if either their entire crew is also eligible, or if the supervisor works more than two hours past their shift's end.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == SUPERVISOR AND (crew_meal_eligible == TRUE OR supervisor_overtime_hours > 2) -> OVERRIDE(FORFEIT(MEAL_ENTITLEMENT))
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to a meal forfeiture rule, making it an integral part of the overall LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE logic.

name: Scheduled Overtime Meal Allowance In Lieu
rule_text: Scheduled Overtime...I) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight-time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break, and 2. II) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If it's impractical to provide a meal during scheduled overtime, the employee receives 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time rate and a 15-minute paid rest break instead.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == SCHEDULED AND is_meal_provided == FALSE -> PAY(30_MINUTES, ST) AND PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(15_MINUTES))
reasoning: This rule specifies the monetary and time-off compensation provided when a meal entitlement cannot be fulfilled, which is a core component of a meal allowance policy.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Meal Allowance In Lieu
rule_text: Unscheduled Overtime...I) a payment of forty dollars ($40.00) as a meal allowance. 2. II) a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight-time total package hourly rate in the lieu of meal break, and 3. III) a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If it's impractical to provide a meal during unscheduled overtime, the employee receives a $40 payment, 30 minutes of pay at their straight-time rate, and a 15-minute paid rest break.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == UNSCHEDULED AND is_meal_provided == FALSE -> ALLOWANCE($40) AND PAY(30_MINUTES, ST) AND PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(15_MINUTES))
reasoning: This rule specifies the monetary and time-off compensation provided when a meal entitlement cannot be fulfilled under specific circumstances, which is a core component of a meal allowance policy.

name: Meal Allowance Forfeiture on Subsistence
rule_text: There shall be no meal allowance applicable to those receiving subsistence...
summary: Employees who receive a subsistence (living-out) allowance are not eligible for the overtime meal allowance.
logical_representation: IF receives_subsistence == TRUE -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (receiving subsistence) under which a meal allowance is forfeited. This directly modifies meal allowance entitlement.

name: Meal Allowance Reinstatement for Subsistence Reduction
rule_text: ...however any reduction to the current subsistence rates will attract a meal allowance payment equivalent to the reduction.
summary: If an employee's subsistence payment is reduced, they will receive a meal allowance payment equal to the amount of the reduction.
logical_representation: IF subsistence_is_reduced == TRUE -> ALLOWANCE(subsistence_reduction_amount)
reasoning: This rule creates a meal allowance payment that is directly tied to a change in subsistence rates, making it primarily a meal allowance rule that is triggered by a subsistence event.

name: Meal Allowance Forfeiture with Camp Meal
rule_text: Where a camp is provided, employees will not receive the forty dollars ($40.00) meal allowance where they are able to receive a camp meal at the end of their shift.
summary: Employees staying in a provided camp who can get a meal there at the end of their shift are not eligible for the $40 meal allowance.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_provided == TRUE AND is_camp_meal_available == TRUE -> FORFEIT(MEAL_AMT($40))
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition (availability of a camp meal) that results in the forfeiture of a specific monetary meal allowance, clearly placing it in the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: 12-Hour Shift Implementation
rule_text: Upon written notice to the Local Lodge, the Employer may implement a twelve (12) hour shift with three (3) half hour paid breaks under the following conditions.
summary: The employer can start using a 12-hour shift schedule, which includes three paid half-hour breaks, after providing written notice to the Local Lodge.
logical_representation: IF is_notice_given == TRUE -> ACTION(implement_12_hour_shift)
reasoning: This rule governs the conditions for implementing a specific work schedule, which is a fundamental aspect of defining and categorizing worked time.

name: 12-Hour Shift Pay Calculation (4x10 basis)
rule_text: Four (4) x ten (10) Monday to Thursday or Tuesday to Friday: Ten (10) hours @ straight time, two (2) hours @ doubletime (2x)
summary: On a 12-hour shift based on a 4x10 schedule, employees are paid 10 hours at straight time and 2 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12_hour_on_4x10_basis' AND shift_duration == 12 -> PAY(FIRST(10), ST) AND PAY(NEXT(2), DT)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines how hours are categorized into pay buckets (ST, DT) for a special shift type, which is a core function of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: 12-Hour Shift Pay Calculation (5x8 basis)
rule_text: Five (5) x eight (8) Monday to Friday: Eight (8) hours @ straight time, two (2) hours at time and one half (1 ½), two (2) hours at doubletime (2x)
summary: On a 12-hour shift based on a 5x8 schedule, employees are paid 8 hours at straight time, 2 hours at time-and-a-half, and 2 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12_hour_on_5x8_basis' AND shift_duration == 12 -> PAY(FIRST(8), ST) AND PAY(NEXT(2), OT) AND PAY(NEXT(2), DT)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines how hours are categorized into pay buckets (ST, OT, DT) for a special shift type, making it a clear LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: 12-Hour Shift Weekend/Holiday Pay
rule_text: Any hours worked on Saturday, Sunday or Holidays will be paid at the applicable overtime rates, as per the agreement.
summary: Even on a 12-hour shift schedule, work on weekends and holidays is paid at the standard overtime rates defined elsewhere in the agreement.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12_hour' AND (day_of_week IN [SAT, SUN] OR is_holiday == TRUE) -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, APPLICABLE_OT_RATE)
reasoning: This rule clarifies how worked time is categorized and paid on special days within the context of a specific shift schedule, placing it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: 12-Hour Shift Breaks
rule_text: All employees on this shift must observe three (3) half hour breaks.
summary: It is mandatory for all employees on a 12-hour shift to take three separate half-hour breaks.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '12_hour' -> CONSTRAINT(MANDATORY_BREAKS(3, 30_MINUTES))
reasoning: This rule mandates breaks during a shift. While the breaks are paid, the rule's primary function is to govern the structure of the workday, which is an aspect of managing worked time.

name: Overtime Calculation - 4x10 Schedule with 15-min Break
summary: On a 4x10 schedule with a 15-minute overtime break, the first 10 hours are straight time. Any hours worked beyond 10 are paid at double time, and a half-hour paid meal break at straight time is also provided.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10' AND overtime_break_duration == 15 AND hours_on_site > 10 -> ALLOCATE(10, ST) AND ALLOCATE(hours_on_site - 10, DT) AND PAY(0.5, ST)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines how hours worked on a specific schedule are categorized into different pay buckets (ST, DT) and includes a paid meal break, making it a classic worked time rule.

name: Overtime Calculation - 4x10 Schedule with 30-min Break
rule_text:
| 4 x 10's Schedule        | 4 x 10's Schedule        | 4 x 10's Schedule        | 4 x 10's Schedule        |
|--------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|--------------------------|
| Overtime Break is 30-min | Overtime Break is 30-min | Overtime Break is 30-min | Overtime Break is 30-min |
| ST                       | OT                       | DT                       | Meal ST                  |
| 10                       | N/A                      | N/A                      | N/A                      |
| 10                       | N/A                      | 1                        | N/A                      |
| 10                       | N/A                      | 2                        | N/A                      |
| 10                       | N/A                      | 3                        | N/A                      |
summary: On a 4x10 schedule with a 30-minute overtime break, the first 10 hours are straight time. Any hours worked beyond 10 are paid at double time. No paid meal break is provided in this scenario.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10' AND overtime_break_duration == 30 AND hours_on_site > 10 -> ALLOCATE(10, ST) AND ALLOCATE(hours_on_site - 10, DT)
reasoning: This rule defines how worked hours are categorized into pay buckets (ST, DT) based on the schedule and break duration, which is a core function of worked time rules.

name: Holiday Entitlement - Time Off
rule_text: All employees covered by this Agreement shall be entitled to time off for the Recognized Holidays.
summary: Employees have the right to take the day off for any holiday recognized in the agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_recognized_holiday == TRUE -> ENTITLEMENT(time_off)
reasoning: This rule establishes the basic entitlement to a day off, which is a fundamental aspect of managing an employee's work time and schedule.

name: Holiday Pay Allowance - General
rule_text: The pay allowance as provided for in the appropriate Appendix shall be included in the employees'  weekly  pay.
summary: Employees receive a holiday pay allowance in their weekly paycheck, with the specific amount detailed in an appendix.
logical_representation: PAY(holiday_allowance)
reasoning: This rule dictates a payment related to a non-worked day (a holiday), which falls under the compensation rules for an employee's time.

name: Holiday Pay Allowance - In Lieu Of
rule_text: This  pay  allowance  shall  be  in  lieu  of  actual  pay  for  any  of  the Recognized Holidays as specified herein.
summary: The holiday pay allowance replaces the regular pay an employee would have received for working on that holiday.
logical_representation: holiday_allowance -> REPLACES(holiday_pay)
reasoning: This clarifies how the holiday allowance interacts with regular pay, making it a rule about the calculation and classification of time and pay.

name: Holiday Pay Allowance - Calculation Base
rule_text: This  pay  allowance  shall  be  applied  to  gross  wages  for  all  hours  earned  including: overtime and shift premium; and also to waiting and reporting time per Article 15.00; daily travel allowance per Article 16.01.
summary: The holiday pay allowance is calculated as a percentage or factor applied to the employee's gross wages, which includes all earned hours, premiums, and other specified allowances.
logical_representation: holiday_allowance = CALCULATE_ON(gross_wages(all_hours_earned, overtime_premium, shift_premium, waiting_time, reporting_time, daily_travel_allowance))
reasoning: This is a complex calculation rule that defines the earnings base for an allowance. It directly pertains to how compensation for time (worked or not) is calculated.

name: Recognized Holidays - List
rule_text:
The following Recognized Holidays are observed by this Agreement:

| New Year's Day   | Family Day                                |
|------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| Good Friday      | Victoria Day                              |
| Canada Day       | Civic Day                                 |
| Labour Day       | National Day for Truth and Reconciliation |
| Thanksgiving Day | Remembrance Day                           |
| Christmas Day    | Boxing Day                                |
summary: The agreement specifies twelve official holidays: New Year's Day, Family Day, Good Friday, Victoria Day, Canada Day, Civic Day, Labour Day, National Day for Truth and Reconciliation, Thanksgiving Day, Remembrance Day, Christmas Day, and Boxing Day.
logical_representation: RECOGNIZED_HOLIDAYS = ['New Year\'s Day', 'Family Day', 'Good Friday', 'Victoria Day', 'Canada Day', 'Civic Day', 'Labour Day', 'National Day for Truth and Reconciliation', 'Thanksgiving Day', 'Remembrance Day', 'Christmas Day', 'Boxing Day']
reasoning: This rule defines the specific days that are subject to all other holiday rules, making it a foundational element of scheduling and pay for time.

name: Recognized Holidays - Future Additions
rule_text: And any other Holiday(s) that may be proclaimed by Federal or Provincial Governments during the life of this Agreement.
summary: Any new holidays officially declared by the federal or provincial government will also be recognized under this agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_government_proclaimed_holiday == TRUE -> ADD(RECOGNIZED_HOLIDAYS)
reasoning: This rule dynamically updates the list of recognized holidays, affecting scheduling and pay. It is therefore a rule about managing worked time.

name: Holiday Work Pay Rate
rule_text: Employees working on a Recognized Holiday shall be paid an overtime rate at double (2) time the regular rate of pay.
summary: If an employee works on a recognized holiday, they must be paid at double their regular hourly rate.
logical_representation: IF is_working == TRUE AND day_type == RECOGNIZED_HOLIDAY -> PAY_RATE(2.0)
reasoning: This is a direct rule about the pay rate for hours worked on a specific type of day (a holiday), which is a core concept of categorizing worked time.

name: Holiday Observance - Weekend Shift (General)
rule_text: Should any of the above listed holidays (Article 14.02) occur on a Saturday or Sunday, such  holiday  shall  be  observed  on  the  preceding  Friday  or  on  the  Monday  following  unless changed by mutual agreement between the Employer and the Local Lodge Representative.
summary: If a holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, it will be observed on either the preceding Friday or the following Monday, unless otherwise agreed upon.
logical_representation: IF holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.preceding('Friday') OR holiday_date.following('Monday')
reasoning: This rule dictates the scheduling of a non-worked day, directly impacting the work week structure and pay.

name: Straight Time Maximum - 4x10 Week with Holiday
rule_text: When the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is being worked and a Holiday falls during the normal work week the maximum of thirty (30) hours per week shall form the basis of maximum straight time.
summary: In a week with a holiday on a 4x10 schedule, the maximum number of straight-time hours for the week is reduced to 30.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10' AND week_has_holiday == TRUE -> MAX(30, ST_per_week)
reasoning: This rule sets the threshold for when overtime begins in a specific weekly scenario, which is a fundamental rule for categorizing worked time.

name: Holiday Observance - 5x8 Mid-Week
rule_text: When working the five (5) x eight (8) hour work week and the recognized holiday falls in the  work  week the holiday is observed on the day it falls.
summary: For employees on a standard 5x8 work week, a holiday that falls on a weekday is observed on that specific day.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '5x8' AND holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday'] -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date
reasoning: This rule defines the specific day of observance for a holiday based on the work schedule, affecting scheduling and pay.

name: Holiday Observance - 5x8 Weekend
rule_text: If the holiday falls  on Saturday or Sunday, it is moved to the preceding Friday or the following Monday.
summary: For employees on a 5x8 schedule, if a holiday falls on a weekend, it is observed on the preceding Friday or the following Monday.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '5x8' AND holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.preceding('Friday') OR holiday_date.following('Monday')
reasoning: This rule dictates the rescheduling of a non-worked day due to a weekend conflict, directly impacting the work week structure.

name: Holiday Observance - 4x10 Mid-Week
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week and the recognized holiday falls in the work week it will be observed on the day it falls.
summary: For employees on a 4x10 work week, a holiday that falls on one of their regular workdays is observed on that specific day.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10' AND holiday_date IN work_days -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date
reasoning: This rule defines the day of observance for a holiday based on a 4x10 schedule, affecting scheduling and pay.

name: Holiday Observance - 4x10 Mon-Thurs, Friday Holiday
rule_text: When working  the  four  (4)  x  ten  (10)  hour  work  week  Monday  to  Thursday  and  the recognized holiday falls on the Friday it will be moved to the preceding Thursday.
summary: For employees on a Monday-Thursday 4x10 schedule, if a holiday falls on a Friday, it is observed on the preceding Thursday instead.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thurs' AND holiday_date.day_of_week == 'Friday' -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.preceding('Thursday')
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific rescheduling of a holiday observance to a workday, affecting the employee's work schedule and potential pay for that day.

name: Overtime Rates - 4x10 Mon-Thurs Schedule
rule_text: Thursday is the double time day and Friday is the time and one-half day.
summary: On a Monday-Thursday 4x10 schedule, hours worked on Thursday after the regular 10 are paid at double time, and all hours worked on Friday are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thurs' AND day_of_week == 'Thursday' -> PAY_RATE(2.0, AFTER(10)) | IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thurs' AND day_of_week == 'Friday' -> PAY_RATE(1.5)
reasoning: This specifies the overtime multipliers for specific days on a particular schedule, which is a core rule for calculating pay for worked time.

name: Holiday Observance - 4x10 Mon-Thurs, Weekend Holiday
rule_text: If the holiday falls on Saturday or Sunday, it is moved to the following Monday.
summary: For employees on a Monday-Thursday 4x10 schedule, a holiday falling on a weekend is observed on the following Monday.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thurs' AND holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.following('Monday')
reasoning: This rule dictates the rescheduling of a non-worked day, directly impacting the employee's schedule.

name: Holiday Observance - 4x10 Tues-Fri, Monday Holiday
rule_text: When working the four (4) x ten (10) hour work week Tuesday to Friday and the holiday falls  on  the  Monday  it  is  observed  on  the  Tuesday.
summary: For employees on a Tuesday-Friday 4x10 schedule, if a holiday falls on a Monday, it is observed on Tuesday instead.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Tues-Fri' AND holiday_date.day_of_week == 'Monday' -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.following('Tuesday')
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific rescheduling of a holiday observance to a workday for a particular schedule.

name: Holiday Observance - 4x10 Tues-Fri, Weekend Holiday
rule_text: If  it  falls  on  Saturday  or  Sunday,  it  is observed on the preceding Friday or on the following Tuesday.
summary: For employees on a Tuesday-Friday 4x10 schedule, a holiday falling on a weekend is observed on either the preceding Friday or the following Tuesday.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Tues-Fri' AND holiday_date.day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> observed_holiday_date = holiday_date.preceding('Friday') OR holiday_date.following('Tuesday')
reasoning: This rule dictates the rescheduling of a non-worked day for a specific schedule, impacting the work week.

name: Holiday Observance - Employer Posting Requirement
rule_text: Employers  will  post  the  date  to  be  observed  no  later  than  seven  (7)  days  prior  to  the holiday.
summary: The employer must post a notice of which day a holiday will be observed at least seven days in advance.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: POST(observed_holiday_date) >= 7_days_before_holiday
reasoning: This is a procedural rule that is a prerequisite for applying holiday scheduling and pay rules correctly, thus it relates to the administration of worked time.

name: Holiday Observance - Change by Mutual Agreement
rule_text: In  order  to  harmonize  (Client,  multi-Employer)  observance  on  maintenance  sites  the Employer may make a request to the Local Lodge within fourteen (14) days of the holiday to establish another day to be observed other than those noted above.
summary: To align with other employers on a maintenance site, the Employer can request to change the observed holiday date by getting agreement from the Local Lodge at least 14 days before the holiday.
logical_representation: IF reason_for_change == 'harmonize_observance' -> PERMIT(REQUEST(change_observed_holiday_date) WITHIN 14_days_of_holiday)
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism to alter the work schedule and holiday observance, making it a rule about managing work time.

name: Waiting Time Pay, First Two Days
rule_text: When an employee, on initial hire or transfer to a project, is instructed by the Employer to report to a job location on a certain day but is not placed to work until a later date, they shall be  entitled  to  two  (2)  hours  pay... for  each  of  the  first  two  (2) regular working days they are kept waiting.
summary: If a new or transferred employee is told to report to a job but isn't put to work, they receive 2 hours of pay for each of the first two days they wait.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == NEW_HIRE OR employee_status == TRANSFER) AND waiting_day_count <= 2 -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific payment (2 hours pay) for non-worked time under specific conditions (waiting), which is a core concept of worked time calculation and entitlement.

name: Subsistence During Waiting Time
rule_text: When an employee, on initial hire or transfer to a project, is instructed by the Employer to report to a job location on a certain day but is not placed to work until a later date, they shall be  entitled  to... subsistence  if  applicable,  for  each  of  the  first  two  (2) regular working days they are kept waiting.
summary: If an employee qualifies for waiting time pay during their first two days of waiting, they also receive their subsistence allowance if they are otherwise eligible for it.
logical_representation: IF (employee_status == NEW_HIRE OR employee_status == TRANSFER) AND waiting_day_count <= 2 AND is_subsistence_applicable == TRUE -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: The primary topic is subsistence because it grants a subsistence allowance. It's secondarily related to worked time because the trigger for the allowance is a waiting time condition.

name: Waiting Time Pay, After Two Days
rule_text: Thereafter the waiting pay shall be increased to a full day of pay (i.e. eight (8) hours) for each regular working day.
summary: After waiting for two regular workdays without starting, an employee's waiting pay increases to a full 8-hour day for each subsequent day they wait.
logical_representation: IF waiting_day_count > 2 -> PAY(8_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines an increased payment (8 hours pay) for non-worked time based on the duration of the waiting period, directly impacting worked time calculations.

name: Waiting Time Duration
rule_text: This waiting pay shall continue until the employee is given work or released from the job in which latter case Article 15.02 (c) shall govern.
summary: Waiting time pay continues daily until the employee either starts work or is officially released from the job.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == WAITING -> ENTITLEMENT(waiting_pay) UNTIL (employee_status == WORKING OR employee_status == RELEASED)
reasoning: This rule establishes the end conditions for a pay entitlement related to non-worked time, which is a key parameter in labor time and pay management.

name: Reporting Pay, Inclement Weather (No Start)
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time...
summary: If an employee shows up for work but cannot start due to bad weather, they are paid for two hours.
logical_representation: IF reported_to_work == TRUE AND work_start_status == NOT_STARTED AND reason_for_no_work == INCLEMENT_WEATHER -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
reasoning: This rule guarantees a minimum payment for showing up to work, even if no work is performed. This is a form of 'show-up pay' or 'reporting time,' which falls under worked time rules.

name: Obligation to Remain on Job, Inclement Weather
rule_text: ...and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: When receiving reporting pay for bad weather, the employee must stay on the job site for those two hours unless a supervisor tells them they can leave.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_weather_reporting_pay == TRUE AND supervisor_instruction != 'LEAVE' -> OBLIGATION(REMAIN_ON_JOB_FOR_2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule imposes a condition (remaining on site) directly linked to the receipt of a pay entitlement (reporting time), making it an integral part of the worked time agreement.

name: Pay for Work Stopped by Weather
rule_text: When an employee has commenced work and is instructed to stop due to inclement weather, they shall be paid for the actual time worked.
summary: If an employee starts their shift and is later told to stop because of bad weather, they are paid for the exact amount of time they worked.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status == STARTED AND stop_work_reason == INCLEMENT_WEATHER -> PAY(hours_actually_worked)
reasoning: This rule specifies how to calculate paid hours when a shift is cut short, which is a fundamental aspect of worked time calculation.

name: Minimum Pay Guarantee, Inclement Weather
rule_text: In no case shall an employee receive less than two (2) hours of pay.
summary: In any inclement weather scenario where an employee reports to work, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay for the day.
logical_representation: IF reported_to_work == TRUE AND reason_for_no_work == INCLEMENT_WEATHER -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for a workday, which is a core component of labor worked time rules.

name: Reporting Pay, Work Not Available
rule_text: When an employee reports  to  work  and  is  not  given  the  opportunity  to  work  because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day of work, they  shall  be  paid  two  (2)  hours  of  reporting  time...
summary: If an employee shows up for work and there is no work for them, and they weren't told not to come in the day before, they receive two hours of reporting pay.
logical_representation: IF reported_to_work == TRUE AND work_available == FALSE AND prior_day_notification == FALSE -> PAY(2_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule specifies a payment for 'show-up' or 'reporting' time when work is unexpectedly unavailable, a standard element of worked time and payroll rules.

name: Permission to Leave, Work Not Available
rule_text: ...and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: An employee who receives reporting pay because no work is available is allowed to leave the job site right away.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_no_work_reporting_pay == TRUE -> ENTITLEMENT(LEAVE_IMMEDIATELY)
reasoning: This rule is a condition tied directly to a reporting pay scenario, defining the employee's time obligation (or lack thereof), which is part of worked time management.

name: Pay for Work Started and Stopped
rule_text: When an employee has started to work on their regular shift and is instructed to stop, they shall be paid for the actual time worked.
summary: If an employee starts their shift and is then told by the employer to stop working, they will be paid for the hours they actually worked.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status == STARTED AND employer_instruction == 'STOP_WORK' -> PAY(hours_actually_worked)
reasoning: This rule dictates how to calculate pay for a partially completed shift, a fundamental rule for determining hours worked and paid.

name: Minimum Pay When Sent Home
rule_text: In no case shall the employee receive less than two (2) hours of pay.
summary: If an employee starts work and is sent home by the employer, they are guaranteed to receive at least two hours of pay for that day.
logical_representation: IF work_start_status == STARTED AND employer_instruction == 'STOP_WORK' -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
reasoning: This rule sets a minimum pay guarantee for employees who start their shift, a core concept in worked time rules that ensures a baseline compensation for coming to work.

name: Pay When Employee Stops Work
rule_text: If an employee stops work for reasons of their own, and without the approval of the Employer, they shall be entitled to pay only for the hours actually worked in the day and minimum conditions shall not apply.
summary: If an employee decides to leave work on their own without the employer's permission, they are only paid for the hours they actually worked and lose any right to minimum reporting pay.
logical_representation: IF employee_action == 'STOPS_WORK_OWN_REASON' AND employer_approval == FALSE -> PAY(hours_actually_worked) AND FORFEIT(minimum_pay_guarantees)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition for forfeiting a pay guarantee, which is an exception rule within the worked time framework. It specifies how pay is calculated under special circumstances.

name: Employer's Right to Stop Work
rule_text: Subject to all of the above, it shall be the Employer's prerogative to decide whenever work shall be stopped during the day for any reason.
summary: The employer has the right to stop work at any time during the day for any reason, provided they follow the other rules about pay.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | Employer has right to stop work at any time, subject to other pay rules.
reasoning: This is a management rights clause that directly impacts work schedules and hours, setting the overarching condition under which worked time can be curtailed by the employer.

name: Subsistence Entitlement for Reporting/Waiting Time
rule_text: An employee who is affected by the Conditions set out above shall be entitled to subsistence in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement.
summary: If an employee qualifies for any of the reporting or waiting time conditions, they are also entitled to receive their subsistence allowance as per the agreement's terms.
logical_representation: IF is_eligible_for_reporting_or_waiting_time == TRUE -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule explicitly grants a subsistence allowance based on waiting/reporting time eligibility, making subsistence its primary topic.

name: Shift Premium on Reporting/Waiting Time
rule_text: When an employee qualifies for reporting or waiting time, such time shall include the regular shift premium when applicable.
summary: If an employee is eligible for reporting or waiting time pay, that pay must also include any shift premium they would have normally received.
logical_representation: IF is_eligible_for_reporting_or_waiting_time == TRUE AND is_shift_premium_applicable == TRUE -> PAY(reporting_or_waiting_hours + PREMIUM(shift))
reasoning: This rule modifies the calculation of a pay entitlement (reporting/waiting time) by adding a premium. This directly relates to how labor time is costed and paid, placing it under worked time.

name: Reporting Pay Exemption with 8-Hour Notice
rule_text: When an employee is notified eight (8) hours prior to the commencement of the scheduled starting time not to report for work, then such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: An employee is not entitled to reporting pay if the employer tells them not to come to work at least 8 hours before their shift is scheduled to start.
logical_representation: IF notification_time_prior_to_start_hours >= 8 -> FORFEIT(reporting_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule creates a specific condition under which a worked time entitlement (reporting pay) is forfeited, making it an exception rule within the worked time category.

name: Reporting Pay Exemption on Camp Jobs
rule_text: On camp jobs, the notice time may be reduced to one (1) hour prior to starting time.
summary: For employees on camp jobs, the notice period to cancel a shift without paying reporting time is reduced from 8 hours to just 1 hour before the start of the shift.
logical_representation: IF job_type == CAMP AND notification_time_prior_to_start_hours >= 1 -> FORFEIT(reporting_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule modifies the conditions for forfeiting a worked time entitlement (reporting pay) based on job location, which is a common variant in worked time rules.

name: Layoff Option after Frequent Cancellations
