rule_text: If this occurs more than twice in any one week, Monday through Friday, then the employee shall, at their option, be entitled to a layoff...
summary: If an employee's shift is cancelled with proper notice more than twice in a single work week (Mon-Fri), the employee has the option to accept a layoff.
logical_representation: IF cancellation_with_notice_count_in_week > 2 -> ENTITLEMENT(EMPLOYEE_OPTION_FOR_LAYOFF)
reasoning: This rule provides an employment status option based on the frequency of work unavailability, which directly affects an employee's hours and continuity of work. It is a condition related to the scheduling and guarantee of work time.

name: Layoff Option Exemption for Christmas Break
rule_text: ...however, this does not pertain to the normal Christmas break (i.e. two (2) weeks).
summary: The option to take a layoff after frequent shift cancellations does not apply during the normal two-week Christmas break.
logical_representation: IF time_period == NORMAL_CHRISTMAS_BREAK -> FORFEIT(EMPLOYEE_OPTION_FOR_LAYOFF)
reasoning: This rule specifies a calendar-based exception to a worked time provision, defining a period where the layoff option is not available.

name: No Reporting Pay during Strikes
rule_text: When an employee is unable to report for work due to a strike or work stoppage on the project where they are employed, such employee will not be entitled to any reporting time.
summary: If an employee cannot get to work because of a strike or work stoppage at their project, they are not eligible for reporting pay.
logical_representation: IF reason_for_inability_to_report == STRIKE_OR_WORK_STOPPAGE -> FORFEIT(reporting_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific circumstance (strike) that nullifies the entitlement to reporting pay, making it an exception clause within worked time rules.

name: Pay for Workplace Accident (WCA)
rule_text: If an employee meets with an accident during working hours and available medical advice or proper medical considerations deem it unsafe for them to continue work, they shall be paid those amounts as compensation as prescribed in the Workers' Compensation Act...
summary: If an employee is injured at work and cannot continue, they will be paid compensation according to the Workers' Compensation Act.
logical_representation: IF event_type == WORKPLACE_ACCIDENT AND medical_assessment == UNSAFE_TO_CONTINUE -> PAY(WCA_PRESCRIBED_AMOUNT)
reasoning: This rule dictates the source and type of payment an employee receives when unable to work due to injury. While related to WCA, it's fundamentally a rule about pay in lieu of worked hours.

name: Daily Allowances After Workplace Accident
rule_text: ...and shall also receive any other applicable daily allowances until such time that the employee is no longer in Employer's care.
summary: An employee injured at work will continue to receive any applicable daily allowances (like subsistence) until they are no longer considered to be in the employer's care.
logical_representation: IF is_in_employer_care_post_accident == TRUE -> ALLOWANCE(applicable_daily_allowances)
reasoning: This rule's primary focus is on the continuation of 'daily allowances,' which typically refers to subsistence, making it a subsistence rule triggered by a workplace incident.

name: Pay for Remainder of Day (Non-Lost Time Accident)
rule_text: If it is not a lost time accident covered by Workers' Compensation, they shall also be paid for the remaining unworked normal daily hours for that day (e.g. eight (8) hours, or in case of a compressed work day ten (10) hours) at the applicable rate.
summary: If an employee has a minor workplace accident that doesn't result in lost time under Workers' Compensation, they will be paid for the rest of their scheduled shift for that day.
logical_representation: IF accident_type == NOT_LOST_TIME_ACCIDENT -> PAY(remaining_hours_in_shift)
reasoning: This rule guarantees payment for unworked hours in a shift due to a specific event (non-lost time accident). This is a pay guarantee that falls squarely under worked time rules.

name: Camp Room Move During Work Hours
rule_text: Should an employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the Clients' designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, they are to do it during work hours and will be paid at appropriate rates...
summary: If an employee in a camp is asked to move rooms, they should do so during their paid work hours.
logical_representation: IF is_in_camp == TRUE AND is_requested_to_move == TRUE AND move_time == DURING_WORK_HOURS -> PAY(time_spent_moving)
reasoning: This rule defines an activity (moving rooms) as payable work time, which directly impacts how hours are categorized and paid, making it a worked time rule.

name: Camp Room Move Outside Work Hours
rule_text: ...or the employee shall be paid two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rate to carry out the move, if done outside work hours.
summary: If an employee in a camp is asked to move rooms and does it outside of their work hours, they will be paid two hours at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF is_in_camp == TRUE AND is_requested_to_move == TRUE AND move_time == OUTSIDE_WORK_HOURS -> PAY(2_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific payment for an activity performed outside of regular hours, functioning as a special allowance or minimum payment, which is a worked time concept.

name: Exemption for Camp Room Move Pay
rule_text: This provision will not apply where employees are required to pack their room at the end of a work cycle or to facilitate a move that will occur during the employees furlough.
summary: Employees are not paid for moving rooms if the move is part of packing up at the end of a work cycle or happens during their time off (furlough).
logical_representation: IF reason_for_move == END_OF_CYCLE OR reason_for_move == DURING_FURLOUGH -> FORFEIT(room_move_pay)
reasoning: This rule specifies conditions under which a pay entitlement is forfeited, making it an exception rule that is integral to the administration of worked time and pay.

name: Transportation for Camp Move
rule_text: Transportation will be supplied if required.
summary: If transportation is needed for an employee to move to a new room or camp, the employer will provide it.
logical_representation: IF is_transportation_required_for_move == TRUE -> PROVIDE(transportation)
reasoning: This rule concerns the provision of a non-monetary benefit related to accommodation and living arrangements (camp move), which aligns best with the scope of subsistence and travel allowances.

name: Employer Provided Daily Transport
rule_text: On those projects that are located between forty-five (45) radius kilometers to one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from Edmonton and/or Calgary City Hall(s) or other Hiring Hall locations, the Employer shall supply suitable transportation to and from the project and mutually agreed to pick-up points.
summary: For projects located between 45 and 120 radius kilometers from a hiring hall, the employer is obligated to provide transportation for employees to and from the worksite via agreed-upon pickup points.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_hiring_hall >= 45km AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall <= 120km -> PROVIDE(transportation)
reasoning: This rule outlines a non-monetary entitlement (transportation) based on project distance, which is a core component of remote work compensation and subsistence policies.

name: Daily Travel Allowance in Lieu of Transport
rule_text: Alternatively, the Employer shall pay to each employee a transportation cost at the rate of sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone to the project and return.
summary: If the employer does not provide transportation for projects 45-120 km away, they must pay a daily travel allowance of $0.69 per road kilometer. This is calculated for the distance from the 45 km free zone boundary to the project, and back.
logical_representation: IF transportation_not_provided AND project_distance_from_hiring_hall >= 45km -> PAY(0.69 * (road_kilometers_from_free_zone * 2)) PER day_worked_or_reported
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary allowance for daily travel to a remote work site, which is a form of subsistence compensation.

name: Subsistence Eligibility Distance Threshold
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid or camp provided on projects which are more than one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: Employees become eligible for either a subsistence allowance or camp accommodations when the project is located more than 120 radius kilometers from a designated hiring hall.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_hiring_hall > 120km -> ALLOWANCE(subsistence) OR PROVIDE(camp)
reasoning: This is the primary eligibility rule for subsistence, establishing the distance threshold that triggers the entitlement.

name: Standard Subsistence Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The default subsistence payment is $150.00 for each day an employee works or reports for work, unless a location-specific rate applies.
logical_representation: IF subsistence_eligible AND location NOT IN special_rate_areas -> ALLOWANCE($150) PER day_worked_or_reported
reasoning: This rule establishes the standard monetary value of the daily subsistence allowance entitlement.

name: Location-Specific Subsistence Rates
summary: For specific listed locations, a different daily subsistence rate applies, overriding the standard $150.00 rate. For example, Fort McMurray is $200.00 and Grande Prairie is $205.00 per day worked.
logical_representation: IF subsistence_eligible AND project_location IN special_rate_areas -> ALLOWANCE(location_specific_rate) PER day_worked_or_reported
reasoning: This rule provides a schedule of specific monetary rates for subsistence based on geographic location, which is a direct entitlement.

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Projects
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 radius kilometers or more from the hiring hall, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just on days worked.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_hiring_hall >= 475km -> ALLOWANCE(subsistence) PER 7_days_a_week
reasoning: This rule modifies the payment frequency and continuity of the subsistence allowance based on a significant distance threshold, impacting the total entitlement.

name: Subsistence Forfeiture Waiver
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: If an employee is absent, they may still receive their subsistence allowance if the employer deems the reason for the absence to be acceptable.
logical_representation: IF employee_is_absent AND reason_is_acceptable_to_employer -> WAIVE(FORFEIT(subsistence))
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition under which the forfeiture of the subsistence entitlement can be overridden, thus affecting pay.

name: Additional Subsistence Day for Travel
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: Non-local employees on projects over 200 road kilometers away can receive one extra day of subsistence pay to cover travel time, either for the day before they start work or the day after they finish.
logical_representation: IF project_road_distance_from_hiring_hall > 200km AND is_local_resident == false -> ALLOWANCE(subsistence * 1_day) ON start_date-1 OR end_date+1
reasoning: This rule defines an additional monetary allowance under specific conditions related to travel distance and residency status.

name: Proof for Additional Subsistence Day
rule_text: This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (e.g., receipt or registration verification).
summary: To receive the additional day of subsistence for travel, the employee must provide verifiable proof, such as a receipt, that they used accommodation on that day.
logical_representation: IF claiming_additional_subsistence_day -> REQUIRE(proof_of_accommodation)
reasoning: This rule establishes a prerequisite (providing proof) for receiving a specific subsistence entitlement, making it a conditional rule.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance
rule_text:
Effective June 1, 2025 (second Sunday following ratification), there is a scheduled increase to initial and terminal travel which will be paid as follows from the above:

| One Hundred and Twenty (120) - Two Hundred (200) Radius Kilometers | $ | One Hundred and Sixteen ($116.00) each way, |
|---|---|---|
| Two Hundred (200) - Three Hundred (300) Radius Kilometers | $ | One Hundred and Sixty-Six ($166.00) each way, |
| Three Hundred (300) - Three Hundred and Seventy-Five (375) Radius Kilometers | $ | Two Hundred ($200.00) each way, |
| Three Hundred and Seventy-Five (375) - Four Hundred and Seventy-Five (475) Radius Kilometers | $ | Two Hundred and Ninety-Seven ($297.00) each way, |
summary: Effective June 1, 2025, employees receive a fixed travel payment for their initial trip to the job and terminal trip from the job. The amount is based on the project's distance from the hiring hall, ranging from $116 to $297 each way.
logical_representation: IF effective_date >= 2025-06-01 -> PAY(initial_and_terminal_travel_allowance) BASED ON distance_tiers
reasoning: This rule details a schedule of monetary allowances for travel to and from a remote work site, which is a key component of subsistence policies.

name: Airfare in Lieu of Travel Allowance
rule_text: or actual airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: As an alternative to the fixed distance-based travel payment, an employee can be reimbursed for the actual cost of their airfare if they provide proof to the employer.
logical_representation: IF proof_of_air_transport_provided -> PAY(actual_airfare) INSTEAD OF standard_travel_allowance
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative method for calculating a travel-related monetary entitlement, directly affecting employee compensation.

name: Ft. McMurray Initial and Terminal Travel
rule_text: Initial and Terminal travel for any project which falls within one- hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall will be two hundred and ninety-seven dollars ($297.00).
summary: For any project located within a 100 km radius of Ft. McMurray city hall, the initial and terminal travel payment is a flat rate of $297.00.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_ft_mcmurray <= 100km -> PAY($297) FOR initial_and_terminal_travel
reasoning: This rule defines a specific monetary travel allowance for a particular geographic area, which overrides the standard distance-based travel rules.

name: Travel Allowance Invalidation by Client Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation for employees to and from the work site, the employee is not entitled to any initial or terminal travel allowance payments.
logical_representation: IF client_provides_transportation -> FORFEIT(initial_and_terminal_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition under which a travel-related monetary entitlement is completely voided.

name: Travel Allowance for Very Remote Projects
rule_text: On jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial and terminal travel amounts will be mutually agreed between the Local Lodge and the Employer to a maximum of four hundred and fifty-five dollars ($455.00) each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: For projects over 475 km away, the travel allowance is determined by mutual agreement between the union and the employer, capped at $455.00 each way. Alternatively, the employee can be reimbursed for actual airfare with proof.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_hiring_hall > 475km -> PAY(mutually_agreed_amount) WITH MAX($455) EACH_WAY OR PAY(actual_airfare)
reasoning: This rule defines a unique calculation method and cap for a travel allowance based on a significant distance threshold.

name: Initial Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay- off.
summary: The initial travel allowance is paid out to the employee after they have worked for 15 calendar days or at the time of lay-off, whichever occurs first.
logical_representation: PAY(initial_travel_allowance) AT MIN(15_calendar_days_on_job, lay_off_date)
reasoning: This rule governs the timing and conditions for the payout of a travel-related entitlement, which is a key part of subsistence administration.

name: Terminal Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The terminal (return) travel allowance is paid to the employee at the time they are laid off from the job.
logical_representation: PAY(terminal_travel_allowance) AT lay_off_date
reasoning: This rule governs the timing of the payout for a travel-related entitlement.

name: Travel Allowance Forfeiture on Resignation or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee resigns or is terminated for cause before their travel allowance has been paid, they forfeit their right to any outstanding travel payments.
logical_representation: IF reason_for_separation == 'quit' OR reason_for_separation == 'terminated_for_cause' -> FORFEIT(outstanding_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule defines conditions related to employment separation that lead to the forfeiture of a travel allowance entitlement.

name: Subsistence Eligibility Verification
rule_text:
To qualify for the subsistence allowance under Article 16.01, the member, will supply two (2) of the following documents as verification of their name and current address. It is understood that the Employer will ensure any copies of such documents will be handled in accordance with PIPA regulations.

- Any government issued identification
- Utility Bill
- Bank Statement
- Vehicle Registration
- Housing Rental Agreement
- Mortgage Documentation

- Land Title
- Credit Card Statement
- Income Tax Assessment
- Property Tax Assessment
- Employment Insurance
summary: To qualify for subsistence, an employee must provide two forms of documentation from an approved list to verify their name and current address. Examples include government ID, a utility bill, or a bank statement.
logical_representation: IF is_claiming_subsistence -> REQUIRE(2_documents_from_approved_list) FOR address_verification
reasoning: This rule establishes the documentation requirements an employee must meet to qualify for the subsistence entitlement, making it a critical condition.

name: Local Resident Ineligibility for Subsistence
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel
summary: Employees who live in the local area of a project that qualifies for subsistence are not eligible to receive the accommodation allowance or initial/terminal travel payments.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true AND is_subsistence_project == true -> INELIGIBLE(accommodation_allowance) AND INELIGIBLE(initial_terminal_travel)
reasoning: This rule defines a condition (being a local resident) that makes an employee ineligible for specific subsistence and travel entitlements, acting as an exclusion clause.

name: Local Resident Eligibility for Daily Travel
rule_text: but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 16.01 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: Even though local residents on a subsistence project don't get the accommodation allowance, they can still receive daily travel payments if their home is outside a 45 km radius free zone around the project.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true AND residence_distance_from_project > 45km -> ELIGIBLE(daily_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule establishes eligibility for a daily travel allowance for a specific subset of employees (local residents) based on their distance from the worksite.

name: Travel for Non-Locals on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid sixty-nine cents ($0.69) per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the free zone to the temporary domicile and return.
summary: On a subsistence project, employees whose temporary housing is outside a 45 km radius of the job site must be provided with transportation or be paid a travel allowance of $0.69 per kilometer from the edge of the free zone to their temporary lodging and back.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_project == true AND temporary_domicile_distance_from_project > 45km -> PROVIDE(transportation) OR PAY(0.69 * (road_km_from_free_zone_to_domicile * 2)) PER day_worked
reasoning: This rule provides a daily travel entitlement (either transportation or a monetary payment) for non-local employees on a subsistence job, based on the location of their temporary residence.

name: Ft. McMurray Transport for Subsistence Employees
rule_text: In Ft. McMurray, subsistence employees will be provided transportation to and from the job site as per current arrangements under the Agreement.
summary: For projects in the Ft. McMurray area, employees who are receiving subsistence must be provided with transportation to and from the job site according to the currently established arrangements.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Ft. McMurray' AND is_receiving_subsistence == true -> PROVIDE(transportation)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific, non-monetary transportation entitlement for a particular geographic area, overriding other daily travel rules for those employees.

name: Review of Travel and Subsistence Rates
rule_text:
The transportation cost will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.

These amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.

Initial and terminal travel amounts will be reviewed by the Boilermaker/BCA Liaison Committee should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: All travel and subsistence monetary rates (daily travel cost, daily subsistence amounts, and initial/terminal travel) are subject to review by a joint committee if rates in other key reference agreements change.
logical_representation: IF reference_agreement_rates_change -> ACTION(review_all_travel_and_subsistence_rates)
reasoning: This is a procedural rule governing how all subsistence-related rates are maintained and updated over time. Combining the three identical clauses into one rule is efficient.

name: Pay Frequency and Timing
rule_text: Employees shall be paid weekly during working hours, not later than Thursday.
summary: Employees must be paid their wages every week, no later than Thursday, during their regular working hours.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(pay_frequency == WEEKLY) AND CONSTRAINT(pay_day_of_week <= THURSDAY)
reasoning: This rule governs the frequency and timing of payment for labor, which is a core administrative aspect of worked time. Among the given choices, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most appropriate category for rules about pay administration.

name: Pay Holdback Limit
rule_text: In no case shall more than five (5) regular working days be held back in any one payroll period.
summary: The employer cannot withhold more than five regular working days' worth of pay from any single paycheck.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(payroll_holdback_days <= 5)
reasoning: This rule sets a limit on the amount of time an employer can hold back pay. It's an administrative rule directly related to the compensation for worked time, making LABOR_WORKED_TIME the best fit.

name: Final Pay Obligation on Termination
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or discharged from the service of the Employer shall receive  their  wages  and  all  monies  owing  and  their  Employment  Insurance  Contribution Certificate.
summary: When an employee is laid off or fired, they must receive all wages and money owed to them, along with their Employment Insurance documents.
logical_representation: IF employment_status == LAID_OFF OR employment_status == DISCHARGED -> PAY(final_wages) AND PROVIDE(employment_insurance_certificate)
reasoning: This rule concerns the final payment for all worked time and other entitlements upon termination. It's a fundamental aspect of pay administration, best categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME from the available options.

name: Termination Slip Requirements
rule_text: the employee shall receive an Employer termination slip which shall show either their net pay and deductions, or the basic factors from which their pay will be calculated including: total pay hours, travel allowance and transportation allowances, subsistence, etc.
summary: Upon termination, an employee must be given a slip detailing either their final net pay and deductions or the components used to calculate it, such as hours, travel pay, and subsistence.
logical_representation: IF employment_status == TERMINATED -> PROVIDE(termination_slip)
reasoning: This rule dictates the information that must be provided regarding the calculation of final pay. Since it relates directly to the components of compensation for labor, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most suitable topic.

name: Payment Method
rule_text: Pay shall be by direct deposit.
summary: All payments to employees must be made via direct deposit.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(payment_method == DIRECT_DEPOSIT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the method of payment for labor. As a core administrative rule for compensation, it falls under the umbrella of LABOR_WORKED_TIME from the provided options.

name: Final Pay Deadline on Termination
rule_text: and the Employer shall direct deposit monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment  by the next regular scheduled pay period for the pay period in question, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday, and Recognized Holidays.
summary: For laid off or discharged employees, the employer must issue final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment by the next scheduled payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employment_status == LAID_OFF OR employment_status == DISCHARGED -> PAY(final_wages_by_next_pay_period) AND PROVIDE(ROE_by_next_pay_period)
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final payment upon termination. It's a critical administrative rule related to compensation for worked time, fitting best under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Late Final Pay on Termination
rule_text: Should the Employer fail to comply with this provision (excluding the reference to the Record of Employment), the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates for each day they are kept waiting exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays up to a maximum of forty (40) hours of pay.
summary: If the employer is late with the final payment for a laid off or discharged employee, the employee is entitled to a penalty of 8 hours of straight-time pay for each business day of delay, up to a maximum of 40 hours.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_is_late AND (employment_status == LAID_OFF OR employment_status == DISCHARGED) -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * days_late, MAX=40_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty, calculated in hours of pay, for failing to adhere to payment deadlines. Since the penalty is a form of compensation related to the administration of worked time, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most appropriate classification.

name: Final Pay Deadline on Quitting
rule_text: When  an  employee  quits  of  their  own  volition,  the  Employer  shall  direct  deposit  all monies owing and file electronically the Record of Employment by the next regular scheduled pay  period  for  the  pay  period  in  question,  exclusive  of  Saturday,  Sunday  and  Recognized Holidays.
summary: When an employee quits, the employer must issue their final pay and electronically file the Record of Employment by the next scheduled payday for that pay period, excluding weekends and holidays.
logical_representation: IF employment_status == QUIT -> PAY(final_wages_by_next_pay_period) AND PROVIDE(ROE_by_next_pay_period)
reasoning: This rule sets the deadline for final payment when an employee resigns. It's an administrative rule for worked time compensation, fitting best under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Late Final Pay on Quitting
rule_text: If the Employer fails to comply with this requirement within five (5) working days after the specified pay day, the employee shall receive an additional sum equivalent to eight (8) hours of pay at straight time rates.
summary: If an employer fails to provide final pay to a quitting employee within five business days after the scheduled payday, the employee receives a one-time penalty of 8 hours of straight-time pay.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_is_late_by_days > 5 AND employment_status == QUIT -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty, calculated in hours of pay, for failing to meet payment deadlines for an employee who has quit. As a form of compensation related to pay administration, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the correct topic.

name: Employee Obligation for Pay Shortage
rule_text: If on an employee's weekly paycheck, they are shorted pay, the employee is required to notify  the  Employer  immediately  in  writing.
summary: If an employee's paycheck is short, they must immediately notify the employer in writing.
logical_representation: IF pay_is_short -> OBLIGATION(employee_notify_employer_in_writing)
reasoning: This rule outlines the employee's responsibility in the process of correcting pay errors. This process is integral to the administration of compensation for worked time, thus falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Employer Obligation for Pay Shortage
rule_text: The  Employer  shall  provide  an  adjustment  on  a subsequent  pay  date  but  not  later  than  ten  (10)  days  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays,  and Recognized Holidays after receiving the notification of the shortage in writing.
summary: After being notified in writing of a pay shortage, the employer must correct the error and pay the employee the missing amount within 10 business days.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_notification_received -> PAY(shortage_adjustment, MAX_DAYS=10)
reasoning: This rule dictates the employer's responsibility and timeline for correcting pay errors. This is a core function of pay administration for worked time, making LABOR_WORKED_TIME the appropriate category.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Employer will pay one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day the employee is kept waiting from the date the notification of shortage was received in writing by the Employer to a maximum of seven hundred dollars ($700.00).
summary: If the employer fails to correct a pay shortage within 10 business days of being notified, they must pay a penalty of $100 per day (starting from the original notification date) up to a maximum of $700.
logical_representation: IF pay_adjustment_is_late_by_days > 10 -> PAY($100 * days_since_notification, MAX=$700)
reasoning: This rule establishes a monetary penalty for failing to correct pay errors in a timely manner. As this penalty is directly linked to the administration of employee compensation, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most fitting topic.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of continuous service with one (1) Employer,  the  employee  will  be  entitled  to  bereavement  pay  benefits  of  eight  (8)  hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a results  of  the  employee's  attendance  at  a  funeral  or  memorial  service  upon  the  dea th  of  an employee's  Spouse,  Child,  Parent,  Parent -in-Law,  Grandparent  or  Sibling.  Bereavement  Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: An employee with over three years of continuous service is entitled to up to three days of bereavement pay for lost work while attending a funeral for an immediate family member. Pay is for 8 hours per day at the straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF continuous_service_years > 3 AND reason_for_absence == BEREAVEMENT(qualifying_relative) -> PAY(8_HOURS_ST * days_absent, MAX_DAYS=3)
reasoning: This rule grants an entitlement to paid time off, calculated in hours at a specific rate. While it is for time not worked, it is a form of compensation directly tied to the employee's work schedule and pay rate, making LABOR_WORKED_TIME the most appropriate category from the options provided.

name: Bereavement Eligibility Change (2026)
rule_text: January 1, 2026, continuous employment transitions to thirty (30) months.
summary: Starting January 1, 2026, the service requirement for bereavement pay will be reduced to 30 months of continuous employment.
logical_representation: IF effective_date >= 2026-01-01 -> SET(bereavement_eligibility_service_months = 30)
reasoning: This rule modifies the eligibility criteria for a paid time off benefit. Since it directly impacts an entitlement calculated based on hours and pay rates, it falls under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category.

name: Bereavement Eligibility Change (2027)
rule_text: January 1, 2027, continuous employment transitions to twenty-four (24) months.
summary: Starting January 1, 2027, the service requirement for bereavement pay will be further reduced to 24 months of continuous employment.
logical_representation: IF effective_date >= 2027-01-01 -> SET(bereavement_eligibility_service_months = 24)
reasoning: This rule further modifies the eligibility criteria for a paid time off benefit. As it pertains to an entitlement based on hours and pay rates, LABOR_WORKED_TIME is the most suitable classification.

name: Reporting Pay, Inclement Weather
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and cannot work because of inclement weather they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and the employee must remain on the job for the two (2) hour period, unless otherwise instructed by the Employer's supervisor.
summary: If an employee shows up for work but cannot start due to bad weather, they receive 2 hours of pay. They must stay on site for those 2 hours unless told otherwise by a supervisor.
logical_representation: IF work_cannot_start == TRUE AND reason == 'INCLEMENT_WEATHER' -> PAY(2_HOURS) AND IF instructed_to_leave_by_supervisor == FALSE -> employee_must_remain_on_job_for(2_hours)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment (reporting time) for employees who report to work but are unable to start due to a specific condition (weather), which is a form of guaranteed hours/pay, falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Pay for Partial Shift, Inclement Weather
rule_text: When an employee has commenced work and is instructed to stop due to inclement weather, they shall be paid for the actual time worked.
summary: If a work shift starts but is later stopped by the employer due to bad weather, the employee is paid for the hours they actually worked.
logical_representation: IF work_commenced == TRUE AND work_stopped_by_employer == TRUE AND reason == 'INCLEMENT_WEATHER' -> PAY(actual_hours_worked)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule defines how to calculate pay for an incomplete shift under specific circumstances, which is a core component of how worked time is compensated. It directly relates to the calculation of payable hours.

name: Minimum Pay Guarantee, Inclement Weather
rule_text: In no case shall an employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: On a day where work is affected by bad weather (either not starting or stopping early), an employee will always receive a minimum of 2 hours of pay.
logical_representation: IF day_impacted_by_inclement_weather == TRUE -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule sets a minimum payment floor, or a guaranteed minimum number of hours to be paid, which is a fundamental aspect of worked time rules and pay calculation. It applies to the inclement weather section.

name: Reporting Pay, Work Unavailable
rule_text: When an employee reports to work and is not given the opportunity to work because none is available or was not advised before the completion of the previous day's work, they shall be paid two (2) hours reporting time and allowed to leave the job immediately.
summary: If an employee shows up for work and there is no work for them, and they weren't told not to come in the day before, they get 2 hours of pay and can leave right away.
logical_representation: IF work_is_unavailable == TRUE AND employee_not_notified_previously == TRUE -> PAY(2_HOURS) AND employee_can_leave_immediately
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This is a 'show-up time' rule. It guarantees a minimum payment when an employee reports for duty as scheduled but is sent home, which is a rule governing compensation for time, thus falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Pay for Partial Shift, Employer Stop
rule_text: When an employee has started to work on their regular shift and is instructed to stop, they shall be paid for the actual time worked.
summary: If an employee starts their shift and is later told to stop working by a supervisor for any reason, they will be paid for the hours they actually worked.
logical_representation: IF work_commenced == TRUE AND work_stopped_by_employer == TRUE -> PAY(actual_hours_worked)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule dictates how payment is calculated for an incomplete shift stopped by the employer. It is a direct rule about the calculation of payable hours and falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Minimum Pay Guarantee, Started Shift
rule_text: In no case shall the employee receive less than two (2) hours pay.
summary: If a shift has started and is then stopped by the employer for any reason, the employee is guaranteed to receive at least 2 hours of pay for that day.
logical_representation: IF work_commenced == TRUE AND work_stopped_by_employer == TRUE -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule provides a minimum pay guarantee for any shift that has begun. Setting a minimum floor for compensation is a core function of rules categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME. It applies to the 'Work Not Available' section.

name: Forfeiture of Minimums, Employee Stop
rule_text: If an employee stops work for reasons of their own, and without the approval of the Employer, they shall be entitled to pay only for the hours actually worked in the day and minimum conditions shall not apply.
summary: If an employee decides to stop working on their own without the employer's permission, they forfeit any minimum pay guarantees (like reporting pay) and are only paid for the hours they actually worked.
logical_representation: IF work_stopped_by_employee == TRUE AND employer_approval_for_stop == FALSE -> PAY(actual_hours_worked) AND FORFEIT(minimum_pay_guarantees)
hierarchy: Boilermaker Contractors' Association>International Brotherhood of Boilermakers>Tank Work Employers Letter
reasoning: This rule acts as an exception to the other minimum pay rules. It defines a scenario where guaranteed pay entitlements are forfeited, which is integral to the overall logic of worked time and compensation, thus fitting LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Date Requirement
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

1. Date
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the submitted receipt must clearly state the date.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.date)
reasoning: This rule specifies a mandatory piece of information (a date) required on a receipt for the reimbursement of a subsistence allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Establishment and Contact Name
rule_text: Name of Establishment and Name of Contact Person if appropriate (see examples below) ABC Motel -Company letterhead receipt -Name of Contact Person not required B & B or Relative (non-registered) -Name of Contact Person required
summary: For subsistence reimbursement, receipts must show the establishment's name. If staying at a non-registered place like a B&B or with a relative, the name of a contact person is also required.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.establishment_name) AND IF receipt.establishment_type == NON_REGISTERED -> REQUIRE(receipt.contact_person_name)
reasoning: This rule outlines specific information (establishment and contact person names) required on a receipt for subsistence reimbursement, making it a condition for the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Address and Phone Number
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

3. Complete Address and Phone Number of the Establishment
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must include the complete address and phone number of the establishment where the employee stayed.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.establishment_address) AND REQUIRE(receipt.establishment_phone)
reasoning: This rule specifies mandatory information (address and phone number) for a subsistence reimbursement receipt, making it a condition for the allowance.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Employee Name
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

4. Employee's Full Name
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must clearly state the employee's full name.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.employee_full_name)
reasoning: This rule specifies the employee's full name must be on the receipt, a necessary condition for processing a subsistence reimbursement claim.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Reason for Cost
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

5. Reason/Description of Cost (including dates)
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must provide a description of the cost and include the specific dates the cost was incurred for.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.cost_description) AND REQUIRE(receipt.service_dates)
reasoning: This rule dictates that a description and the dates of the cost must be on the receipt, making it a condition for subsistence reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Total Cost
rule_text:
The following information must appear on all receipts:

6. Total Cost
summary: To be reimbursed for subsistence, the receipt must state the total cost.
logical_representation: IF claim_type == SUBSISTENCE -> REQUIRE(receipt.total_cost)
reasoning: This rule requires the total cost to be present on the receipt, a key condition for calculating and processing subsistence reimbursement.

name: Subsistence Receipt, Incomplete Information
rule_text: A receipt without complete or required information will not be considered.
summary: A receipt that is missing any of the required information will be rejected, and the subsistence allowance will not be reimbursed.
logical_representation: IF receipt_is_complete == FALSE -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a direct consequence (forfeiture of reimbursement) for failing to meet the informational requirements for a subsistence receipt, linking it directly to the allowance.

name: Compressed Work Week, Normal Day
rule_text: The parties to this Agreement agree that the maximum of nine (9) hours shall constitute a normal days work beginning at 7:30 a.m. and ending at 5:00 p.m. (excluding a one-half hour (1/2) lunch break) may be utilized if restricted to Long Term Base Crew employees.
summary: For Long Term Base Crew employees on a Compressed Work Week, a normal workday is 9 hours, from 7:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., with a 30-minute unpaid lunch.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW -> SET(schedule_workday_hours, 9) AND SET(schedule_start_time, '07:30') AND SET(schedule_end_time, '17:00') AND SET(schedule_unpaid_lunch_minutes, 30)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard hours and schedule for a specific type of work arrangement, which is a core concept of labor worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week, Normal Week
rule_text: With the understanding that this work schedule is utilized to compensate the employees for hours lost during the twenty-six (26) yearly earned days off (EDO's), in keeping with the terms of the Maintenance Contract with Suncor, Edmonton Refinery, the maximum normal work week shall be forty-five (45) hours beginning Monday at 7:30 a.m. and ending Friday at 5:00 p.m.
summary: For employees on the Compressed Work Week, the normal work week is 45 hours, Monday to Friday, to make up for 26 annual Earned Days Off (EDOs).
logical_representation: IF work_schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> SET(schedule_workweek_hours, 45) AND SET(schedule_days, [MONDAY, TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY, THURSDAY, FRIDAY])
reasoning: This rule establishes the standard weekly hours and days for a specific schedule, which is fundamental to classifying worked time.

name: Earned Days Off (EDO) Allocation
rule_text: Of the twentysix (26) EDO's, eighteen (18) will be scheduled by Suncor and the remaining eight (8) will be designated as flex EDO's to be taken as mutually agreed between the employee and the supervisor.
summary: Employees receive 26 Earned Days Off (EDOs) per year. 18 are scheduled by the company (Suncor), and the remaining 8 are flexible days scheduled by mutual agreement.
logical_representation: PROVIDE(26_EDO) -> SET(company_scheduled_edos, 18) AND SET(employee_flex_edos, 8)
reasoning: This rule concerns scheduling and entitlement to paid days off, which are a component of how overall time and compensation are managed.

name: Long Term Crew Definition
rule_text: It is understood that when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew employee.
summary: An employee hired for a job expected to last more than six weeks is automatically classified as a Long Term Base Crew employee and placed on the Compressed Work Week schedule.
logical_representation: IF intended_employment_term_weeks > 6 -> SET(employee_type, LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW) AND SET(work_schedule_type, COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule defines the conditions for an employee's classification, which in turn dictates their schedule and pay rules, directly impacting labor worked time calculations.

name: Long Term Crew, Early Termination Adjustment
rule_text: Should an employee be terminated prior to working six (6) weeks, an adjustment shall be made in accordance with the terms of Clause b).
summary: If a Long Term Crew employee is terminated before completing six weeks, their pay will be adjusted according to the rules for short-term employees (Clause b), likely meaning they get overtime for their 9th hour worked each day.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW AND termination_status == TERMINATED AND employment_duration_weeks < 6 -> TRIGGER(PAY_ADJUSTMENT_PER_CLAUSE_B)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific pay calculation and adjustment upon termination, which is a key aspect of labor worked time and compensation.

name: Short Term Employee, 9th Hour Pay
rule_text: It is understood that when employees are hired with the intentions of short-term employment (defined as less than six (6) weeks from the date of hire) that they will be paid time and one-half (1 1/2) for the ninth (9th) hour.
summary: Employees hired for a short term (less than six weeks) are paid time and a half for the ninth hour worked in a day.
logical_representation: IF intended_employment_term_weeks < 6 AND daily_hours > 8 -> PAY(1.5x) FOR daily_hours BETWEEN 8 AND 9
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines an overtime condition (time and a half) for a specific hour of work for a specific class of employee, making it a clear labor worked time rule.

name: Short Term Employee, Conversion to Long Term
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms (except as outlined in item (e) below).
summary: If a short-term employee works longer than six weeks, they are re-classified as Long Term Crew and will be paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules from that point on.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == SHORT_TERM AND employment_duration_weeks > 6 -> SET(employee_type, LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW) AND APPLY(PAYMENT_TERMS_CWW)
reasoning: This rule governs the re-classification of an employee, which changes their pay and schedule rules, directly impacting how their worked time is categorized and compensated.

name: Overtime on Scheduled EDOs
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the scheduled eighteen (18) days off will be at time and one half (1 ½) for the first twelve (12) hours and double-time (2) paid thereafter.
summary: When working on one of the 18 company-scheduled Earned Days Off, employees receive time and a half for the first 12 hours and double time for any hours worked beyond 12.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == SCHEDULED_EDO -> PAY(1.5x) FOR hours <= 12 AND PAY(2.0x) FOR hours > 12
reasoning: This rule specifies overtime rates and thresholds for work on a specially designated day, which is a core function of categorizing labor worked time.

name: Overtime on Sundays and Statutory Holidays
rule_text: Double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: All hours worked on a Sunday or a Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == SUNDAY OR work_day_type == STAT_HOLIDAY -> PAY(2.0x) FOR ALL hours_worked
reasoning: This rule establishes a special pay rate (double time) for specific calendar days, a classic labor worked time rule.

name: Overtime on Short Notice Flex EDO Work
rule_text: If an employee is asked to work their scheduled flex day off without being given forty- eight (48) hours notice, then the employee will be paid overtime at time and one half (1 ½) for up to twelve (12) hours except on Sundays and Statutory Holidays where double-time (2) will be paid for all hours worked.
summary: If asked to work on a scheduled flex EDO with less than 48 hours' notice, an employee gets time and a half for the first 12 hours. However, if that day is a Sunday or Statutory Holiday, all hours are paid at double time instead.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == FLEX_EDO AND notice_period_hours < 48 AND work_day_type != SUNDAY AND work_day_type != STAT_HOLIDAY -> PAY(1.5x) FOR hours <= 12
reasoning: This rule defines overtime conditions based on the type of day, the amount of notice given, and hour thresholds, all of which are key elements of labor worked time classification.

name: Flex EDO Work as Last Resort
rule_text: Once scheduled, requests for employees to work on flex days will only be made a last resort, after all reasonable options are made to find alternate arrangements.
summary: The company should only ask employees to work on their scheduled flex days as a last resort, after trying all other options.
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == FLEX_EDO -> CONSTRAINT(REQUEST_WORK only as LAST_RESORT)
reasoning: This rule places a procedural condition on scheduling work, which affects how and when time is worked, falling under the broader category of labor worked time.

name: Termination Pay Adjustment without Recent EDO
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If a long-term employee is terminated and has not taken a flex EDO in the past six weeks, their final pay is adjusted. Any regular hours they worked over 240 in that six-week period will be recalculated and paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW AND termination_status == TERMINATED AND weeks_since_last_flex_edo >= 6 AND regular_hours_in_last_6_weeks > 240 -> PAY(applicable_ot_rate) FOR regular_hours_in_last_6_weeks - 240
reasoning: This rule describes a specific, conditional calculation for re-classifying straight time hours as overtime upon termination, making it a definitive labor worked time rule.

name: Flex EDO Request Notice
rule_text: The employee will provide a minimum of seven (7) days notice when requesting flex. EDO's.
summary: Employees must give at least seven days' notice when they want to schedule one of their flexible Earned Days Off (EDOs).
logical_representation: IF requesting_flex_edo -> CONSTRAINT(flex_edo_request_notice_days >= 7)
reasoning: This is a procedural rule for scheduling time off, which is an integral part of managing and categorizing an employee's time.

name: Flex EDO Request Notice Exception
rule_text: Special circumstances will be considered by the supervisor wherein a shorter notice period may be allowed.
summary: A supervisor may allow an employee to take a flex EDO with less than seven days' notice in special circumstances.
logical_representation: IF requesting_flex_edo AND special_circumstances == TRUE -> OVERRIDE(flex_edo_request_notice_days >= 7)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to a scheduling requirement, which pertains to the administration of worked and non-worked time.

name: No Pay for Untaken Flex EDOs
rule_text: overtime payment will not be made for flex days not taken by the employee with the exception of those circumstances outlined in items b) and c) above
summary: Employees will not be paid out for any unused flexible EDOs, unless specific termination or early-hire adjustment circumstances apply.
logical_representation: IF untaken_flex_edos > 0 -> FORFEIT(PAY) UNLESS condition IN [CLAUSE_B_ADJUSTMENT, CLAUSE_C_ADJUSTMENT]
reasoning: This rule clarifies that an entitlement (flex EDOs) is for time off only and is not a cashable benefit, which is a rule governing compensation for time.

name: Plant Shutdown, Short Term Employee Schedule
rule_text: During a period of Plant Shutdown, all employees hired with the intentions of short- term employment shall be paid based on five (5) eight (8) hour days Monday to Friday or four (4) ten (10) hour days Monday to Thursday and or Tuesday to Friday.
summary: During a plant shutdown, short-term hires will work a schedule of either five 8-hour days (Mon-Fri) or four 10-hour days (Mon-Thurs or Tues-Fri).
logical_representation: IF work_period_type == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employee_type == SHORT_TERM -> SET(work_schedule, '5x8' OR '4x10')
reasoning: This rule defines the specific work schedules (hours and days) for a class of employees during a specific operational period, directly governing how their time is worked.

name: Plant Shutdown, Short Term Status Extension
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than six (6) weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a plant shutdown remain classified as short-term employees for pay purposes for the entire duration of the shutdown, even if it lasts longer than six weeks.
logical_representation: IF hired_for == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employment_duration_weeks > 6 -> MAINTAIN(employee_type, SHORT_TERM) AND MAINTAIN(payment_terms, SHORT_TERM)
reasoning: This rule is an explicit override to the standard employee classification timeline, which directly impacts pay and scheduling rules, making it a labor worked time issue.

name: Plant Shutdown, Long Term Crew Pay
rule_text: All Long Term Base Crew employees shall remain on the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a plant shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees continue to be paid under their normal Compressed Work Week rules, including any overtime for working on scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF work_period_type == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW -> MAINTAIN(payment_terms, COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule confirms that the standard pay and time categorization rules for a specific employee class remain in effect during a special work period.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Approved Worksites
rule_text:
APPROVED WORKSITES FOR THE 9/80 SCHEDULE

- □ Shell Scotford, Ft. Saskatchewan, Alberta
- □ Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, Redwater, Alberta
- □ Northwest Redwater, Alberta
summary: The 9/80 work schedule is only approved for use at three specific worksites: Shell Scotford, Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer, and Northwest Redwater.
logical_representation: IF worksite IN ['Shell Scotford', 'Nutrien Redwater Fertilizer', 'Northwest Redwater'] -> CONSTRAINT(9/80_schedule_applicable)
reasoning: This rule defines the geographic locations where specific schedule and time-tracking rules apply, making it a foundational condition for how worked time is categorized.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Definition
rule_text: This work week averages to forty (40) hours straight time over a two-week period and is generally known as the 9/80 schedule.
summary: The 9/80 schedule is a two-week work cycle that averages 40 straight-time hours per week.
logical_representation: SCHEDULE_DEFINITION(9/80) -> AVG(40_ST_hours_per_week_over_2_weeks)
reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental structure of the work schedule, which is the basis for categorizing hours worked as straight time or overtime.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Major Shutdown Exclusion
rule_text: It is intended for on-going work and does not operate in 'major shutdown' situations.
summary: The 9/80 work schedule is not applicable during major shutdowns and is only used for ongoing work.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'major_shutdown' -> CONSTRAINT(9/80_schedule_not_applicable)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition under which the entire 9/80 schedule and its associated pay rules are suspended, directly impacting how work time is managed and categorized.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Regular Hours
rule_text: The regular work week will consist of four (4) nine (9) hour straight time days Monday to Thursday and one (1) eight (8) hour straight time day on Friday in the first week.
summary: In the first week of the 9/80 schedule, the regular workday is 9 hours of straight time from Monday to Thursday, and 8 hours of straight time on Friday.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 1 AND day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU] -> MAX(9_ST_hours) | IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 1 AND day == FRI -> MAX(8_ST_hours)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the daily straight time hour limits for the first week of the schedule, which is a core component of categorizing worked time.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Regular Hours
rule_text: The regular work week will consist of four (4) nine (9) hour straight time days Monday to Thursday in the second week. Friday is a day off.
summary: In the second week of the 9/80 schedule, the regular workday is 9 hours of straight time from Monday to Thursday. Friday is a scheduled day off.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 2 AND day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU] -> MAX(9_ST_hours) | IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 2 AND day == FRI -> PAY(EDO)
reasoning: This rule defines the daily straight time hour limits and scheduled days off for the second week, directly governing how hours are classified.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime on 9-Hour Days
rule_text: Week 1 Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first three (3) hours worked before or after the regular nine (9) hour days. ... Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In Week 1, on the 9-hour days (Mon-Thurs), hours worked beyond the regular 9 are paid at time-and-a-half for the first 3 hours, and double-time for any hours after that.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 1 AND day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU] AND daily_hours > 9 -> MAX(3_OT_hours) -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the thresholds and pay rates for overtime hours on specific days of the work week, which is a classic example of categorizing worked time.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Overtime on 8-Hour Day
rule_text: Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first (4) hours worked before or after the regular eight (8) hour days. Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In Week 1, on the 8-hour Friday, hours worked beyond the regular 8 are paid at time-and-a-half for the first 4 hours, and double-time for any hours after that.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 1 AND day == FRI AND daily_hours > 8 -> MAX(4_OT_hours) -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific overtime thresholds and rates for the Friday in week 1, directly related to the classification of worked hours.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Overtime
rule_text: Week 2 Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first three (3) hours worked before or after the regular nine (9) hour days. Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: In Week 2, on the 9-hour days (Mon-Thurs), hours worked beyond the regular 9 are paid at time-and-a-half for the first 3 hours, and double-time for any hours after that.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '9/80' AND week == 2 AND day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU] AND daily_hours > 9 -> MAX(3_OT_hours) -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule specifies the overtime thresholds and pay rates for the workdays in the second week, a core function of categorizing worked time.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Earned Day Off Overtime
rule_text: Time and one half (1 ½) will be paid for the first twelve (12) hours worked on the earned Friday off. Double-time will be paid thereafter.
summary: For work performed on the scheduled Friday off in the second week, the first 12 hours are paid at time-and-a-half, and all subsequent hours are paid at double-time.
logical_representation: IF day == EDO -> MAX(12_OT_hours) -> TRANSITION(DT)
reasoning: This rule defines how hours worked on a specific type of day off (Earned Day Off) are categorized and paid, which falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Overtime, Sundays and Statutory Holidays
rule_text: Double-time will be paid on Sundays and Statutory Holidays for all hours worked
summary: All hours worked on any Sunday or Statutory Holiday are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day IN [SUN, STAT_HOLIDAY] -> ALL_HOURS(DT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a special pay rate for specific calendar days, which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time based on when it occurs.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement
rule_text: It is understood that those required to work more than ten (10) hours on this shift are entitled to an overtime meal and break pursuant to the overtime meal articles in the agreement.
summary: An employee who works more than 10 hours on a shift is entitled to an overtime meal and a break.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> MEAL_TRIG(1) AND PROVIDE(BREAK)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the conditions (working more than 10 hours) that trigger an entitlement to a meal, which is the core definition of LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE.

name: Standard Workday, IOL Strathcona
rule_text: Those employees working long-term maintenance at the Imperial Oil Strathcona site will work eight and sixth tenths (8.6) hours at straight time Monday to Friday.
summary: For long-term maintenance employees at the Imperial Oil Strathcona site, the standard workday is 8.6 hours at straight time, from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: IF employee_group == 'long-term maintenance' AND site == 'Imperial Oil Strathcona' AND day IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> MAX(8.6, ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard daily hours to be paid at straight time, which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: EDO Compensation Structure
rule_text: The extra six tenths of an hour (.6) hour worked each Monday to Friday is designed to compensate the employee for the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's.
summary: The additional 0.6 hours worked daily from Monday to Friday serves as compensation for the 16 scheduled Earned Days Off (EDOs).
logical_representation: IF day IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(0.6, ST) FOR EDO_COMPENSATION
reasoning: This rule explains the purpose and allocation of a specific portion of daily worked hours, tying it to the overall compensation scheme for Earned Days Off, which is a labor time rule.

name: Daily Overtime Threshold, IOL Strathcona
rule_text: All additional hours after the eight and sixth tenths (8.6) will be performed at the regular overtime provisions as indicated in the Maintenance Agreement.
summary: Any hours worked beyond the standard 8.6 hours in a day are considered overtime and will be paid according to the main Maintenance Agreement's overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours_worked > 8.6 -> TRANSITION(OT_FROM_MAIN_AGREEMENT)
reasoning: This rule sets the specific hourly threshold after which straight time ends and overtime begins on a standard workday, directly impacting the categorization of worked time.

name: Overtime Meal Break Entitlement
rule_text: It is understood that those required to work more than ten (10) hours on this shift are entitled to an overtime meal break at the ten hour mark (10) pursuant to the overtime meal articles in this agreement.
summary: Employees who work more than 10 hours in a shift are entitled to an overtime meal break right at the 10-hour mark, as specified in the agreement's meal articles.
logical_representation: IF hours_worked > 10 -> MEAL_TRIG(1)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition (working more than 10 hours) that explicitly triggers an entitlement for a meal break, which falls under the meal allowance topic.

name: EDO Work Pay Rate
rule_text: Overtime payments for work on the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's will be paid at double (2x).
summary: Any work performed on a scheduled Earned Day Off (EDO) must be paid at double the standard rate (2x).
logical_representation: IF work_day_type == SCHEDULED_EDO -> PAY_ALL(DT)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific pay rate (double time) for work performed on a special type of day (EDO), which is a core function of categorizing worked labor time.

name: Compressed Work Week Minimum Duration
rule_text: A "Compressed Work Week" system may be established when it is intended to operate the system in excess of fourteen (14) calendar days.
summary: A compressed work week schedule must be intended to last for more than 14 calendar days to be established.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK' -> MIN(intended_duration_days > 14)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition (minimum duration) for a specific work schedule (Compressed Work Week), which is fundamental to defining how work time is structured and paid. Therefore, it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Compressed Work Week Exception for 40-Hour Average Schedules
rule_text: The fourteen (14) calendar day requirement does not apply to those compressed work week schedules that average forty (40) hours per week, Monday to Friday. In this case, the schedule must be established for a minimum of one (1) week timeframe, Monday to Friday.
summary: For compressed work week schedules that average 40 hours weekly from Monday to Friday, the 14-day minimum duration does not apply; instead, a minimum duration of one week is required.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK' AND schedule_avg_hours_per_week == 40 AND schedule_days == ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> MIN(duration_weeks >= 1)
reasoning: This rule modifies the standard duration requirement for a specific type of work schedule, directly impacting how work time is organized and categorized. It is a core element of worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week Pay Adjustment for Not Meeting Duration
rule_text: In the event that the fourteen (14) day conditions are not met, pay conditions will be adjusted to pay eight (8) hours per day Monday through Friday at the straight time hourly rate, plus applicable shift premium, and all hours worked after the eight (8) hours per day, Monday through Friday and all hours worked on Saturday and Sunday at the applicable overtime rates.
summary: If a compressed work week schedule does not meet its required minimum duration (e.g., 14 days), employee pay for that period will be recalculated as if they were on a standard 5-day, 8-hour/day work week, with standard overtime rules applying.
logical_representation: IF cww_duration_condition_met == false -> RECALCULATE_PAY(schedule_type='5x8')
reasoning: This rule defines a financial penalty and a specific method for recalculating pay when schedule conditions are not met. It directly governs how hours are categorized (ST/OT) and paid, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Compressed Work Week Pay Adjustment for Inter-Schedule Transfers
rule_text: When an employee is transferred from one Compressed Work Week schedule to another Compressed Work Week schedule and either schedule does not last fourteen (14) days, pay conditions will be adjusted in accordance with Article 1.102 for that cycle.
summary: If an employee transfers between two compressed work week schedules and either the old or new schedule fails to last the required 14 days, their pay for that cycle will be recalculated based on a standard 5-day, 8-hour work week.
logical_representation: IF is_transfer_cww_to_cww == true AND cww_schedule_duration_met == false -> RECALCULATE_PAY(schedule_type='5x8')
reasoning: This rule specifies pay recalculation based on schedule duration and employee transfers, which directly impacts the categorization and payment of worked hours. It is a clear LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Compressed Work Week Standard Work Day
rule_text: The standard work day shall be up to twelve (12) hours of continuous employment including lunch breaks except those breaks provided for in Article 1.506.
summary: A standard workday on a compressed work week schedule can be up to 12 continuous hours, which includes lunch breaks (unless specified otherwise).
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == 'COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK' -> MAX(standard_work_day_hours <= 12)
reasoning: This rule defines the maximum length of a standard workday under a specific schedule, which is a foundational element for determining when regular hours end and overtime hours begin. It pertains directly to the categorization of worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week Overtime Trigger
rule_text: All overtime worked in excess of a regularly scheduled twelve (12), ten (10) or eight (8) hour shift and all hours worked on regularly scheduled days off shall be paid at the applicable overtime provisions in accordance with the established Compressed Work Week rates.
summary: Overtime is paid for any hours worked beyond an employee's regularly scheduled 8, 10, or 12-hour shift, and for all hours worked on their scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF hours_worked > scheduled_shift_hours OR is_scheduled_day_off == true -> PAY(OVERTIME)
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the conditions under which overtime is triggered (exceeding scheduled hours or working on a day off). This is a core concept of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime on Earned Day Off (12-Hour Shift)
rule_text: On the twelve (12) hour day, all Earned Days Off (EDO's) will be compensated as follows: The first three (3) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next six (6) hours worked at time and one half (1½x) The last three (3) hours worked at double-time (2x).
summary: When working on a scheduled day off (EDO) for a 12-hour shift schedule, the first 3 hours are paid at double time, the next 6 hours at time and a half, and the final 3 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_edo_worked == true AND base_shift_length == 12 -> PAY(hours_worked_on_edo[0-3] AT 2x, hours_worked_on_edo[3-9] AT 1.5x, hours_worked_on_edo[>9] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific, multi-tiered formula for calculating overtime pay on a specific day (EDO) for a specific shift type. It directly governs the rate of pay for worked hours, classifying it as LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Overtime on Earned Day Off (10-Hour Shift)
rule_text: On the ten (10) hour day, all EDO's will be compensated as follows: The first two and one half (2 ½) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next five (5) hours worked at time and one half (1 ½x) The last two and one half (2 ½) hours worked at double-time (2x)
summary: When working on a scheduled day off (EDO) for a 10-hour shift schedule, the first 2.5 hours are paid at double time, the next 5 hours at time and a half, and the final 2.5 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_edo_worked == true AND base_shift_length == 10 -> PAY(hours_worked_on_edo[0-2.5] AT 2x, hours_worked_on_edo[2.5-7.5] AT 1.5x, hours_worked_on_edo[>7.5] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule details a specific formula for calculating overtime pay on a designated day (EDO) for a 10-hour shift schedule, clearly defining how worked time is to be compensated. It falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Overtime on Earned Day Off (8-Hour Shift)
rule_text: On the eight (8) hour day, all EDO's will be compensated as follows: The first two (2) hours worked at double-time (2x) The next four (4) hours worked at time and one half (1 ½x) The last two (2) hours at double-time (2x)
summary: When working on a scheduled day off (EDO) for an 8-hour shift schedule, the first 2 hours are paid at double time, the next 4 hours at time and a half, and the final 2 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF is_edo_worked == true AND base_shift_length == 8 -> PAY(hours_worked_on_edo[0-2] AT 2x, hours_worked_on_edo[2-6] AT 1.5x, hours_worked_on_edo[>6] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule provides a precise, multi-tiered formula for calculating overtime pay on a specific day (EDO) for an 8-hour shift schedule, making it a clear LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Statutory Holiday Pay Rate
rule_text: All hours worked on Statutory Holidays will be paid at double-time (2x) in accordance with Compressed Work Week rates.
summary: Any hours worked on a statutory holiday are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF is_statutory_holiday == true -> PAY(ALL_HOURS AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific pay rate for a special day (Statutory Holiday), which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing and compensating worked time.

name: Penalty for Avoiding Statutory Holiday Pay
rule_text: A Compressed Work Week shift schedule will not be cancelled and reinstituted within a cycle if the intention is to avoid payment for statutory holidays. If this occurs all time worked on the first cycle after reinstitution up to a maximum of fourteen (14) days will be in accordance with Day Work Conditions.
summary: Employers cannot cancel and then restart a compressed work week schedule simply to avoid paying for a statutory holiday. If this happens, all work during the first 14 days of the new schedule will be paid under standard 'Day Work' rules, not the compressed schedule rates.
logical_representation: IF cww_cancelled_to_avoid_stat_pay == true -> RECALCULATE_PAY(schedule_type='Day_Work', duration_days=14)
reasoning: This rule establishes a penalty and a specific pay recalculation method to prevent manipulation of work schedules around holidays. It directly governs how pay is calculated for worked time, classifying it as LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Compressed Work Week Night Shift Premium
rule_text: The shift premium on all compressed work week night shifts will be three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) per hour for all straight time hours worked on shift.
summary: Employees on a compressed work week night shift receive an additional $3.50 per hour for all straight time hours worked.
logical_representation: IF is_cww_schedule == true AND shift_type == 'NIGHT' AND time_bucket == 'ST' -> PREMIUM($3.50)
reasoning: This rule specifies a monetary premium for working during certain hours (night shift) under a specific schedule. This addition to the base rate is a core component of calculating pay for worked time.

name: Unpaid Lunch Break on 10-Hour Shifts
rule_text: When working ten (10) hours with two (2) fifteen (15) minute paid breaks and a half (1/2) hour lunch, the midday lunch period of one-half (1/2) hour on workdays of ten (10) hours or less between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m. will be unpaid.
summary: On workdays of 10 hours or less that occur between 7:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m., the 30-minute midday lunch break is unpaid.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours <= 10 AND shift_time_window == '7:30-19:30' AND break_type == 'LUNCH' -> PAY(0)
reasoning: This rule defines whether a specific period within the workday (a lunch break) is paid or unpaid. This directly impacts the calculation of total paid hours, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Paid Breaks on 12-Hour Shifts
