rule_text: On twelve (12) hour shifts when working in conjunction with the Client's personnel the breaks provided will be the same as those scheduled for the Client working the same compressed work week schedule in the area. ... In all other instances there shall be three (3) half hour (1/2) paid breaks per twelve (12) hour shifts.
summary: On 12-hour shifts, employees receive three paid 30-minute breaks. However, if working alongside the client's staff, they will follow the client's break schedule instead.
logical_representation: IF shift_length_hours == 12 AND working_with_client == false -> PROVIDE(break_count=3, break_duration_minutes=30, break_is_paid=true)
reasoning: This rule specifies the number, duration, and paid status of breaks during a workday. Determining which hours are paid work and which are paid breaks falls under the categorization of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Penalty for Insufficient Notice of Shift Change
rule_text: An employee will be given twenty-four (24) hours advance notice prior to the start of their new shift and if not then they shall be paid their first shift at time and one-half (1 ½x).
summary: If an employee is not given at least 24 hours' notice before a shift change, their entire first shift on the new schedule must be paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice_hours < 24 -> PAY(first_shift_all_hours AT 1.5x)
reasoning: This rule imposes a penalty rate of pay for a specific condition (lack of notice). This directly alters the pay rate for worked hours, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule. This rule appears in 1.509.2, 1.510.1, and 1.511.1 and is identical.

name: Pay for Lost Time Due to CWW to CWW Shift Change
rule_text: If an employee loses time on their initial Compressed Work Week schedule due to having their Compressed Work Week schedule changed to a new Compressed Work Week schedule, they shall be paid for those hours they would have worked on their initial schedule up to the start of their new schedule.
summary: When an employee's shift is changed from one compressed schedule to another, they must be paid for any hours they would have worked on their original schedule but missed due to the change.
logical_representation: IF is_transfer_cww_to_cww == true AND lost_hours_due_to_change > 0 -> PAY(lost_hours_due_to_change)
reasoning: This rule guarantees payment for time that was scheduled but not worked due to an employer-directed change. This is a form of guaranteed pay related to work schedules, which is part of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Limit on Pay for Lost Time During Shift Change
rule_text: In no case will missed hours be paid if the employee works forty (40) or more straight time hours in the calendar week. If less than forty (40) hours is worked in the calendar week, missed hours on the initial schedule will be paid but only to the extent that straight time hours on the new schedule in the calendar week plus hours worked on the old schedule in the calendar week plus missed hours on the initial schedule does not exceed forty (40).
summary: Payment for hours lost due to a shift change is capped. An employee will not be paid for missed hours if they already worked 40 or more straight-time hours that week. If they worked less than 40 hours, they will only be paid for missed hours up to a combined total of 40 straight-time hours for the week.
logical_representation: IF lost_hours_due_to_change > 0 -> PAY(MIN(lost_hours_due_to_change, 40 - weekly_st_hours_worked))
reasoning: This rule places a condition and a cap on a pay entitlement (pay for lost time). It directly modifies the calculation of paid hours for the week, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Earned Days Off (EDO) Entitlement
rule_text: Earned days off on a Compressed Work Week are days which are scheduled as regular days off and are earned when regular scheduled consecutive work days immediately preceding have been worked.
summary: On a compressed work week, an employee earns their scheduled days off by working all of their scheduled consecutive workdays leading up to those days off.
logical_representation: IF scheduled_work_days_worked == scheduled_work_days_total -> ENTITLEMENT(EDO)
reasoning: This rule defines the condition for earning paid time off, which is a key component of a work schedule and overall compensation for time. It fits within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Proration of Earned Days Off
rule_text: If a fraction of the regular work days are worked the same fraction of the immediately following regular days off are earned. Any fraction of a day shall be considered one day when calculating earned days off.
summary: If an employee works only part of their scheduled workdays, they earn a proportional amount of their scheduled days off. When calculating this, any fraction of a day off earned is rounded up to a full day.
logical_representation: IF fraction_of_work_days_worked < 1 -> PRORATED(EDO_earned = CEILING(fraction_of_work_days_worked * total_scheduled_days_off))
reasoning: This rule provides a specific formula for calculating an entitlement (earned days off) based on time worked. This calculation is integral to managing and compensating for an employee's time.

name: Handling of Earned Days Off During Shift Transfer
rule_text: When an employee is transferred to a different shift schedule all scheduled days off which have been earned must be given to the employee prior to the start of their new schedule. If earned days off are worked they shall be considered overtime and paid the applicable overtime rate.
summary: When an employee is transferred to a new shift, they must be given all their previously earned days off before starting the new schedule. If the employer requires them to work on these earned days off, that time must be paid at the applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF is_transferring_shifts == true AND has_earned_days_off == true -> PROVIDE(EDO) BEFORE new_schedule_start | IF is_edo_worked == true -> PAY(OVERTIME)
reasoning: This rule dictates both the scheduling of time off and the pay rate if that time off is worked. Both aspects are central to the management and compensation of an employee's time, classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule (Daily)
rule_text: Monday [to] Friday | 8 hours Straight Time | Up to 2 hours TimeandOneHalf (1.5x) | After 10 hours DoubleTime (2x)
summary: On a 5-day, 8-hour/day schedule (Monday-Friday), the first 8 hours are paid at straight time, the next 2 hours (hours 9 and 10) are at time and a half, and any hours worked beyond 10 in a day are at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU', 'FRI'] -> PAY(daily_hours[0-8] AT 1x, daily_hours[8-10] AT 1.5x, daily_hours[>10] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule provides a clear, tiered structure for calculating daily pay based on hours worked, defining the thresholds for straight time, time and a half, and double time. This is a classic LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule (Weekend & Stat Holiday)
rule_text:
Saturday | All hours DoubleTime (2x)
Sunday | All hours DoubleTime (2x)
Stat Holiday | All hours DoubleTime (2x)
summary: On a 5-day, 8-hour/day schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN', 'STAT_HOLIDAY'] -> PAY(ALL_HOURS AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for specific, non-standard workdays (weekends and holidays), which is a core function of categorizing and calculating pay for worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thurs Schedule (Regular Day)
rule_text: Monday [to] Thursday | 10 hours Straight Time | After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour/day schedule from Monday to Thursday, the first 10 hours each day are paid at straight time, and any hours worked beyond 10 are at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thu' AND day_of_week IN ['MON', 'TUE', 'WED', 'THU'] -> PAY(daily_hours[0-10] AT 1x, daily_hours[>10] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule sets the straight time and overtime thresholds for regular workdays on a specific schedule. It is fundamental to the calculation of pay for hours worked.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thurs Schedule (Friday)
rule_text: Friday | Up to 10 hours Time and One Half (1.5x) | After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour/day schedule (Monday-Thursday), all hours worked on a Friday are paid at time and a half for the first 10 hours, and double time thereafter.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Mon-Thu' AND day_of_week == 'FRI' -> PAY(daily_hours[0-10] AT 1.5x, daily_hours[>10] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule defines the overtime rates for a scheduled day off (Friday) in a 4x10 work week, which is a core component of categorizing and paying for worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule (Monday)
rule_text: Monday | Up to 10 hours Time and One Half (1.5x) | After 10 hours Double Time (2x)
summary: On a 4-day, 10-hour/day schedule from Tuesday to Friday, any hours worked on Monday are paid at time and a half for the first 10 hours, and double time for any hours beyond that.
logical_representation: IF schedule == '4x10_Tue-Fri' AND day_of_week == 'MON' -> PAY(daily_hours[0-10] AT 1.5x, daily_hours[>10] AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rates for working on a scheduled day off (Monday) for a particular work schedule. This is a direct rule about categorizing and compensating worked hours.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Schedules (Weekend & Stat Holiday)
rule_text:
Saturday | All hours Double Time (2x)
Sunday | All hours Double Time (2x)
Stat Holiday | All hours Double Time (2x)
summary: For any 4-day, 10-hour/day schedule, all hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND day_of_week IN ['SAT', 'SUN', 'STAT_HOLIDAY'] -> PAY(ALL_HOURS AT 2x)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific, premium pay rate for special days (weekends and holidays), which is a key part of defining how worked time is compensated.

name: Bereavement Pay Entitlement
rule_text: For those employees with more than three (3) years of service with an Employer, the employee will be entitled to bereavement pay benefits of eight (8) hours multiplied by the employees' base wage rate for up to three (3) days of lost work incurred as a result of the employee's attendance at a funeral or memorial service upon the death of an employee's Spouse, Child, Parent, Parent -inLaw, Grandparent or Sibling. Bereavement Pay Benefits shall be paid at the straight time rate.
summary: Employees with over three years of service are entitled to up to three days of bereavement leave upon the death of an immediate family member. Each day is paid for 8 hours at the employee's straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF years_of_service > 3 AND reason_for_absence == 'BEREAVEMENT' AND relationship IN ['SPOUSE', 'CHILD', 'PARENT', 'PARENT_IN_LAW', 'GRANDPARENT', 'SIBLING'] -> PAY(MAX(3_days * 8_hours_per_day) AT 1x)
reasoning: This rule provides for paid time off under specific circumstances. Since it deals with payment for hours not worked as an entitlement based on service, it falls under the broad category of managing and compensating an employee's time.

name: Vacation Pay Tiers
summary: For long-term maintenance employees, vacation pay is calculated as a percentage of earnings based on years of service: 6% for up to 3 years, 7% for 3-7 years, 8% for 7-10 years, 9% for 10-12 years, and 10% for over 12 years.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == 'LONG_TERM_MAINTENANCE' -> PAY(VACATION_PAY_PERCENTAGE based on years_of_service)
reasoning: This rule establishes the rate at which vacation pay, a form of compensation for time, is accrued. It's a direct entitlement related to an employee's service time and overall compensation structure.

name: Vacation Pay Service Continuity
rule_text: Long term maintenance employees who have a break in service with the Employer will maintain their years of service should the break in service be less than ninety (90) calendar days. A change to the commercial contract whereby an individual is moved from one Signatory Employer to another shall not be considered a break in service. The break in service is not applicable for those who quit or are terminated.
summary: For calculating vacation pay, a long-term maintenance employee's years of service are maintained if a break in employment is less than 90 days. Changing between signatory employers does not count as a break. This does not apply if the employee quits or is terminated.
logical_representation: IF break_in_service_days < 90 AND reason_for_break NOT IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATION'] -> MAINTAIN(years_of_service)
reasoning: This rule defines how 'years of service' are calculated, which is a key input for the vacation pay entitlement. It directly affects a compensation component based on time, placing it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: CF Industries SDO Overtime Trigger
rule_text: The first two hours of overtime on the 8-9-9-8-8 will be compensated at time and one half (1 ½).
summary: On the special 8-9-9-8-8 schedule at CF Industries, the first two hours of overtime worked are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF site == 'CF_Industries' AND schedule == '8-9-9-8-8' -> PAY(overtime_hours[0-2] AT 1.5x)
reasoning: This rule specifies the overtime rate for a particular, site-specific work schedule. This is a direct rule governing the compensation of worked hours.

name: CF Industries SDO Pay Calculation
rule_text: All work on the SDO will be paid in accordance with the number of hours an individual employee has worked since the last SDO. For example: if an individual has worked three (3) of the scheduled nine (9) hour days and are asked to work an SDO, the first five (5) hours on the schedule will be paid at the straight time rate and all additional hours will be compensated at the appropriate overtime rate as per the collective agreement.
summary: At CF Industries, pay for working a Scheduled Day Off (SDO) depends on completing the 40-hour work week first. Any hours worked on the SDO that are needed to reach 40 straight-time hours for the cycle are paid at straight time; only hours worked beyond the 40-hour threshold are paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF site == 'CF_Industries' AND is_sdo_worked == true -> PAY(hours_to_reach_40_st AT 1x) THEN PAY(hours_after_40_st AT OT_RATE)
reasoning: This rule describes a complex calculation for determining when straight time ends and overtime begins on a special day (SDO). It is fundamentally about categorizing hours worked into different pay buckets, which is the definition of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Maintenance Work Wage Rate
rule_text: Wage rates for maintenance work shall be $0.75 per hour less than base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement of the Member Union where such work is to be performed and shall be paid to all employees under the terms of this agreement.
summary: The hourly wage for maintenance work is set at $0.75 less than the standard base rate defined in the relevant Area Labour Agreement.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'maintenance' -> PAY(base_rate_area_agreement - $0.75)
reasoning: This rule defines the calculation of a specific wage rate based on hours worked, which is a fundamental component of compensating for worked time.

name: Employer Option for Electronic Pay Records
rule_text: At the Employer's option, electronic pay records and records of Employment may be provided in lieu of  printed  records.
summary: The employer can choose to provide pay records and Records of Employment electronically instead of as printed documents.
logical_representation: IF employer_discretion -> PROVIDE(electronic_pay_records) AND PROVIDE(electronic_roe)
reasoning: This rule pertains to the administration and delivery of payment information for hours worked, which is an essential part of the labor payment process.

name: Employee Right to Printed Pay Records
rule_text: Upon  request  from  an  employee  that  does  not  have  the  capability  to  access electronic records, printed pay records shall be issued.
summary: If an employee cannot access electronic records, they can request printed pay records, and the employer must provide them.
logical_representation: IF employee_request AND employee_capability_electronic_access == false -> OBLIGATION(PROVIDE(printed_pay_records))
reasoning: This rule governs the method of communicating payment details for worked time, directly relating to the administration of wages.

name: Employee Right to Printed Record of Employment
rule_text: Upon request, a printed record of employment will be issued.
summary: An employee can request a printed Record of Employment, and the employer must issue it.
logical_representation: IF employee_request -> OBLIGATION(PROVIDE(printed_roe))
reasoning: This rule concerns the provision of employment records, which document worked time and earnings, and is thus related to the administration of worked time.

name: Ft. McMurray Maintenance Wage Rate Exception
rule_text: For projects that are located within a one hundred (100) radius kilometers of Ft. McMurray city hall, wage rates for maintenance shall be 100% of base rates set forth in the Area Labour Agreement.
summary: For maintenance work within a 100km radius of Ft. McMurray city hall, the wage rate is 100% of the Area Labour Agreement's base rate, overriding the standard reduction.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'maintenance' AND project_location_fort_mcmurray_radius_km <= 100 -> PAY(base_rate_area_agreement * 1.0)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific wage rate for worked time based on a geographic condition, directly affecting how labor time is valued and paid.

name: Weekly Payday Schedule
rule_text: Wages will be paid weekly by cheque or other legal tender by the end of the work day on Thursday.
summary: Employees will be paid their weekly wages by the end of the workday every Thursday.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT pay_frequency == weekly AND pay_day <= Thursday EOD
reasoning: This rule establishes the timing and frequency for the payment of wages earned from worked time, a core component of labor payment administration.

name: Second Shift Payday Schedule
rule_text: If there is a second shift the weekly cheques will be distributed by the end of the work day Wednesday if available on site.
summary: For employees on a second shift, weekly paycheques will be distributed by the end of Wednesday's workday, provided they are available on site.
logical_representation: IF shift == 'second' AND cheques_available_on_site == true -> OBLIGATION(PAY() by Wednesday EOD)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to the standard payday schedule based on an employee's work schedule, linking payment timing directly to worked time.

name: Foreperson ICCS Premium
rule_text: General Forepersons and Forepersons who have achieved the status of Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor designation from the Alberta Apprenticeship Industry Training will receive an additional one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) over the regular General Forepersons and Forepersons rates (for all hours worked) contained in the applicable reference agreement.
summary: General Forepersons and Forepersons with an Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor (ICCS) designation receive a $1.50 per hour premium on top of their regular rate for all hours worked.
logical_representation: IF (role == 'General Foreperson' OR role == 'Foreperson') AND certification_iccs == true -> PREMIUM($1.50)
reasoning: This rule adds a premium to the hourly wage rate based on a qualification, directly affecting the value and calculation of payment for worked time.

name: ICCS Premium No Pyramiding
rule_text: The premium is not to be pyramided.
summary: The $1.50 per hour premium for the Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor designation cannot be compounded or stacked with other premiums.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT iccs_premium_pyramiding == false
reasoning: This rule places a constraint on the calculation of a wage premium, which is a key aspect of determining the final pay for worked time.

name: Employer Fund Contributions
rule_text:
Employers will make appropriate contributions to the following funds for those participating trades which  have  the  provision  contained  within  their  respective  Industrial  Construction  Reference Agreement:
- o Building Trades of Alberta
- o Audiometric Testing
- o Construction Employee Family Assistance Program (CEFAP)
- o Case Managed Aftercare (CMAC)
- o Rapid Site Access Program (RSAP)
- o Workforce Development Trust Fund (WFDT)
summary: Employers are required to contribute to a specific list of funds (e.g., Building Trades of Alberta, CEFAP) for trades whose reference agreements include these provisions.
logical_representation: IF trade_is_participating -> OBLIGATION(CONTRIBUTE(specified_funds))
reasoning: This rule defines employer obligations for monetary contributions that are often calculated based on hours worked, making it a component of the overall labor cost for worked time.

name: Enablement Clause Parity
rule_text: Any enablement provisions made by the Local Unions to the wage rates or benefits  packages and provided to any Employer will be extended to NMA Employers when bidding the same or similar work packages. In these circumstances' maintenance will be at the enabled conditions.
summary: If a Local Union offers more favorable wage or benefit terms (enablement provisions) to any employer, those same terms must be offered to NMA Employers bidding on similar work.
logical_representation: IF enablement_provision_exists_for_any_employer -> OBLIGATION(EXTEND(enablement_provision) TO nma_employer)
reasoning: This rule ensures parity in wage rates and benefits, directly impacting the calculation and conditions of payment for worked time for a specific group of employers.

name: Implementation Period for Monetary Changes
rule_text: Upon renewal of a Local Reference Agreement the Employer will have thirty (30) days from receipt of notification to implement any initial monetary changes.
summary: When a Local Reference Agreement is renewed, the employer has 30 days after being notified to implement any new monetary changes, such as wage increases.
logical_representation: IF agreement_renewal -> SET(implementation_deadline_days, 30, AFTER(notification_date))
reasoning: This rule sets a timeline for applying changes to wage rates, which is a procedural aspect of administering payment for worked time.

name: Retroactive Pay for Increases
rule_text: Payment of any initial increase will be paid retroactively to the implementation date.
summary: Any initial wage increases from a new agreement must be paid retroactively, going back to the official implementation date of that agreement.
logical_representation: IF wage_increase -> OBLIGATION(PAY(retroactively) TO implementation_date)
reasoning: This rule dictates how past worked time should be recalculated and paid in the event of a wage increase, directly relating to the compensation for that time.

name: Alloy Welder Premium on Dispatch
rule_text: Alloy welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of three dollars and twenty-five cents ($3.25) per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: If an alloy welding certificate was a prerequisite for being dispatched to a job, the certified welder receives a premium of $3.25 for each hour worked.
logical_representation: IF role == 'welder' AND certification_alloy_welder == true AND dispatch_requirement == true -> PREMIUM($3.25)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific monetary premium added to the hourly wage for a skilled position, directly impacting the calculation of pay for worked time.

name: Alloy Welder Reclassification On-Site
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to  be  certified  by  the  employer  and  is  requested  to  perform  alloy  welding,  the  worker  will  be  reclassified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium from the date of re-classification.
summary: If a certified welder (not originally dispatched for alloy work) is asked to perform alloy welding, they will be reclassified and will start receiving the alloy welder premium from that date forward.
logical_representation: IF role == 'welder' AND certification_alloy_welder == true AND work_performed == 'alloy_welding' -> RECLASSIFY('alloy_welder') AND PREMIUM($3.25) FROM reclassification_date
reasoning: This rule details the conditions under which an employee's pay rate changes due to a change in duties, directly linking the type of work performed to the rate of pay for that time.

name: Alloy Welder Premium Calculation
rule_text: This premium shall not pyramid on an overtime hour; however, it will attract applicable Vacation and Statutory Holiday Pay.
summary: The alloy welder premium is not multiplied for overtime hours, but it is included when calculating vacation and statutory holiday pay.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT alloy_welder_premium_pyramiding == false ON OT | INCLUDE(alloy_welder_premium) IN (vacation_pay_calculation, stat_holiday_pay_calculation)
reasoning: This rule specifies how a wage premium interacts with other pay components like overtime and vacation pay, which is a key part of calculating total compensation for worked time.

name: Final Pay on Termination at Jobsite
rule_text: Employees who are laid off or terminated from the services of the Company shall normally receive their final wages, vacation pay due, and unemployment insurance record of earnings before they leave the jobsite.
summary: Typically, when an employee is laid off or terminated, they should receive all final pay and their Record of Employment before leaving the worksite.
logical_representation: IF employment_status IN ('laid_off', 'terminated') -> OBLIGATION(PROVIDE(final_pay_and_roe) BEFORE leave_jobsite)
reasoning: This rule sets the standard procedure for the final payment of all earned wages upon cessation of employment, governing the last transaction for worked time.

name: Mailing Final Pay on Termination
rule_text: In these cases final wages, vacation pay due, and Records of Earnings (ROE's) will be mailed to the employee's last  recorded  home  address  within  three  (3)  working  days  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory  Holidays.
summary: If final pay cannot be provided at the jobsite, it must be mailed to the employee's last known address within three business days of termination.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_not_at_jobsite -> OBLIGATION(MAIL(final_pay_and_roe) WITHIN 3_working_days)
reasoning: This rule defines an alternative timeline and method for issuing final payment for worked time when the standard procedure is not possible.

name: ROE Filing and Mailing Options
rule_text: EI  Records  of  Earnings  (ROE's)  will  be  filed  electronically  or  at  the  employees' written request be mailed Express Post to the employees' last recorded home address within three (3) working days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays.
summary: Records of Earnings will be filed electronically unless an employee makes a written request for it to be sent by Express Post to their home address within three business days.
logical_representation: DEFAULT roe_filing_method = 'electronic' | IF employee_written_request -> OBLIGATION(MAIL(roe_express_post) WITHIN 3_working_days)
reasoning: This rule specifies the administrative procedures for the Record of Earnings, a document that summarizes an employee's history of worked time and earnings.

name: Final Electronic Pay Deadline
rule_text: When electronic deposits are made, the final deposit and other termination document mailings/filings must be made by the next pay period.
summary: If an employee is paid by electronic deposit, their final pay and termination documents must be processed no later than the next scheduled pay period.
logical_representation: IF payment_method == 'electronic_deposit' -> OBLIGATION(PROCESS(final_pay) BY next_pay_period)
reasoning: This rule establishes the deadline for issuing final payment for all worked time when using electronic banking, a key administrative aspect of wages.

name: Penalty for Late Mailed Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay earnings not be mailed within this time period noted above, the  Company  will  pay  a  penalty  of  $100.00  per  day,  exclusive  of  Saturdays,  Sundays  and Statutory Holidays, until the mailing or filing is made.
summary: If the company fails to mail final wages and vacation pay within the three-business-day deadline, it must pay a penalty of $100 for each business day of delay.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_mailed_late -> PENALTY($100) PER day
reasoning: This rule creates a financial penalty for failing to pay for worked time by the contractual deadline, enforcing the timely administration of wages.

name: Penalty for Late Electronic Final Pay
rule_text: Should wages and vacation pay not be electronically submitted by the next pay period the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays. The penalty will be imposed from the pay date for which the electronic deposit was not received.
summary: If the company fails to electronically deposit final pay by the next pay period, it must pay a $100 penalty for each business day of delay, starting from the missed payday.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_electronic_late -> PENALTY($100) PER day
reasoning: This rule imposes a financial penalty for the late payment of electronically deposited final wages, ensuring compliance with payment schedules for worked time.

name: Correction Period for Final Pay Error
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the final electronic deposit, the Company will have three (3) days, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment. Should this make-up payment not be made within the three (3) days, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 from the pay date of the final electronic deposit.
summary: If there's an error on a final electronic pay, the company has three days after being notified to correct it. If they fail, a $100 penalty applies, retroactive to the original final pay date.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_error -> OBLIGATION(CORRECT_PAYMENT() WITHIN 3_days_of_notification) | IF NOT OBLIGATION -> PENALTY($100)
reasoning: This rule outlines the process and penalties for correcting errors in the payment for worked time, which is a critical aspect of wage administration.

name: Grievance Timeline for Final Pay Issues
rule_text: Complaints/grievances with respect to non-receipt of final wages, vacation pay due and employment insurance record of earnings must be raised to the Company in a timely fashion, in any event, not more than ten (10) days, exclusive of Saturday, Sunday and Holidays, from date of lay-off/termination.
summary: Any complaints or grievances about not receiving final pay or ROE must be submitted to the company within ten business days of the layoff or termination date.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_grievance -> OBLIGATION(SUBMIT() WITHIN 10_working_days_of_termination)
reasoning: This rule establishes a procedural timeline for disputes regarding the payment for worked time, directly relating to the administration and resolution of wage issues.

name: Correction of Significant Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should employees be short paid ten (10) or more hours or equivalent value on their weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit, the Company will provide an adjustment on a subsequent pay date but not later than ten (10) days exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and Statutory Holidays after notification of the shortage is received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If an employee is shorted 10 or more hours of pay, the company must provide a make-up payment within ten business days of being officially notified of the error.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours >= 10 -> OBLIGATION(CORRECT_PAYMENT() WITHIN 10_working_days_of_notification)
reasoning: This rule dictates the timeline for correcting significant errors in payment for worked time, ensuring proper wage administration.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Significant Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this payment not be made within the allotted ten (10) days, the Company will pay the penalty amount noted in article 9.400 above from the date the issue was raised by the employee and received in writing and acknowledged by the Company.
summary: If the company fails to correct a significant pay shortage (10+ hours) within the ten-day timeframe, it must pay the specified penalty ($100/day) starting from the date the error was reported.
logical_representation: IF significant_pay_shortage_correction_late -> PENALTY($100) PER day
reasoning: This rule enforces the timely correction of wage errors with a financial penalty, directly related to the proper payment for worked time.

name: Correction of Minor Pay Shortage
rule_text: In the event that there is a payroll error (miscalculation) on the weekly pay cheque or electronic deposit where an employee is short paid less than ten (10) hours or equivalent, the Company will have two (2) payroll periods, after notification is provided to the Company in accordance with the Company's normal payroll query process, to provide a make-up payment.
summary: If an employee is shorted less than 10 hours of pay, the company has two pay periods after being notified to correct the error and provide a make-up payment.
logical_representation: IF pay_shortage_hours < 10 -> OBLIGATION(CORRECT_PAYMENT() WITHIN 2_pay_periods_of_notification)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific timeline for correcting minor errors in the payment for worked time, forming part of the wage administration framework.

name: Penalty for Uncorrected Minor Pay Shortage
rule_text: Should this make-up payment not be made within the two (2) payroll periods, the Company will pay a penalty of $100.00 per day from the date the Company was notified.
summary: If the company fails to correct a minor pay shortage (less than 10 hours) within two pay periods, it must pay a penalty of $100 per day, starting from the date it was notified of the error.
logical_representation: IF minor_pay_shortage_correction_late -> PENALTY($100) PER day
reasoning: This rule applies a financial penalty for failing to correct minor wage errors in a timely manner, enforcing the accurate payment for worked time.

name: Penalty Condition for Late Payroll Query
rule_text: Should  the  employee  not  submit  a  payroll  query  within  three  (3)  weeks  of  the  payroll  error (miscalculation) the penalty payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day will be applicable on day 15 from the submission of the query.
summary: If an employee waits more than three weeks to report a minor payroll error, the $100 daily penalty for non-correction will only start 15 days after they finally submit the query.
logical_representation: IF payroll_query_submission_weeks > 3 -> SET(penalty_start_day, 15, AFTER(query_submission_date))
reasoning: This rule modifies the penalty conditions for late wage corrections based on the employee's reporting timeline, creating a procedural nuance in wage administration.

name: Overpayment Negotiation Process
rule_text: When the Company or the Employee becomes aware of an overpayment, the Company the Union and the Employee will meet to negotiate the repayment terms.
summary: If a wage overpayment occurs, the company, the union, and the employee must meet to negotiate the terms under which the money will be repaid.
logical_representation: IF overpayment_detected -> OBLIGATION(MEET(company, union, employee) TO NEGOTIATE(repayment_terms))
reasoning: This rule establishes the process for resolving errors in payment for worked time, specifically overpayments, which is a key part of wage administration.

name: List of Recognized Statutory Holidays
rule_text: The following days will constitute the recognized holidays within the terms of this Agreement. ... 1. New Years Day 2. Family Day 3. Good Friday 4. Victoria Day 5. Canada Day 6. Civic Holiday 7. Labour Day 8. National Day for Truth & Reconciliation 9. Thanksgiving Day 10. Remembrance Day 11. Christmas Day 12. Boxing Day
summary: The agreement recognizes twelve specific days as statutory holidays, including New Year's Day, Canada Day, and Christmas Day.
logical_representation: IF date IS_IN (New_Years_Day, Family_Day, Good_Friday, Victoria_Day, Canada_Day, Civic_Holiday, Labour_Day, National_Day_for_Truth_Reconciliation, Thanksgiving_Day, Remembrance_Day, Christmas_Day, Boxing_Day) -> day_type = STATUTORY_HOLIDAY
reasoning: This rule defines which specific calendar days are categorized as Statutory Holidays, which is a fundamental aspect of classifying work time for pay purposes.

name: Automatic Recognition of New Government Holidays
rule_text: Any other holiday proclaimed by either the Provincial or Federal Government will be automatically recognized within this Agreement.
summary: If the Provincial or Federal Government proclaims a new public holiday, it will automatically be considered a recognized holiday under this agreement.
logical_representation: IF is_government_proclaimed_holiday(date) -> day_type = STATUTORY_HOLIDAY
reasoning: This rule adds a condition for classifying a day as a Statutory Holiday, directly impacting how work time is categorized and paid on that day.

name: Default Holiday Observance Date
rule_text: Each of the recognized holidays listed in Article 12.100 shall be observed on the calendar day on which it occurs.
summary: Recognized statutory holidays are to be observed on the actual calendar date on which they fall.
logical_representation: IF day_type == STATUTORY_HOLIDAY -> observed_date = holiday_calendar_date
reasoning: This rule establishes the default timing for when a special work day (Statutory Holiday) is observed, which is essential for scheduling and payroll categorization.

name: Moving Specific Holidays into Work Week
rule_text: When any of these three identified holidays: Family Day, Victoria Day, Labour Day fall outside of the regularly scheduled work week, they will be moved into the work week for observance.
summary: If Family Day, Victoria Day, or Labour Day fall on a weekend or other non-scheduled workday, the day of observance is moved to a day within the regular work week.
logical_representation: IF holiday_name IN (Family_Day, Victoria_Day, Labour_Day) AND is_in_work_week == FALSE -> observed_date = NEXT_AVAILABLE_WORK_DAY
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to the default observance date for specific holidays, altering the schedule and thus affecting the classification of workdays.

name: Holiday Work Pay or Day Off Option
rule_text: On the day of observance, the Company may either pay the workforce at double-time (2) the total package straight time hourly rate or provide the day off.
summary: On a statutory holiday, the company has the option to either have employees work at double-time pay or give them the day off.
logical_representation: IF day_type == STATUTORY_HOLIDAY_OBSERVED -> company_decision IN (PAY(2 * total_package_straight_time_hourly_rate), PROVIDE(day_off))
reasoning: This rule directly defines the pay rate (double-time) for working on a specific category of day (Statutory Holiday), which is a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Maintenance Holiday Harmonization with Client
rule_text: On maintenance, the overriding factor is harmonizing statutory holidays with in-plant workers. Should the Owner determine another day be recognized for its people, this day will be recognized by Company forces.
summary: For maintenance work, if the facility owner observes a statutory holiday on a different day, the company's employees will observe the holiday on that same day to align schedules.
logical_representation: IF work_type == MAINTENANCE AND owner_observes_holiday_on_different_day == TRUE -> observed_date = owner_observed_holiday_date
reasoning: This rule dictates a condition under which the date of a special pay day (Statutory Holiday) is moved, which is a key aspect of defining and scheduling work time.

name: Harmonization Triggered by Client Direction
rule_text: The day of observance for the Holiday remains as identified, unless direction has been given by the Client requesting for our employers to observe it at the same time as the in-plant personnel.
summary: Moving the observance date of a holiday to match the client's schedule (harmonization) only happens if the client explicitly directs the employer to do so.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: holiday_harmonization_rule_applies ONLY_IF client_direction_to_harmonize == TRUE
reasoning: This rule places a specific condition on the movement of a holiday observance date, which is a rule governing the scheduling and categorization of special work days.

name: Harmonization GPMC Notification Prerequisite
rule_text: In order for the harmonization principle to be applicable, the Contractor must notify the GPMC in advance of the pending movement of the Holiday along with the designated day for observance.
summary: To move a holiday observance date to align with a client's schedule, the contractor is required to notify the GPMC in advance of the change and the new date.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: holiday_harmonization_rule_applies ONLY_IF gpmc_notification_provided == TRUE
reasoning: This rule is a procedural requirement that acts as a gate for changing a scheduled holiday, which directly relates to the correct categorization and scheduling of work time.

name: Harmonization Scope Across Facility
rule_text: The designated day to for observance must be applicable to all contractors and all trades across the entire facility.
summary: If a holiday observance date is moved to align with a client, the new date must apply uniformly to all contractors and trades at that facility.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: IF holiday_harmonization_rule_applies -> new_observed_date APPLIES_TO (all_contractors, all_trades)
reasoning: This rule defines the scope and applicability of a changed work schedule for a statutory holiday, ensuring consistent time categorization across a site.

name: Holiday Observance Posting Deadline
rule_text: Employers will post the date to be observed no later than seven (7) days prior to the holiday.
summary: Employers must provide notice by posting the date a statutory holiday will be observed at least seven days beforehand.
logical_representation: ACTION: post_holiday_observance_date >= 7_days_before_holiday
reasoning: This rule is a scheduling and notification requirement directly related to the administration of special work days, which falls under the management of worked time.

name: Default Observance on Harmonization Failure
rule_text: In the absence of meeting the above and providing proper notification, the holiday will be observed in accordance with the provisions outlined in Article 12.000.
summary: If the specific conditions and notification requirements for moving a holiday date are not met, the holiday will be observed on its standard, default date.
logical_representation: IF harmonization_conditions_met == FALSE -> observed_date = default_holiday_date
reasoning: This rule specifies the fallback for scheduling a special pay day (Statutory Holiday) if other conditions aren't met, making it a rule about how work time is categorized and scheduled.

name: Reporting Time Pay Minimum
rule_text: When an employee reports for work, unless previously advised there is no work available, they shall be entitled to two (2) hours pay at the appropriate day or shift rate.
summary: If an employee shows up for work without being told in advance that there is no work, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay at their standard rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_reports_for_work AND previously_advised_no_work == false -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for reporting to work, which is a core concept of worked time calculation and entitlement.

name: Pay for Extended Waiting or Work Time
rule_text: Should the employee start work or be required to wait at the jobsite, they shall be paid for hours worked or actual waiting time past the two (2) hours minimum.
summary: If an employee starts working or is required to wait at the site, and the total time is more than two hours, they will be paid for all hours worked or waited, superseding the two-hour minimum.
logical_representation: IF (employee_starts_work OR required_to_wait) AND total_hours_on_site > 2 -> PAY(total_hours_on_site)
reasoning: This rule defines how payment is calculated when an employee's time on site, whether working or waiting, exceeds the minimum reporting guarantee. It is a calculation rule for worked time.

name: Daily Travel, Company Transportation
rule_text: On those projects that are located between forty-five (45) radius kilometers to one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from Edmonton and/or Calgary City Hall(s) or other Hiring Hall locations, the Company shall supply suitable transportation to and from the project and mutually agreed to pick-up points.
summary: For projects between 45 and 120 radius kilometers from a city hall or hiring hall, the company must provide transportation for employees.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km >= 45 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km <= 120 -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule outlines an entitlement for company-provided transportation based on project location, which is a form of travel and subsistence support.

name: Daily Travel, Vehicle Allowance
rule_text: Alternatively, the Company shall pay to each employee a vehicle allowance at the rate established by the Canadian Revenue Agency per road kilometer for each day worked or reported for work, from the edge of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone to the project and return.
summary: As an alternative to providing transportation for projects 45-120 km away, the company can pay a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate for the distance traveled beyond the 45 km free zone to the project and back.
logical_representation: IF is_transportation_provided == false -> PAY(distance_from_free_zone_edge_km * 2 * cra_rate_per_km)
reasoning: This rule defines a monetary allowance for travel, which is a core component of subsistence and remote work compensation.

name: Subsistence Amount Updates
rule_text: Subsistence amounts to be cross referenced with any changes made through the CLRA and these amounts will be updated within the Agreement in a timely manner.
summary: Subsistence payment amounts must be kept current by checking for and applying any changes made through the CLRA (Construction Labour Relations - an Alberta Association).
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT subsistence_rate == clra_rate
reasoning: This rule governs how subsistence amounts are determined and updated, directly impacting the monetary living-out entitlement.

name: Subsistence Eligibility
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid or camp provided on projects which are more than one hundred and twenty (120) radius kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary or other Hiring Hall locations.
summary: Employees are entitled to either a subsistence allowance or camp accommodation for projects located more than 120 radius kilometers from a city hall or hiring hall.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 120 -> ALLOWANCE(SUBSISTENCE) OR PROVIDE(CAMP)
reasoning: This is the primary eligibility rule defining the distance threshold for receiving subsistence or camp, a key aspect of living-out allowances.

name: Standard Subsistence Rate
rule_text: Subsistence will be paid at a rate of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per day worked or reported for.
summary: The standard subsistence rate is $150.00 for each day an employee works or reports for work, unless a location-specific rate applies.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_eligible == true AND day_status IN ['WORKED', 'REPORTED'] -> PAY(150)
reasoning: This rule sets the default monetary amount for the daily living-out allowance, which is the definition of a subsistence allowance.

name: Location-Specific Subsistence Rates
rule_text: In the following areas, subsistence will be paid at a rate per day worked or reported for as noted: ... [table of locations and rates]
summary: In certain specified locations such as Fort McMurray ($200), Grande Prairie ($205), and others, a specific, non-standard daily subsistence rate applies for each day worked or reported.
logical_representation: IF project_location == 'Athabasca' -> PAY(170) | IF project_location == 'Fort McMurray' -> PAY(200) | ...
reasoning: This rule provides a list of specific monetary rates for subsistence based on geographic location, directly defining the living-out allowance for those areas.

name: 7-Day Subsistence for Remote Sites
rule_text: On sites which are four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers plus as noted above, subsistence will be paid on a seven (7) day per week basis.
summary: For projects located 475 radius kilometers or more from a designated city hall, subsistence is paid for all seven days of the week, not just on days worked.
logical_representation: IF project_distance_from_city_hall_km >= 475 -> SET_ALLOWANCE_SCHEDULE(7_DAY)
reasoning: This rule defines the continuity and payment schedule (7 days/week) for subsistence on very remote projects, a key parameter of the allowance.

name: Absenteeism and Subsistence Forfeiture
rule_text: Forfeiture of subsistence allowance due to absenteeism may be waived if the reason for absence is acceptable to the Employer.
summary: If an employee is absent, they may lose their subsistence payment for that day; however, this can be waived if the employer accepts the reason for the absence.
logical_representation: IF is_absent == true AND is_reason_for_absence_acceptable == false -> FORFEIT(SUBSISTENCE) | IF is_absent == true AND is_reason_for_absence_acceptable == true -> PAY(SUBSISTENCE)
reasoning: This rule details a condition (absenteeism) under which the subsistence entitlement can be forfeited, directly relating to attendance requirements for the allowance.

name: Additional Subsistence for Travel Day
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees not residing in the area where the project is located will be eligible to receive one additional day of subsistence for either the day before commencing work or the day after completing the work assignment, where the project is greater than two hundred (200) road kilometers from the City Hall(s) of Edmonton and Calgary, or other Hiring Hall locations. This payment will be made for the preceding or succeeding day where substantiated by verifiable proof that accommodation was used (i.e. receipt or registration verification).
summary: For non-local employees on projects over 200 road kilometers away, one extra day of subsistence is paid for either the travel day before starting or the travel day after finishing, provided they can show proof of accommodation (like a receipt).
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == false AND project_road_distance_km > 200 AND has_accommodation_proof == true -> PAY(1_DAY_SUBSISTENCE_EXTRA)
reasoning: This rule grants an additional day of monetary living-out allowance to cover travel time and expenses, which is a specific condition of subsistence pay.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance (120-300km)
rule_text: As of May 4, 2025, Initial and terminal travel which will be paid as follows from the above: | 120-200 Radius Kilometers 200-300 Radius Kilometers | $ 116.00 each way, $ 166.00 each way, |
summary: Effective May 4, 2025, employees receive a fixed travel payment for their initial trip to the job and final trip from the job. The amount is $116 each way for projects 120-200 km away, and $166 each way for projects 200-300 km away.
logical_representation: IF effective_date >= 2025-05-04 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km >= 120 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km <= 200 -> ALLOWANCE(116_EACH_WAY) | IF effective_date >= 2025-05-04 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 200 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km <= 300 -> ALLOWANCE(166_EACH_WAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific monetary allowance for travel to and from a remote worksite, which is a type of subsistence entitlement.

name: Travel Allowance Ineligibility with Client Transport
rule_text: No travel shall be payable under this Article if the Client provides transportation to the work site and return.
summary: If the client provides transportation to and from the worksite, no separate travel allowance will be paid.
logical_representation: IF is_client_transport_provided == true -> FORFEIT(TRAVEL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition under which a monetary travel allowance is forfeited, directly impacting subsistence-related entitlements.

name: Initial and Terminal Travel Allowance (>475km)
rule_text: As of May 4, 2025, on jobs beyond the four hundred and seventy-five (475) radius kilometers initial and terminal travel amounts will be mutually agreed between the Union and the Employer to a maximum of $455.00 each way or airfare if suitable proof of air transport is provided to the Employer.
summary: Effective May 4, 2025, for jobs over 475 radius kilometers away, the initial and terminal travel allowance will be negotiated, up to a maximum of $455 each way. Alternatively, the company will pay for airfare if proof is provided.
logical_representation: IF effective_date >= 2025-05-04 AND project_distance_from_city_hall_km > 475 -> ALLOWANCE(AGREED_AMOUNT) AND MAX(455_EACH_WAY) OR PAY(AIRFARE)
reasoning: This rule defines the travel allowance for very remote projects, including maximums and alternative provisions like airfare, which are components of subsistence and travel compensation.

name: Review of Travel Amounts
rule_text: Initial and terminal travel amounts will be reviewed by the National Maintenance Council should there be general increases or reductions in the reference agreements.
summary: The amounts paid for initial and terminal travel will be reviewed and potentially adjusted if there are changes in the rates specified in other reference agreements.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT travel_allowance_amount F(reference_agreement_rates)
reasoning: This rule specifies the process for updating travel allowance amounts, which is directly related to maintaining the value of this subsistence entitlement.

name: Initial Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Initial travel amounts will be paid after fifteen (15) calendar days on the job or at lay-off.
summary: The payment for the initial trip to the job site is made only after the employee has worked for 15 calendar days, or when they are laid off, whichever comes first.
logical_representation: IF days_on_job >= 15 OR employment_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(INITIAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule dictates the timing and conditions for paying the initial travel allowance, which is a key parameter of this subsistence-related benefit.

name: Terminal Travel Payment Timing
rule_text: Terminal travel will be paid at lay-off.
summary: The travel allowance for the return trip from the job site is paid when the employee is laid off.
logical_representation: IF employment_status == 'LAID_OFF' -> PAY(TERMINAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule specifies when the terminal travel allowance is paid, defining an important aspect of this subsistence benefit.

name: Forfeiture of Travel Pay on Quit or Termination
rule_text: Employees who quit or are terminated for cause prior to the entitlement payment of either initial or terminal amounts are not entitled to any travel payments outstanding.
summary: If an employee quits or is fired for cause before they have qualified for their initial or terminal travel payments, they lose their right to receive those payments.
logical_representation: IF separation_reason IN ['QUIT', 'TERMINATED_FOR_CAUSE'] -> FORFEIT(OUTSTANDING_TRAVEL_PAYMENTS)
reasoning: This rule outlines conditions (quitting or termination) under which an employee forfeits their travel allowance, directly impacting this subsistence entitlement.

name: Local Resident Ineligibility for Subsistence
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees residing in the area where the project is located will not be eligible for Accommodation Allowance and initial/terminal travel
summary: On a project that qualifies for subsistence, employees who already live in the local area are not entitled to receive the accommodation allowance or initial/terminal travel pay.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true -> FORFEIT(ACCOMMODATION_ALLOWANCE) AND FORFEIT(INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule defines an exclusion from subsistence and travel benefits based on the employee's residence status, a core aspect of eligibility for living-out allowances.

name: Local Resident Daily Travel Entitlement
rule_text: but will receive daily travel payments pursuant to Article 14.100 (a) if they reside outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer free zone around the project.
summary: Although local residents on a subsistence project don't get the full accommodation allowance, they are still eligible for daily travel payments if they live more than 45 radius kilometers from the project site.
logical_representation: IF is_local_resident == true AND distance_from_project_km > 45 -> ALLOWANCE(DAILY_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule grants a specific travel allowance to a certain class of employees (local residents) on subsistence projects, making it a rule about subsistence-related travel pay.

name: Daily Travel for Non-Local Employees on Subsistence Projects
rule_text: On a subsistence project, employees domiciled outside a forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job will be provided transportation to and from the job or paid a vehicle allowance at the rate established by the Canadian Revenue Agency.
summary: On a subsistence project, non-local employees living more than 45 km from the job must be given either transportation to the job or a vehicle allowance at the CRA rate.
logical_representation: IF is_subsistence_project == true AND distance_from_project_km > 45 -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION) OR PAY(VEHICLE_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule specifies travel entitlements for non-local workers on subsistence jobs, which is a core component of subsistence and travel policy.

name: Forfeiture of Daily Travel when Choosing Subsistence over Camp
rule_text: Employees who are offered camp accommodation and choose to receive subsistence instead are not entitled to daily travel outside of the forty-five (45) radius kilometer zone around the job.
summary: If an employee is offered camp accommodation but opts to take the subsistence money instead, they lose their entitlement to any daily travel allowance for commuting from outside the 45 km zone.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_offered == true AND employee_choice == 'SUBSISTENCE' -> FORFEIT(DAILY_TRAVEL)
reasoning: This rule describes a condition based on employee choice that leads to the forfeiture of a travel allowance, directly impacting the overall subsistence package.

name: Fort McMurray Local Transportation
rule_text: Ft. McMurray residents or those employees accommodated in Ft. McMurray will be provided with transportation to and from the jobsite by the Employer.
summary: For projects near Fort McMurray, any employees who are residents of or are housed in Fort McMurray must be provided with transportation to and from the jobsite by the employer.
logical_representation: IF employee_residence_or_accommodation_location == 'Ft. McMurray' -> PROVIDE(TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule mandates company-provided transportation for a specific geographic location, which is a form of travel support covered under subsistence allowances.

name: Travel to Fort McMurray from Edmonton
rule_text: Employees travelling to Ft. McMurray from Edmonton will be paid initial and terminal travel pursuant to Article 14.100 b) and provided with camp accommodation or accommodation allowance.
summary: Employees who travel from Edmonton to work in Fort McMurray are entitled to receive initial and terminal travel pay, as well as either camp housing or a monetary accommodation allowance.
logical_representation: IF travel_origin == 'Edmonton' AND travel_destination == 'Ft. McMurray' -> PAY(INITIAL_TERMINAL_TRAVEL) AND (PROVIDE(CAMP) OR ALLOWANCE(ACCOMMODATION))
reasoning: This rule defines the complete subsistence package (travel pay and living allowance/camp) for a specific travel route, making it a clear subsistence allowance rule.

name: Standard Work Day, 8-Hour Schedule
rule_text: Eight (8) hours per day shall constitute a day's work
summary: A standard workday consists of eight hours.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT standard_work_day_hours == 8
reasoning: This rule defines the standard duration of a workday, which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

name: Standard Work Week, 5x8 Schedule
rule_text: forty (40) hours per week, Monday to Friday inclusive, shall constitute a week's work.
summary: A standard work week is forty hours, from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT standard_work_week_hours == 40 AND standard_work_week_days == [MONDAY, TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY, THURSDAY, FRIDAY]
reasoning: This rule defines the standard duration and days of a workweek, which is a core component for calculating weekly hours and overtime.

name: Regular Start and Quit Times, 8-Hour Schedule
rule_text: The regular starting time shall be eight (8) o'clock a.m., and the regular quitting time shall be four-thirty (4:30) o'clock p.m.
summary: For an 8-hour day, the regular start time is 8:00 a.m. and the regular quit time is 4:30 p.m.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT regular_start_time == '08:00' AND regular_quitting_time == '16:30'
reasoning: This rule establishes the specific hours for a standard shift, which is essential for defining shift boundaries and calculating deviations.

name: Staggered Start Times
rule_text: Start times may be staggered two (2) hours between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. as job conditions warrant.
summary: Depending on job needs, start times can be adjusted to any time between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.
logical_representation: IF job_conditions_warrant -> ALLOW_ACTION(stagger_start_time BETWEEN '07:00' AND '09:00')
reasoning: This rule provides flexibility in scheduling work hours, directly impacting how a workday is defined and tracked.

name: Optional 4x10 Work Week
rule_text: As an option, ten (10) hours per day, Monday to Thursday or Tuesday to Friday may be worked at straight time.
summary: An optional compressed work week of four 10-hour days (either Monday-Thursday or Tuesday-Friday) can be worked at straight time.
logical_representation: ALLOW_OPTION schedule_type == '4x10' AND daily_hours == 10 AND schedule_days IN ([MON,TUE,WED,THU], [TUE,WED,THU,FRI]) -> PAY(ST)
reasoning: This rule defines an alternative regular work schedule, which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time and calculating overtime.

name: 4x10 Schedule Establishment Period
rule_text: The ten (10) hour system must operate for a minimum period of four (4) consecutive days before it is established as the regular hours of work.
summary: To make the four-day, 10-hour work week the official schedule, it must be worked for at least four consecutive days.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND duration >= 4_consecutive_days -> SET_STATUS(regular_hours_of_work)
reasoning: This rule sets the condition for when an alternative work schedule becomes the standard, impacting how hours are categorized.

name: 4x10 Schedule Regular Hours
rule_text: Once established it becomes the regular hours of work for those so assigned.
summary: Once the four-day, 10-hour schedule is established, it is considered the regular hours of work for the assigned employees.
logical_representation: IF schedule_is_established == TRUE -> a_work_day == 10_hours
reasoning: This rule solidifies the definition of 'regular hours' under the compressed work week, which is crucial for overtime calculations.

name: 4x10 Schedule Union Notification
rule_text: When establishing a four (4) day ten (10) hour work week, the Employer will advise the affected Local Union office that a four (4) day ten (10) hour option is in place and declare if it is a Monday to Thursday, or Tuesday to Friday work pattern.
summary: When implementing a 4x10 work week, the employer must inform the local union office and specify whether it runs Monday-Thursday or Tuesday-Friday.
logical_representation: IF establishing_schedule == '4x10' -> NOTIFY(local_union) AND DECLARE(work_pattern)
reasoning: This rule outlines a procedural requirement for changing work schedules, which are central to defining and categorizing work time.

name: Short Term Work on 4x10 Project
rule_text: Where a multi trade project is scheduled under the four (4) ten (10) hour shift system and an Employer secures short term work that may not provide for forty (40) hours of work, all hours worked shall be paid for in keeping with the provisions applicable to the four (4) ten (10) hour shift.
summary: If a project is on a 4x10 schedule and an employer gets short-term work that is less than 40 hours, those hours are still paid according to the 4x10 overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF project_schedule == '4x10' AND work_type == 'short_term' AND weekly_hours < 40 -> APPLY_PAY_RULES('4x10')
reasoning: This rule specifies which pay calculation rules to apply under a specific scenario (short term work on a 4x10 project), directly affecting how hours are categorized and paid.

name: 10-Hour Shift Paid Breaks Option
rule_text: When ten (10) hour shifts are worked, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two breaks of one half (½) hour each, paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On 10-hour shifts, the employer can choose to provide two paid 30-minute breaks instead of the standard breaks, spaced evenly throughout the shift.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours == 10 -> ALLOW_OPTION(PROVIDE(2_breaks, 30_minutes_each, 'paid'))
reasoning: This rule defines break entitlements and their paid status during a specific work schedule, which is a component of how worked time is structured and compensated.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Straight Time Day
rule_text: On a straight time, day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes paid at the time and one-half rate.
summary: If an employee cannot take their break on a regular straight-time day, they must be paid for an extra 30 minutes at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF break_missed == TRUE AND day_type == 'straight_time' -> PAY(30_minutes * 1.5)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific pay calculation (premium pay) as a penalty for a missed entitlement, directly related to compensation for time.

name: Missed Break Penalty, Overtime Day
rule_text: On an overtime day, the employee will be compensated an additional thirty (30) minutes at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If an employee cannot take their break on an overtime day, they must be paid for an extra 30 minutes at the day's applicable overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF break_missed == TRUE AND day_type == 'overtime' -> PAY(30_minutes * applicable_overtime_rate)
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium pay calculation as a penalty, which falls under the categorization and compensation of worked time.

name: Staggering Paid Breaks
rule_text: Under schedules utilizing a half (½) hour (paid break) system, they may be staggered one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies.
summary: Paid 30-minute breaks can be moved up to one hour earlier or later to meet production or emergency needs.
logical_representation: IF break_type == 'paid_half_hour' -> ALLOW_ACTION(stagger_break, MAX(1_hour))
reasoning: This rule governs the scheduling of paid breaks within the workday, which is an element of managing and defining the structure of work hours.

name: Penalty for Excessive Break Staggering
rule_text: The above penalty clauses outlined in 15.100(i) a) and b) will apply in instances when the staggered one half (½) hour (paid break) is moved greater than one (1) hour either way to accommodate production schedules and emergencies.
summary: If a paid 30-minute break is moved by more than one hour, the missed break penalties (extra pay) will apply.
logical_representation: IF break_stagger_duration > 1_hour -> APPLY_PENALTY('15.100(i)a_and_b')
reasoning: This rule triggers a specific pay calculation (a penalty) based on how work time is scheduled, making it a rule about time compensation.

name: Day Shift Definition
rule_text: Employees working a day shift defined as a shift starting at 8:00 a.m. shall work eight (8) hours for eight (8) hours pay.
summary: A day shift is defined as starting at 8:00 a.m. and consists of eight hours of work for eight hours of pay.
logical_representation: IF shift_start_time == '08:00' -> shift_type == 'day_shift' AND shift_duration == 8 AND shift_paid_hours == 8
reasoning: This rule provides a specific definition for a type of work shift, which is fundamental to categorizing hours and applying correct pay rates.

name: No Guarantee of Work
rule_text: The Company does not guarantee to provide work to any employee for regularly assigned hours, except as provided in 13.000.
summary: The company does not promise to provide work for all regularly scheduled hours, unless specified elsewhere (in Article 13.000).
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT work_guarantee == FALSE UNLESS specified_in('13.000')
reasoning: This rule sets an expectation about the availability of work hours and pay, establishing a condition related to minimum time guarantees.

name: Shift Premium
rule_text: Employees working any shift that is outside of daywork conditions, shall receive a shift premium of four dollars and fifty cents ($4.50) per hour worked.
summary: Employees working any shift other than a standard day shift will receive an extra $4.50 for each hour worked.
logical_representation: IF shift_type != 'daywork' -> PREMIUM($4.50/hour)
reasoning: This rule specifies an additional payment based on the time of day work is performed, which is a key aspect of how worked time is compensated.

name: Unpaid Lunch Break
rule_text: The mid-shift lunch break will be of one half (1/2) hour in duration and will be unpaid.
summary: There is a 30-minute unpaid lunch break in the middle of a shift.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT lunch_break_duration == 30_minutes AND lunch_break_pay_status == 'unpaid'
reasoning: This rule defines the status of a specific block of time within a shift (unpaid), which is essential for calculating total paid hours.

name: Short Notice Shift Change Penalty
rule_text: If eight (8) hours notice is not provided then all regular hours worked on the first shift on the new schedule will be paid at time and one-half the straight time total package rate (1-1/2).
summary: If an employee's shift is changed with less than eight hours' notice, all regular hours on their first new shift will be paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF shift_change_notice < 8_hours -> PAY(first_shift_regular_hours * 1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium pay rate triggered by a scheduling condition, directly impacting how worked time is compensated.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Weekday ST
rule_text:
Monday | 8 hours
Tuesday | 8 hours
Wednesday | 8 hours
Thursday | 8 hours
Friday | 8 hours
summary: On a 5x8 schedule, the first 8 hours worked from Monday to Friday are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU,FRI] AND daily_hours <= 8 -> PAY(ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the straight time threshold for a standard work week, which is the basis for all overtime calculations.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Weekday OT
rule_text:
Monday | Up to 2 hours
Tuesday | Up to 2 hours
Wednesday | Up to 2 hours
Thursday | Up to 2 hours
Friday | Up to 2 hours
summary: On a 5x8 schedule, the first 2 hours worked after 8 hours from Monday to Friday are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU,FRI] AND daily_hours > 8 AND daily_hours <= 10 -> TRANSITION(OT, 1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines the first tier of overtime pay for a standard work week, specifying the rate and hours.

name: Overtime, 5x8 Schedule, Weekday DT
rule_text:
Monday | After 10 hours
Tuesday | After 10 hours
Wednesday | After 10 hours
Thursday | After 10 hours
Friday | After 10 hours
summary: On a 5x8 schedule, any hours worked after 10 hours from Monday to Friday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '5x8' AND day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU,FRI] AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime pay for a standard work week, specifying the rate and threshold.

name: Overtime, All Schedules, Weekend & Holiday DT
rule_text:
Saturday | All hours
Sunday | All hours
Stat Holiday | All hours
summary: All hours worked on a Saturday, Sunday, or Statutory Holiday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_of_week IN [SAT, SUN] OR day_type == 'stat_holiday' -> PAY(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for special days (weekends, holidays), which is a key component of categorizing worked time.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Weekday ST
rule_text:
Monday | 10 hours
Tuesday | 10 hours
Wednesday | 10 hours
Thursday | 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked from Monday to Thursday are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU] AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the straight time threshold for a compressed work week, which is the basis for overtime calculations on this schedule.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Weekday DT
rule_text:
Monday | After 10 hours
Tuesday | After 10 hours
Wednesday | After 10 hours
Thursday | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, any hours worked after 10 hours from Monday to Thursday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week IN [MON,TUE,WED,THU] AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the overtime pay rate and threshold for regular workdays on a compressed work week schedule.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Friday OT
rule_text: Friday | Up to 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Friday are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == FRI AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(OT, 1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for the first scheduled day off in a compressed work week, a key part of the overtime structure.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Mon-Thu Schedule, Friday DT
rule_text: Friday | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Monday-Thursday schedule, any hours worked after 10 hours on a Friday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_mon_thu' AND day_of_week == FRI AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime for a scheduled day off in a compressed work week.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Monday OT
rule_text: Monday | Up to 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked on a Monday are paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week == MON AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(OT, 1.5)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for the first scheduled day off in a compressed work week, a key part of the overtime structure.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Monday DT
rule_text: Monday | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, any hours worked after 10 hours on a Monday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week == MON AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the second tier of overtime for a scheduled day off in a compressed work week.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Weekday ST
rule_text:
Tuesday | 10 hours
Wednesday | 10 hours
Thursday | 10 hours
Friday | 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, the first 10 hours worked from Tuesday to Friday are paid at straight time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week IN [TUE,WED,THU,FRI] AND daily_hours <= 10 -> PAY(ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the straight time threshold for a compressed work week, which is the basis for overtime calculations on this schedule.

name: Overtime, 4x10 Tue-Fri Schedule, Weekday DT
rule_text:
Tuesday | After 10 hours
Wednesday | After 10 hours
Thursday | After 10 hours
Friday | After 10 hours
summary: On a 4x10 Tuesday-Friday schedule, any hours worked after 10 hours from Tuesday to Friday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10_tue_fri' AND day_of_week IN [TUE,WED,THU,FRI] AND daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the overtime pay rate and threshold for regular workdays on a compressed work week schedule.

name: Punctuality Requirement
rule_text: Employees shall be at their posts prepared to start work at the regular starting time.
summary: Employees must be at their work station and ready to begin working at their scheduled start time.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT employee_is_at_post_at_start_time == TRUE
reasoning: This rule sets an obligation related to the start of worked time, defining when the paid period begins.

name: Mutual Agreement for Shift Time Changes
rule_text: Outside of the limits established in Article 16.100, by mutual consent of the Company and the Council, the starting and quitting times of any shift, including day work, may be changed for all or any portion of a particular job.
summary: The start and end times of any shift can be changed for a job if both the company and the union council agree to it.
logical_representation: IF mutual_consent('Company', 'Council') -> ALLOW_ACTION(change_shift_times)
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism for altering work schedules, which directly impacts how work time is defined and tracked.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement, Regular Shift
rule_text: When an employee works beyond ten (10) hours per day they shall be entitled to a meal break and a meal supplied by the Company.
summary: An employee who works more than 10 hours in a day is entitled to a meal and a meal break, provided by the company.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> ENTITLEMENT('meal_break') AND PROVIDE('meal')
reasoning: This rule explicitly defines the conditions under which an employee is entitled to a meal or meal-related benefit due to extended work hours.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement, Subsequent Breaks
