rule_text: The meal break will be provided after ten (10) hours of work and subsequent meal breaks each four (4) hours thereafter.
summary: The first meal break is given after 10 hours of work, with additional meal breaks provided every four hours after that.
logical_representation: IF hours_worked > 10 -> MEAL_TRIG(1) AND IF subsequent_hours_worked % 4 == 0 -> MEAL_TRIG(NEXT)
reasoning: This rule sets the triggers and frequency for meal entitlements, which is a core function of the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: 4x10 Schedule Overtime Meal Exception
rule_text: When the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is worked, recognizing emergency situations will arise, if the Company has not scheduled in excess of the ten (10) hour shift, the Company shall be granted a one (1) hour extension where a meal and meal break are not required.
summary: On a 4x10 schedule, if overtime was not pre-scheduled, the company has a one-hour grace period (up to 11 hours total) before a meal and break are required.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND overtime_scheduled == FALSE -> meal_break_trigger_hours == 11
reasoning: This rule provides a specific exception to a meal entitlement rule based on the work schedule, directly modifying the conditions for a meal allowance.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement, Scheduled Overtime
rule_text: When an employee works Scheduled Overtime (work performed on Saturdays, Sundays and Holidays they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds ten (10) hours.
summary: During scheduled overtime on weekends or holidays, an employee is entitled to a meal break after working more than 10 hours.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'scheduled' AND hours_worked > 10 -> ENTITLEMENT('meal_break')
reasoning: This rule specifies the meal entitlement trigger for a particular type of overtime, clearly falling under the meal allowance topic.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement, Emergency Call-Out
rule_text: When an employee works Short Notice Emergency Call-Out Overtime (overtime work performed other than continuous with the regular work day or Scheduled Overtime) they shall be entitled to a meal break when overtime work exceeds four (4) hours.
summary: For emergency call-out overtime that is not continuous with a regular shift, an employee gets a meal break after working more than four hours.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'emergency_call_out' AND hours_worked > 4 -> ENTITLEMENT('meal_break')
reasoning: This rule defines a specific meal entitlement trigger based on the type of work (call-out), which is a key aspect of meal allowance rules.

name: No Meal Entitlement at Conclusion of Overtime
rule_text: No entitlement shall occur at the conclusion of overtime.
summary: An employee does not get a meal break right when their overtime work ends.
logical_representation: IF event == 'conclusion_of_overtime' -> FORFEIT('meal_break')
reasoning: This rule places a specific constraint on meal entitlements, making it a rule about the conditions for receiving a meal allowance.

name: Overtime Meal Break Duration and Pay
rule_text: All overtime meal breaks will be thirty (30) minutes in duration and will be paid for at straight time rates.
summary: All meal breaks during overtime are 30 minutes long and are paid at the employee's straight-time rate.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT overtime_meal_break_duration == 30_minutes AND overtime_meal_break_pay_rate == 'ST'
reasoning: This rule defines the duration and pay rate for an overtime meal break. While it primarily concerns the meal benefit, the pay rate aspect links it to how time is compensated, however the primary topic is the meal benefit itself.

name: Overtime Meal Break Calculation Exclusion
rule_text: However, in calculating entitlement to a meal, the thirty (30) minute break shall not count as overtime work.
summary: The 30-minute paid meal break does not count as time worked when determining eligibility for subsequent meal breaks.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT EXCLUDE_FROM_CALCULATION(meal_break_time) FOR meal_entitlement_trigger
reasoning: This rule is a calculation modifier specifically for meal entitlements, making it a core rule within the meal allowance topic.

name: Foreperson Meal Break Exception
rule_text: When a foreperson is required to: 1) Start up to one (1) hour earlier, or 2) Finish up to one (1) hour later, or 3) Start up to one-half (1/2) hour earlier and finish up to one-half (1/2) hour later than the foreperson's crews, for the purposes of organizing work, obtaining permits or facilitating a transition to another shift, the foreperson shall not be entitled to a meal or meal break as per Clause 16.600 unless those provisions are applicable to the rest of the crew.
summary: A foreperson who works up to an extra hour before or after their crew for prep work is not entitled to an overtime meal unless the rest of the crew is also entitled.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'foreperson' AND extra_work_duration <= 1_hour AND crew_meal_entitlement == FALSE -> FORFEIT('meal_break')
reasoning: This rule sets a specific condition of ineligibility for a meal entitlement based on job role and circumstance, classifying it under meal allowances.

name: Preparatory Work Meal Break Exception
rule_text: This shall also apply to those Employees who are required to arrive at work earlier than their crew on a continual basis to execute work of a preparatory nature for the impending shift. This article will not be applicable to 'one-off' work assignments.
summary: The meal break exception for working extra hours also applies to any employee who regularly comes in early for prep work, but not for occasional, one-time instances.
logical_representation: IF work_nature == 'preparatory' AND work_frequency == 'continual' -> APPLY_RULE('15.601_foreperson_exception')
reasoning: This rule extends a meal allowance exception to a broader group of employees under specific conditions, keeping it within the meal allowance topic.

name: Scheduled Overtime Meal Allowance in Lieu
rule_text: a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay.
summary: For scheduled overtime, if a meal cannot be provided, the employee receives 30 minutes of straight-time pay and a 15-minute paid rest break instead.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'scheduled' AND meal_provided == FALSE -> PAY(30_minutes_ST) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule specifies the monetary and time-based compensation provided when a meal entitlement is not fulfilled, which is a direct component of meal allowance policies.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Meal Allowance in Lieu
rule_text: a payment of forty dollars ($40.00) as a meal allowance. a payment of thirty (30) minutes at the straight time total package hourly rate in lieu of the meal break: and a fifteen (15) minute rest break at the applicable rate of pay
summary: For unscheduled overtime, if a meal cannot be provided, the employee receives a $40 meal allowance, 30 minutes of straight-time pay, and a 15-minute paid rest break.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == 'unscheduled' AND meal_provided == FALSE -> MEAL_AMT($40.00) AND PAY(30_minutes_ST) AND PROVIDE(15_minute_paid_break)
reasoning: This rule details the specific monetary payment and other benefits given in place of a meal for unscheduled overtime, clearly defining it as a meal allowance rule.

name: Meal Allowance and Subsistence
rule_text: There shall be no meal allowance applicable to those receiving subsistence, however any reduction to the current subsistence rates will attract a meal allowance payment equivalent to the reduction.
summary: Employees receiving a subsistence (living-out) allowance are not eligible for an overtime meal allowance, unless their subsistence rate is cut, in which case they get a meal allowance equal to the reduction amount.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_subsistence == TRUE -> FORFEIT('meal_allowance') UNLESS IF subsistence_rate_reduction > 0 -> MEAL_AMT(subsistence_rate_reduction)
reasoning: This rule directly governs eligibility for a meal allowance based on the condition of receiving subsistence, making the meal allowance the primary topic.

name: Meal Allowance and Camp Accommodations
rule_text: Where a camp is provided, employees will not receive the forty dollars ($40.00) meal allowance where they are able to receive a camp meal at the end of their shift.
summary: Employees staying in a camp will not receive the $40 overtime meal allowance if they can get a meal at the camp after their shift.
logical_representation: IF camp_is_provided == TRUE AND camp_meal_is_available == TRUE -> FORFEIT(MEAL_AMT($40.00))
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition (availability of a camp meal) that negates the entitlement to a monetary meal allowance, placing it firmly in the meal allowance category.

name: Call Out Pay Minimum
rule_text: Employees called out between regular shifts will be entitled to a minimum of two (2) hours pay at double (2x) the straight time total package hourly rate.
summary: If an employee is called out to work between their regular shifts, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay at double time.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'call_out' -> MIN_PAY(2_hours * 2.0)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for a specific type of work, which is a fundamental aspect of how worked time is compensated.

name: Call Out Pay After Minimum
rule_text: All hours worked beyond the minimum two (2) hour threshold will be paid at double (2x) the straight time total package hourly rate.
summary: On a call-out, any time worked beyond the initial two-hour minimum is also paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'call_out' AND hours_worked > 2 -> PAY(DT, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for hours worked during a call-out, directly relating to the categorization and compensation of time.

name: Maximum Daily Hours and Rest Period
rule_text: It is not intended that an employee shall work more than sixteen (16) hours in any given twenty-four (24) hour period therefore it is established that the employee must have eight (8) continuous hours off between regular shifts
summary: Employees generally should not work more than 16 hours in a 24-hour period and must have at least 8 consecutive hours off between shifts.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT MAX_HOURS(16 in 24h_period) AND MIN_REST(8_continuous_hours between_shifts)
reasoning: This rule sets constraints on the duration and scheduling of work hours, which is a fundamental aspect of managing and defining worked time.

name: Penalty for Insufficient Rest Period
rule_text: or they will be paid overtime rates for all hours worked in excess of the first eight (8) until such times as they have eight (8) continuous hours off.
summary: If an employee does not get 8 continuous hours off between shifts, any hours they work beyond the first 8 of their new shift will be paid at overtime rates until they get the required break.
logical_representation: IF rest_period < 8_hours -> PAY(OT) FOR all_hours AFTER(8) UNTIL rest_period_taken
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium pay condition triggered by a lack of rest, directly tying scheduling to pay rate calculations.

name: No Pay Loss for Required Rest
rule_text: It is the intent of this clause that no employee shall lose pay on a normal shift due to taking the required eight (8) hour break rule.
summary: An employee will not lose pay from their normal shift if it is shortened because they had to take their mandatory 8-hour break.
logical_representation: IF taking_required_rest_break -> CONSTRAINT no_loss_of_normal_shift_pay
reasoning: This rule protects an employee's regular pay under a specific scheduling circumstance, making it a rule about time and compensation.

name: Indoctrination Time Exclusion
rule_text: Time spent in site indoctrination sessions will not be counted as hours of work for the purposes of calculation of the sixteen (16) or eight (8) hours as noted above except when indoctrination is included as part of the regular work day.
summary: Time spent in site safety orientations does not count towards the 16-hour work limit or the 8-hour rest requirement, unless the orientation is part of the regular paid workday.
logical_representation: IF activity_type == 'indoctrination' AND is_part_of_workday == FALSE -> EXCLUDE_FROM_CALCULATION('16_hour_limit', '8_hour_rest')
reasoning: This rule clarifies what activities are considered 'hours of work' for calculation purposes, which is a core function of categorizing time.

name: Turnaround 12-Hour Shift Option
rule_text: Employers may implement a twelve (12) hour shift with three (3) half hour paid breaks for turnaround activities within the province of Alberta.
summary: For turnaround projects in Alberta, employers can use a 12-hour shift schedule that includes three paid 30-minute breaks.
logical_representation: IF activity_type == 'turnaround' AND location == 'Alberta' -> ALLOW_OPTION(schedule_shift(12_hours, 3_paid_half_hour_breaks))
reasoning: This rule defines a special work schedule, including its duration and break structure, which is fundamental to defining and categorizing work time.

name: Turnaround 12-Hour Shift Pay, 4x10 Basis
rule_text: 4 x 10 Monday to Thursday or Tuesday to Friday: 10 hours @ straight time, 2 hours @ doubletime (2x)
summary: For a 12-hour turnaround shift based on a 4x10 schedule, pay is calculated as 10 hours at straight time and 2 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == '12h_turnaround' AND schedule_basis == '4x10' -> PAY(10_hours_ST) AND PAY(2_hours_DT)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific pay calculation formula for a special shift type, directly governing how worked time is categorized and compensated.

name: Turnaround 12-Hour Shift Pay, 5x8 Basis
rule_text: 5 x 8 Monday to Friday: 8 hours @ straight time, 2 hours at time and one half (1 ½), 2 hours at doubletime (2x)
summary: For a 12-hour turnaround shift based on a 5x8 schedule, pay is calculated as 8 hours at straight time, 2 hours at time and a half, and 2 hours at double time.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == '12h_turnaround' AND schedule_basis == '5x8' -> PAY(8_hours_ST) AND PAY(2_hours_OT) AND PAY(2_hours_DT)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific pay calculation formula for a special shift type, directly governing how worked time is categorized and compensated.

name: Employer Online Orientation Pay
rule_text: If  an  employer  requires  an  employee  to  complete  online  orientation  and  on-boarding,  where applicable,  the  Employer  shall  estimate  a  reasonable  amount  of  time  to  complete  the  online orientation and on-boarding where applicable. The Employer shall pay an allowance for completing the course(s)  equal  to  that  time  estimate,  to  a  maximum  of  eight  (8)  hours,  at  the  straight  time  total package hourly rate.
summary: Employees must be paid for required employer online orientation. Payment is based on the employer's reasonable time estimate for the course, up to a maximum of 8 hours, at the straight-time total package rate.
logical_representation: IF is_employer_orientation_required == true -> PAY(MIN(estimated_completion_time_hours, 8), straight_time_total_package_rate)
reasoning: The rule mandates payment for time spent on a required, work-related activity (orientation), which is a form of worked time entitlement. It specifies the rate and a maximum duration for this compensation.

name: Client Online Orientation Pay
rule_text: Employees will be compensated for the prescribed amount of time, at the straight time total package hourly rate, for completing any Owner / Client online orientation, onboarding or basic training courses required of an employee.
summary: Employees are entitled to payment for the time it takes to complete any required online orientation or training mandated by the owner or client. This time is paid at the straight-time total package hourly rate.
logical_representation: IF is_client_orientation_required == true -> PAY(prescribed_completion_time_hours, straight_time_total_package_rate)
reasoning: This rule establishes that time spent on mandatory client-required training is compensable, treating it as worked time. It defines how this time should be paid, making it a worked time rule.

name: Orientation Pay for Cancelled Job
rule_text: When a job call is cancelled, and employees at the direction of the Employer have completed the required  course(s),  this  Article  shall  apply  and  those  affected  shall  be  compensated.
summary: If an employee completes the required orientation courses at the employer's request and the job is subsequently cancelled, the employee must still be paid for the time spent on the courses.
logical_representation: IF is_job_call_cancelled == true AND has_employee_completed_courses == true -> PAY(orientation_time)
reasoning: This rule guarantees payment for time invested in a mandatory prerequisite for a job, even if the job itself does not materialize. It's a condition for a minimum payment guarantee, falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Forfeiture of Orientation Pay for No-Show
rule_text: Alternatively, compensation will not be provided to employees who complete the required course(s) but fail to report for duty.
summary: An employee who completes the required orientation courses but then fails to show up for work will not be paid for the orientation time.
logical_representation: IF has_employee_completed_courses == true AND did_employee_fail_to_report == true -> FORFEIT(orientation_pay)
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition under which a worked time entitlement (orientation pay) is forfeited. It directly modifies the conditions for payment, making it part of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Payment for Camp Move on Transfer
rule_text: should an employee be required to move from one camp to another, they will be entitled to a payment of two (2) hours at the straight time rate should this occur outside of regular scheduled work hours
summary: If an employee is transferred and required to move between camps outside of their regular work hours, they must be paid for two hours at the straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF is_transfer_required == true AND is_camp_move_required == true AND is_move_outside_work_hours == true -> PAY(2, ST)
reasoning: The rule provides a specific payment for a work-related task (moving camp) performed outside of normal working hours. This is a form of compensation for time spent on employer-directed activities, fitting the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Show-Up Pay for Cancelled Dispatch
rule_text: When personnel requests are cancelled by the Employer after employees have been dispatched by their  respective  Union,  the  Union  and  the  Employer  agree  to  make  every  attempt  to  contact  the affected employees. Employees who cannot be contacted will receive eight (8) hours pay at the straight time  total  package  hourly  rate  for  reporting  for  work,  and  must  be,  at  the  Company's  discretion, prepared to remain on the job.
summary: If a job is cancelled after an employee has been dispatched, and the employee cannot be contacted, they are entitled to 8 hours of pay at the straight-time total package rate upon reporting for work. The company may require them to remain on the job.
logical_representation: IF is_dispatch_cancelled == true AND was_employee_dispatched == true AND was_employee_contacted == false AND did_employee_report_to_work == true -> MIN(8_hours_ST_total_package_rate)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum payment guarantee (show-up pay) for an employee who reports for a shift that has been cancelled without their knowledge. Minimum guarantees are a core component of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Show-Up Pay Exclusion for Local Hires
rule_text: This provision does not apply to local hires.
summary: The rule providing 8 hours of show-up pay for cancelled dispatches does not apply to employees who are classified as local hires.
logical_representation: IF is_local_hire == true -> FORFEIT(cancelled_dispatch_show_up_pay)
reasoning: This rule defines an eligibility exclusion for the show-up pay entitlement. As it directly modifies a condition of a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule, it falls under the same topic.

name: Payment for Room or Camp Move
rule_text: Should an employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the Clients' designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, they are to do it during work hours and will be paid at appropriate rates or the employee shall be paid two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rate to carry out the move, if done outside work hours.
summary: If an employee in a camp is required to move rooms or to another camp, the move should be done during paid work hours. If the move is done outside of work hours, the employee must be paid for two hours at the straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF is_room_or_camp_move_required == true AND is_move_outside_work_hours == true -> PAY(2, ST)
reasoning: This rule mandates compensation for an employer-directed task. When the task occurs outside of regular work hours, it triggers a specific payment, which is an entitlement related to worked time.

name: Exclusion for Room Move Pay
rule_text: This provision will not apply where employees are required to pack their room at the end of a work cycle or to facilitate a move that will occur during the employees furlough.
summary: The payment for moving rooms does not apply if the employee is packing up at the end of their work shift cycle or if the move is set to take place during their scheduled time off (furlough).
logical_representation: IF move_reason IN ('end_of_cycle_pack_up', 'move_during_furlough') -> FORFEIT(room_move_pay)
reasoning: This clause specifies conditions under which the room move payment entitlement is not applicable. As it defines the boundaries of a worked time payment rule, it falls under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Compressed Work Week Daily Schedule
rule_text: The  parties  to  this  Agreement  agree  that  the  maximum  of  nine  (9)  hours  shall constitute  a  normal  days  work  beginning  at  7:30  a.m.  and  ending  at  5:00  p.m. (excluding a one-half hour (1/2) lunch break) may be utilized if restricted to Long Term Base Crew Employees.
summary: For Long Term Base Crew employees on a Compressed Work Week, a normal workday is nine hours, from 7:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., with a 30-minute unpaid lunch.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW AND schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> DEFINE(daily_schedule: 9_hours_work, 0.5_hour_unpaid_lunch, 0730_to_1700)
reasoning: This rule defines the standard hours of work for a specific schedule and employee type, which is a core component of classifying worked time.

name: Compressed Work Week Weekly Schedule
rule_text: the maximum normal work week shall be forty-five (45) hours beginning Monday at 7:30 a.m. and ending Friday at 5:00 p.m.
summary: For employees on the Compressed Work Week, the normal work week is a maximum of 45 hours, running from Monday morning to Friday evening.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> DEFINE(weekly_schedule: MAX(45)_hours, MON_0730_to_FRI_1700)
reasoning: This rule establishes the weekly hour threshold for straight time under the compressed schedule, which is fundamental to calculating overtime.

name: Earned Days Off (EDO) Entitlement
rule_text: this work schedule is utilized to compensate the Employees for hours lost during the twenty-six (26) yearly earned days off (EDO's)
summary: Employees on the compressed work schedule are entitled to 26 Earned Days Off (EDOs) per year.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW -> ENTITLEMENT(26_EDO_per_year)
reasoning: This rule defines an entitlement to paid days off, which is a form of labor time management and compensation.

name: EDO Scheduling
rule_text: Of the twenty-six (26) EDO's, eighteen (18) will be scheduled by Suncor and the remaining eight (8) will be designated as flex EDO's to be taken as mutually agreed between the employee and the supervisor.
summary: Of the 26 annual EDOs, 18 are scheduled by the company (Suncor), and the remaining 8 are flexible EDOs to be scheduled by mutual agreement.
logical_representation: IF entitlement == EDO -> DEFINE(18_EDO_scheduled_by_company) AND DEFINE(8_flex_EDO_mutually_agreed)
reasoning: This rule governs how time off (EDOs) is scheduled, which is directly related to defining the work schedule and when an employee is expected to work.

name: Long Term Base Crew Definition
rule_text: It is understood that when an employee is hired with the intentions of an employment term of more than a six (6) week period, that employee will be automatically on the aforementioned Compressed Work Week arrangements and be considered as a Long Term Base Crew Employee.
summary: An employee hired for a term longer than six weeks is automatically considered a Long Term Base Crew Employee and placed on the Compressed Work Week schedule.
logical_representation: IF intended_employment_term > 6_weeks -> CLASSIFY(employee_type, LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW) AND ASSIGN(schedule_type, COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule defines the eligibility criteria for a specific work schedule and pay structure, which is a prerequisite for applying worked time rules.

name: Early Termination Pay Adjustment
rule_text: Should an employee be terminated prior to working six (6) weeks, an adjustment shall be made in accordance with the terms of Clause b).
summary: If an employee on the compressed work week is terminated before working six weeks, their pay will be recalculated as if they were a short-term employee, likely resulting in back-payment of overtime for the 9th hour worked each day.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW AND employment_term < 6_weeks AND status == TERMINATED -> TRIGGER(payment_adjustment_as_per_clause_b)
reasoning: This rule dictates a retroactive pay calculation based on length of service, directly affecting how hours are compensated upon termination.

name: Short-Term Employment Overtime
rule_text: It  is  understood  that  when  employees  are  hired  with  the  intentions  of  short-term employment (defined as less than six (6) weeks from the date of hire) that they will be paid in the following manner. During this six (6) week period, employees will be paid time and one-half (1 1/2) for the ninth (9th) hour.
summary: Employees hired for short-term work (less than six weeks) are paid time and a half for the ninth hour worked in a day.
logical_representation: IF employment_intent == SHORT_TERM (< 6_weeks) AND daily_hours > 8 AND daily_hours <= 9 -> PAY(1.5x) FOR hour_9
reasoning: This is a classic overtime rule, defining a specific condition (short-term employment) under which hours are paid at a premium rate.

name: Transition to Long Term Crew Status
rule_text: Should the employee be employed onsite after six (6) weeks on the job, that employee will then be considered part of the Long Term Crew and paid in accordance with the Compressed Work Week payment terms (except as outlined in item (e) below).
summary: If a short-term employee works for more than six weeks, they are reclassified as part of the Long Term Crew and will be paid according to the Compressed Work Week rules from that point on.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == SHORT_TERM AND employment_term > 6_weeks -> RECLASSIFY(employee_type, LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW) AND APPLY(compressed_work_week_payment_terms)
reasoning: This rule defines a change in employee status based on time worked, which in turn changes the applicable pay and schedule rules.

name: Overtime on Scheduled EDOs
rule_text: Overtime  payments  for  work  on  the  scheduled  eighteen  (18)  days  off  will  be  at doubletime (2x).
summary: Work performed on one of the 18 company-scheduled Earned Days Off (EDOs) will be paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_type == SCHEDULED_EDO AND work_performed == TRUE -> PAY(2x)
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium pay rate for working on a specific type of scheduled day off, which is a core overtime and worked time classification rule.

name: Overtime on Flex EDOs (Short Notice)
rule_text: If an employee is asked to work their scheduled flex day off without being given forty-eight (48) hours notice, then the employee will be paid overtime at doubletime (2x).
summary: If an employee is required to work on their scheduled flexible EDO with less than 48 hours' notice, they must be paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF day_type == FLEX_EDO AND work_requested == TRUE AND notice_period < 48_hours -> PAY(2x)
reasoning: This rule establishes a premium pay rate for working on a day off, conditional on the amount of notice given. It's a specific overtime calculation rule.

name: Termination Pay Adjustment for Unused Flex EDOs
rule_text: If a long term employee is terminated without having a flex EDO within the previous six (6) weeks, then an adjustment will be made to pay any regular hours worked in excess of two hundred and forty (240) hours over the previous six (6) weeks at the applicable overtime rate.
summary: If a long-term employee is terminated and has not taken a flex EDO in the prior six weeks, their last six weeks of pay will be recalculated. Any regular hours worked over 240 in that period will be paid out at the overtime rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW AND status == TERMINATED AND last_flex_edo > 6_weeks_ago -> PAY(OT_rate) FOR regular_hours_worked > 240 IN previous_6_weeks
reasoning: This is a complex pay calculation rule triggered by termination. It re-evaluates previously worked regular hours and converts them to overtime, directly impacting labor cost and time categorization.

name: Flex EDO Request Notice
rule_text: The employee will provide a minimum of seven (7) days notice when requesting flex. EDO's.
summary: Employees must give at least seven days' notice when they want to schedule one of their flexible EDOs.
logical_representation: IF employee_requests_flex_edo -> REQUIRE(MIN(7)_days_notice)
reasoning: This rule sets a procedural requirement for scheduling time off, which is part of managing the overall work schedule and labor time.

name: Forfeiture of Unused Flex EDOs
rule_text: It is understood that: the onus is on the employee to request the flex EDO's; that these EDO's are over and above the minimum vacation and statutory holiday required by law, and that overtime payment will not be made for flex days not taken by the employee with the exception of those circumstances outlined in items b) and c) above
summary: It is the employee's responsibility to request their flex EDOs. If an employee does not take their flex EDOs, they will not be paid out for them, except in specific situations related to termination or short-term status changes.
logical_representation: IF day_type == FLEX_EDO AND is_taken == FALSE -> FORFEIT(pay) | EXCEPTION(clause_b_or_c_conditions)
reasoning: This rule clarifies that an entitlement (flex EDO) has no cash value if unused, which is a key rule in calculating final pay and managing time-off liabilities.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedule (Short-Term Hires)
rule_text: During a period of Plant Shutdown, all employees hired with the intentions of shortterm employment shall be paid based on five (5) eight (8) hour days Monday to Friday or four (4) ten (10) hour days Monday to Thursday and or Tuesday to Friday.
summary: During a plant shutdown, short-term hires will work a schedule of either five 8-hour days or four 10-hour days.
logical_representation: IF event == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employee_intent == SHORT_TERM -> DEFINE(schedule: 5x8_MON_FRI OR 4x10_MON_THU OR 4x10_TUE_FRI)
reasoning: This rule defines specific work schedules applicable during a particular operational event (shutdown) for a certain class of employee, which is a fundamental aspect of worked time management.

name: Plant Shutdown Employment Status Override
rule_text: Those hired for the Plant Shutdown will continue to receive compensation under the terms of short term employment until the conclusion of the work even if they are on site longer than  six  (6)  weeks.
summary: Employees hired specifically for a plant shutdown will remain on short-term employment pay terms for the entire duration of the shutdown, even if it lasts longer than six weeks.
logical_representation: IF event == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employee_intent == SHORT_TERM AND employment_term > 6_weeks -> MAINTAIN(compensation_terms, SHORT_TERM_EMPLOYMENT)
reasoning: This rule is an explicit override of another rule (the six-week transition to long-term status). It dictates which pay and schedule rules apply, making it a worked time classification rule.

name: Plant Shutdown Schedule (Long-Term Crew)
rule_text: All  Long  Term  Base  Crew  employees  shall  remain  on  the compensation terms of the Compressed Work Week arrangements where applicable overtime payments will be made for work on a scheduled day off as per Clause c).
summary: During a plant shutdown, Long Term Base Crew employees will continue to be paid under the normal Compressed Work Week rules, including the overtime provisions for working on scheduled days off.
logical_representation: IF event == PLANT_SHUTDOWN AND employee_type == LONG_TERM_BASE_CREW -> MAINTAIN(compensation_terms, COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK)
reasoning: This rule confirms the continuation of a specific set of pay and schedule rules for a class of employee during a special event, ensuring clarity on how their time is calculated.

name: Coker Shift Rotation Grandfathering
rule_text: The parties  agree  to  "grandfather"  the  current  coker  shift  rotation  that  is  in  place  and operating  at  the  site  under  the  current  arrangements  and  rules.  This  would  apply  to members of Labourers Local 92 currently involved in this rotation.

name: 9/80 Schedule Definition
rule_text: This work week averages to forty (40) hours straight time over a two-week period and is generally known as  the  9/80  schedule.

reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental characteristics of the work schedule, including its duration and average hours, which falls under the categorization of worked time.

name: 9/80 Schedule Applicability
rule_text: It  is  intended  for  on-going  work  and  does  not  operate  in  'major  shutdown' situations.

logical_representation: IF work_situation == 'MAJOR_SHUTDOWN' -> SCHEDULE_TYPE != 'NINE_EIGHTY'
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for when the specific work schedule and its associated time rules are active, making it a rule about how labor time is managed.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Mon-Thu Hours

reasoning: This rule defines the number of straight time hours for specific workdays within the schedule, which is a core component of categorizing worked time.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 1 Friday Hours

reasoning: This rule defines the number of straight time hours for a specific workday within the schedule, directly relating to how worked time is categorized.

name: 9/80 Schedule, Week 2 Mon-Thu Hours
rule_text: The regular work week will consist of four (4) nine (9) hour straight time days Monday to Thursday in the second week.

reasoning: This rule defines the number of straight time hours for specific workdays within the schedule, which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

reasoning: This rule defines a specific day within the schedule as a non-working day, which is an essential aspect of defining the work schedule.

name: 9/80 OT, Week 1 Daily, First Tier

reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for the second tier of daily overtime, defining how hours are categorized after an initial threshold is met.

reasoning: This rule establishes the pay rate for working on a scheduled day off, defining a specific condition for overtime pay.

reasoning: This rule defines the transition to a higher pay rate after a specific number of hours are worked on a scheduled day off.

name: 9/80 OT, Week 2 Weekday

reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for work on specific non-scheduled days (weekends), making it a rule about how worked time is categorized and paid.

name: Overtime Meal Entitlement
rule_text: It should be noted that those employees working more than ten (10) hours are entitled to an overtime meal and break at the ten (10) hour mark pursuant to the overtime meal articles in the agreement.
summary: Employees who work more than 10 hours in a day receive an overtime meal and a break at the 10-hour mark.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL) AND PROVIDE(BREAK)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to a meal and a break based on a specific threshold of hours worked, which is the definition of a meal allowance rule.

name: Standard Workday, Mon-Fri
rule_text: Those employees working long-term maintenance at the Imperial Oil Strathcona site will work eight and six tenths (8 .6) hours at straight-time Monday to Friday.
summary: The standard workday for long-term maintenance employees at the IOL Strathcona site is 8.6 hours at straight-time, from Monday to Friday.
logical_representation: IF work_day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI] -> PAY(MAX(8.6), ST)
reasoning: This rule defines the number of straight-time hours in a standard workday, which is a core concept of categorizing worked time.

name: EDO Compensation Purpose
rule_text: The extra six tenths of an hour (.6) each Monday to Friday is designed to compensate the worker for the sixteen (16) scheduled EDO's.
summary: An extra 0.6 hours is worked each weekday to compensate employees for 16 scheduled Earned Days Off (EDOs).
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: daily_straight_time_hours == 8.6 FOR EDO_COMPENSATION(16)
reasoning: This rule explains the calculation and purpose behind the standard workday length, linking it to the EDO entitlement, which is part of time categorization and compensation.

name: General Overtime Trigger
rule_text: All additional hours after the eight and six tenths (8 .6) will be performed at the regular overtime provisions as indicated in the National Maintenance Agreement.
summary: Any hours worked beyond the standard 8.6 hours on a weekday are considered overtime and will be paid according to the National Maintenance Agreement's overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF work_day IN [MON, TUE, WED, THU, FRI] AND daily_hours > 8.6 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule establishes the threshold at which straight-time ends and overtime begins for a standard workday.

name: Overtime Meal Break
rule_text: It is understood that those required to work more than ten hours (10) on this shift are entitled to an overtime meal break at the ten-hour mark (10) pursuant to the overtime meal provisions in the collective agreement.
summary: Employees who work more than 10 hours in a single shift are entitled to an overtime meal break at the 10-hour point.
logical_representation: IF daily_hours_worked > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL_BREAK)
reasoning: This rule defines an entitlement to a meal break based on the number of hours worked, which falls under the category of meal allowances and provisions.

name: EDO Work Pay Rate (Text)

summary: Work performed on any of the 16 scheduled Earned Days Off (EDOs) will be paid at a double-time rate.

reasoning: This rule specifies a special pay rate (double-time) for work performed on a specific type of day (EDO), which is a rule for categorizing worked time.

name: Weekday Overtime, First Tier

reasoning: This rule defines the threshold at which the overtime rate transitions to double-time on a standard workday.

reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for work on specific non-standard workdays (Saturday and Sunday), which is a key aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Subsistence Assistance - Request Condition
rule_text: The employer, where requested by both the employee and the Business Manager of the applicable Local Union, would either:
summary: Subsistence assistance, in the form of direct lodging payment or a payroll advance, is only provided if a request is made by both the employee and the local Union Business Manager.
logical_representation: IF is_request_from_employee == TRUE AND is_request_from_union_business_manager == TRUE -> ACTION(provide_lodging_payment OR provide_advance)

name: Subsistence Assistance - Direct Lodging Payment

name: Subsistence Assistance - Payroll Advance
rule_text: (ii) provide the employee with "an advance", based on the subsistence allowance for the time period stated in (i), which will be deducted from the first pay cheque.

name: Foreman Minimum Pay Rate Guarantee
rule_text: he/she will at no time be paid less than the Foreman's rate for which they qualify under  Clause  25.02  (b)  for  a  minimum  of  four  (4)  months  from  date  of  hire  or transfer or until laid off if less than four (4) months.

name: Pay for Online Orientation
rule_text: If  an  Employer  requires  an  employee  to  complete  an  employer  online  orientation,  the Employer shall estimate a reasonable amount of time to complete the orientation.  The Employer shall pay an allowance for completing the course equal to the time estimated, to a maximum of four (4) hours, multiplied by the employee's base rate only and payable with the first pay period following the start of work.

name: Reporting Pay When Not Hired
rule_text: Members of the Union dispatched from the Union office reporting for work at the time and place specified by the Employer and who are not engaged by the Employer shall receive a minimum of two (2) hours locally or four (4) hours beyond 300 km reporting pay, plus travel allowance and expense, if applicable.

logical_representation: IF reported_for_work == true AND was_engaged == false AND employer_notification_is_timely == false AND DIST <= 300km -> MIN(2_HOURS_PAY) | IF reported_for_work == true AND was_engaged == false AND employer_notification_is_timely == false AND DIST > 300km -> MIN(4_HOURS_PAY)

name: Reporting Pay Exception - Timely Notification

reasoning: This rule constrains how wages and benefits are calculated and allocated, directly affecting compensation for worked time.

name: Union Notification for Wage Allocation
rule_text: The union will notify the Association as to where to allocate the wages to benefits not less than 60 days prior to the effective date of the increase in order to publish the revised wage schedule in a timely manner.
summary: The union must inform the employer's association how to distribute wage increases into benefits at least 60 days before the increase takes effect.
logical_representation: IF event == wage_increase -> CONSTRAINT: union_must_notify_association(allocation_details) AT LEAST 60 days PRIOR
reasoning: This is an administrative rule that is a prerequisite for correctly calculating and applying new wage and benefit rates for worked time.

name: Apprentice Rate Increase Timing
rule_text: (d) The apprentice's next period increase will become effective on the first pay period following the date the apprentice presents to his Employer the letter received from the Apprenticeship Board notifying them of successful completion of a schooling period unless the apprentice's anniversary date has not been reached. In that case the increase will become effective on the first pay period following the anniversary date. An apprentice will receive his increase to journeyman rate on the first pay period following the date his ticket becomes effective.
summary: An apprentice's pay raise takes effect on the first pay period after they show their employer proof of passing school, unless their work anniversary date is later, in which case the raise starts after the anniversary. The final increase to journeyman pay happens in the first pay period after their journeyman ticket becomes effective.
logical_representation: IF apprentice_advancement -> ACTION: PAY(increased_rate) ON first_pay_period AFTER MAX(school_completion_proof_date, anniversary_date)
reasoning: This rule specifies the exact timing for a change in an apprentice's pay rate, which directly impacts the compensation for their worked time.

name: Industrial Pay Frequency and Holdback
rule_text: 8.05 ( a) Pay day shall be once each week, and not more than five (5) days pay may be held back, unless other arrangements are made between the Employer and the Union.
summary: For industrial work, employees must be paid weekly, and the employer can hold back a maximum of five days' worth of pay.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' -> CONSTRAINT: pay_frequency == 'weekly' AND pay_holdback <= 5_days
reasoning: This rule governs the timing and frequency of payment for worked time, an administrative but essential aspect of the topic.

name: Pay Time on Pay Day
rule_text: Employees are to be paid a minimum of two (2) hours before the end of their regular shift, except when they are required to work a second or third shift on pay day, in which case they shall be paid on the preceding day.
summary: On payday, employees must receive their pay at least two hours before their regular shift ends. If they work a second or third shift on payday, they must be paid the day before.
logical_representation: IF is_payday AND shift IN [2, 3] -> PAY ON preceding_day | ELSE -> PAY AT LEAST 2_hours BEFORE shift_end
reasoning: This rule sets specific conditions on the timing of payment for worked time, directly relating to the administration of payroll for labor.

name: Pay Error Correction Timeline
rule_text: (b) Errors or omissions with the Employee's pay or pay cheque shall be corrected by the next pay period, provided the Employer is notified in a timely manner.
summary: If there is a mistake in an employee's pay, it must be fixed by the next payday, as long as the employer was notified in time.
logical_representation: IF pay_error_exists AND employer_notified_timely -> ACTION(correct_error) BY next_pay_period
reasoning: This rule defines the process for correcting pay for worked time, which is an essential part of ensuring accurate compensation.

name: Penalty for Late Pay Error Correction
rule_text: If the Employer has been notified at least one (1) working day prior to payroll cut off for the next pay period and the correction(s) is/are not made, there will be a penalty equivalent of two (2) hours at base rate, for every working day until the correction(s) is/are made beyond payday.
summary: If an employer is notified of a pay error at least one working day before the payroll cutoff and fails to fix it by the next payday, they must pay a penalty of two hours' pay for each working day the correction is late.
logical_representation: IF pay_error_uncorrected AND notification_received >= 1_working_day BEFORE payroll_cutoff -> PAY(2_hours_base_rate) PER working_day_of_delay
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee as a penalty for administrative failure, which fits the description of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Overpayment Recovery Process
rule_text: (c) If the Employer determines that an error of overpayment has occurred, and the error has occurred in the last six (6) months, the Employer shall promptly give notice in writing to the affected employee of the amount of the error, how the amount of the error was calculated, and a plan to recover the overpayment through deduction or deductions through one (1) or more pay periods.
summary: If an employer overpays an employee within the last six months, they must provide written notice detailing the error, its calculation, and a repayment plan. The employee then has time to respond before deductions begin.
logical_representation: IF overpayment_error_occurred_within_last(6_months) -> ACTION(employer_provides_written_notice_and_recovery_plan)
reasoning: This rule details the procedure for adjusting pay for worked time due to overpayment, which is directly related to the administration of compensation.

name: Commercial/Institutional Pay Frequency
rule_text: (d) Pay day shall be weekly or biweekly at the option of the Employer and not more than five (5) days pay may be held back, unless other arrangements are made between the Employer and the Union.
summary: For commercial or institutional work, the employer can choose to pay employees either weekly or bi-weekly, with a maximum holdback of five days' pay.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Commercial/Institutional' -> CONSTRAINT: pay_frequency IN ['weekly', 'biweekly'] AND pay_holdback <= 5_days
reasoning: This rule governs the timing and frequency of payment for worked time, an administrative but essential aspect of the topic.

name: Pay Draw for New Hires
rule_text: For new hires only, a draw of seventy-five percent (75%) of net wages due may be requested after one (1) week.
summary: After their first week, new hires can request an advance payment (a 'draw') of up to 75% of their net earnings.
logical_representation: IF employee_status == 'new_hire' AND time_worked >= 1_week -> ALLOW(request_pay_draw, MAX=0.75*net_wages)
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism for the early payment of wages for worked time under specific conditions, relating to the administration of pay.

name: Emergency Pay Draw
rule_text: It is further agreed that, in an emergency situation, an Employee will not be refused a midpoint draw of seventy-five percent (75%) of net wages due.
summary: In an emergency, an employee must be allowed to take an advance payment (a 'draw') of up to 75% of their net earnings from the middle of a pay period.
logical_representation: IF employee_situation == 'emergency' -> ALLOW(midpoint_pay_draw, MAX=0.75*net_wages)
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism for the early payment of wages for worked time under specific conditions, relating to the administration of pay.

name: Final Pay on Termination
rule_text: 8.06 (a) When Employees are laid off or discharged, they shall be paid the wages due to them at the time of layoff or discharge and given their Record of Employment and Apprenticeship Book, if applicable, except in the case where the Employer has not established a pay office at the jobsite, payment will be mailed within two (2) working days.
summary: When an employee is laid off or fired, they must be paid all wages owed at that time. If there's no pay office on-site, the payment must be mailed within two working days.
logical_representation: IF termination_type IN ['layoff', 'discharge'] AND jobsite_pay_office_exists == true -> PAY(final_wages) AT termination | ELSE -> PAY(final_wages) BY mail WITHIN 2_working_days
reasoning: This rule dictates the timing for the final payment of all worked time and associated earnings upon termination, a key aspect of payroll administration.

name: Penalty for Late Final Pay
rule_text: Employees must advise the payroll department of their employer if they believe their final pay is late. The Employer will then have two working days following notification to get the final pay cheque to the employee. Failure to do so will result in a penalty of four (4) hours at the applicable basic hourly rate of pay for each 24-hour period of delay beyond the two working days within which the pay should have been postmarked.
summary: If an employee's final pay is late, they must notify payroll. The employer then has two working days to issue payment. If they fail, they owe a penalty of four hours' pay for every 24-hour delay.
logical_representation: IF final_pay_is_late AND employee_notifies_payroll -> IF employer_fails_to_pay_within(2_working_days) -> PAY(4_hours_base_rate) PER 24_hour_period_of_delay
reasoning: This rule creates a minimum pay guarantee as a penalty for failing to provide final pay on time, which is a condition covered by the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Final Pay on Voluntary Termination
rule_text: (b) When an Employee voluntarily terminates their employment, the Employer will mail their wages to their last known address without undue delay but no later than two (2) working days after termination.
summary: When an employee quits, the employer must mail their final wages to their last known address within two working days.
logical_representation: IF termination_type == 'voluntary' -> PAY(final_wages) BY mail WITHIN 2_working_days
reasoning: This rule defines the required timeline for issuing final payment for all worked time when an employee quits.

name: Final Pay via Direct Deposit
rule_text: (f) For the purposes of this Article, where an Employer is utilizing electronic banking, the above clauses will apply to the Employees of that Employer with the exception of those Employees who have selected to be paid by direct deposit. In this case the final pay will be paid on the next regular pay day when the time owing would have been normally payable. If this pay is late the four (4) hour late remittance language as set out in 8.06 (a) above will be applicable.
summary: For employees paid by direct deposit, the rules for immediate final pay do not apply. Instead, their final pay will be deposited on the next scheduled payday. If this deposit is late, the standard penalty of four hours' pay per day applies.
logical_representation: IF payment_method == 'direct_deposit' -> PAY(final_wages) ON next_regular_payday
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to the standard final pay timing based on payment method, directly impacting the administration of pay for worked time.

name: Vacation and Stat Holiday Pay Timing
rule_text: 8.10 Statutory Holiday Pay and Vacation Pay shall be paid each Employee every pay period except as provided for in Clause 14.06.
summary: Employees must be paid their statutory holiday and vacation pay on every paycheck, unless a specific exception in Clause 14.06 applies.
logical_representation: PAY(statutory_holiday_pay, vacation_pay) ON every_pay_period
reasoning: This rule governs when specific pay entitlements, earned as a function of worked time, are to be paid out to the employee.

name: Industrial Contribution Basis
rule_text: 8.11 (a) For INDUSTRIAL work, notwithstanding anything contained elsewhere in this Agreement, all contributions to the separate following trust funds shall be payable by the Employer on the Employee's total actual hours EARNED including overtime.
summary: For all industrial work, employer contributions to all trust funds must be based on the employee's total hours earned, which includes overtime hours.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' -> CALCULATE(all_trust_fund_contributions) ON total_hours_earned
reasoning: This rule establishes the fundamental basis (earned hours) for calculating all benefit contributions, which is a core part of the overall compensation system for worked time.

name: Commercial/Institutional Contribution Basis
rule_text: (c) For COMMERCIAL/INSTITUTIONAL work, notwithstanding anything contained else-where in this Agreement, all contributions to the separate following Trust Funds shall be payable by the Employer on the Employees' total actual hours WORKED including overtime.
summary: For all commercial and institutional work, employer contributions to all trust funds must be based on the employee's total hours actually worked, which includes overtime hours.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Commercial/Institutional' -> CALCULATE(all_trust_fund_contributions) ON total_hours_worked
reasoning: This rule establishes the fundamental basis (worked hours) for calculating all benefit contributions, which is a core part of the overall compensation system for worked time.

name: ISIT and MMDF Contribution Basis Override
rule_text: All contributions by the Employer(s) for the ISIT and MMDF plan(s) for both INDUSTRIAL and COMMERCIAL INSTITUTIONAL shall be contributed by the Employer based on the Employee's total actual hours EARNED including overtime.
summary: Regardless of whether the work is industrial or commercial/institutional, employer contributions for the ISIT and MMDF plans must always be calculated based on the employee's total hours earned, including overtime.
logical_representation: IF contribution_type IN ['ISIT', 'MMDF'] -> CALCULATE(contribution) ON total_hours_earned
reasoning: This rule provides a specific override for certain benefits, defining their calculation basis (earned hours), which is a key component of the worked time compensation system.

name: Employment Status During Welding Test
rule_text: In the case that any Journeyman, whose skill is welding, is required to take a customer requested welding test, the Employer agrees that such Journeyman will be in the employ of the Employer while taking such tests and be placed on the payroll...
summary: A Journeyman welder is considered an employee and must be on the payroll while taking a customer-requested welding test.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'Journeyman_Welder' AND activity_type == 'customer_requested_welding_test' -> SET employee_status = 'employed' AND ACTION(add_to_payroll)
reasoning: This rule establishes that time spent testing is considered employment time, which is the foundation for being paid for that time, classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Travel Allowance for Welding Test
rule_text: ...and be paid any applicable travel allowance.
summary: A Journeyman taking a customer-requested welding test must be paid any applicable travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'Journeyman_Welder' AND activity_type == 'customer_requested_welding_test' -> PAY(applicable_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule governs payment of a 'travel allowance'. While not subsistence, it's a monetary entitlement for remote or non-standard work locations, making LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE the closest fit among the provided options.

name: Work Expectation After Passing Test
rule_text: A welder who passes the test and has reported for the test at the appointed time is expected to complete the regular day at work at the welding trade that the Employer has available.
summary: A welder who passes a test on time is expected to work for the remainder of their regular shift if work is available.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'pass' AND reported_on_time == true AND work_is_available == true -> OBLIGATION(complete_regular_work_day)
reasoning: This rule defines the work obligation following a paid activity (the test), linking paid time to expected work time, which is a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Full Day's Pay Guarantee for Passing Test
rule_text: Provided that the Employee reports to test at the time scheduled by the Employer, they shall be paid one full day's pay if they pass the test, and the Employer has no work available for them on that day.
summary: If a welder reports on time and passes their test but the employer has no work for them, they are guaranteed one full day's pay.
logical_representation: IF reported_on_time == true AND test_result == 'pass' AND work_is_available == false -> PAY(1_full_day)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee under specific conditions, which is a fundamental aspect of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Pay for Late Arrival and Passing Test
rule_text: if an Employee reports after the scheduled test time and passes the test they shall be paid from the time they started the test until the normal end of that shift.
summary: If an employee arrives late for a test but still passes, they will be paid only from the time the test began until the end of the shift.
logical_representation: IF reported_on_time == false AND test_result == 'pass' -> PAY(hours_from_test_start_to_shift_end)
reasoning: This rule defines how paid hours are calculated based on attendance and test results, falling squarely under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: No Pay for Failed Test Time
rule_text: A welder who fails the test shall not be paid for the time required to complete the failed test...
summary: A welder who fails their test will not be paid for the time they spent taking it.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'fail' -> PAY(0_for_test_time)
reasoning: This rule specifies when time spent on a work-related activity is not compensable, which is a core pay calculation rule under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Travel Allowance for Failed Test
rule_text: ...but will be paid any applicable travel allowance.
summary: Even if a welder fails their test, they will still receive any applicable travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'fail' -> PAY(applicable_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule dictates payment of a 'travel allowance' regardless of test outcome. This is a condition for a monetary entitlement for non-standard work, best categorized under LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE.

name: Pay for Multiple Tests with Mixed Results
rule_text: In the event the worker is required to take multiple tests and passes some of the tests but fails others they will be paid as above if hired or will be paid for the time taken on successful tests if not hired.
summary: For multiple tests with mixed results: if hired, pay is determined by prior rules (e.g., full day's pay); if not hired, pay is only for time spent on successful tests.
logical_representation: IF test_count > 1 AND has_mixed_results AND is_hired == true -> PAY(as_per_prior_rules); IF test_count > 1 AND has_mixed_results AND is_hired == false -> PAY(time_spent_on_successful_tests)
reasoning: This rule details how to calculate pay in a complex scenario involving test outcomes and hiring status, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Waiting Time Pay for Test Results
rule_text: Welders successfully completing such tests shall receive a regular day's pay at straight time rates for any working day lost, due to transportation delays, or when test pieces must be sent to an outside agency for assessment, except when transportation delays are beyond the control of the Employer.
summary: Welders who pass their test will receive a full day's pay at straight time for any workday lost while waiting for test results from an outside agency or due to employer-controlled transportation delays.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'pass' AND (reason_for_lost_day == 'transportation_delay' AND is_delay_employer_controlled == true) OR (reason_for_lost_day == 'external_assessment') -> PAY(1_full_day_ST)
reasoning: This is a waiting time pay rule, which dictates compensation for non-productive time, a classic example of a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Forfeiture of Pay for Failure to Report to Work
rule_text: Welders, upon successfully completing such tests, who fail to report for work, or fail to commence work when directed, will not be eligible for daily subsistence, travel allowance, transportation, accommodation, waiting, and/or testing time pay.
summary: Welders who pass a test but then fail to report for work as directed will forfeit their entitlement to subsistence, travel allowance, transportation, accommodation, and pay for waiting or testing time.
logical_representation: IF test_result == 'pass' AND reported_for_work == false -> FORFEIT(daily_subsistence, travel_allowance, transportation, accommodation, waiting_time_pay, testing_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule's primary action is the forfeiture of entitlements, with 'daily subsistence' being a key item that matches the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic. It also affects pay for time (waiting/testing), making LABOR_WORKED_TIME a valid secondary topic.

name: Required Welding Qualifications for Dispatch
rule_text: Members, whose skill is welding, who are dispatched to an Employer, shall, at the discretion of the Employer, be in possession of a valid standard small bore 'B' Pressure (F3/F4) and Carbon TIG (F6/F4) welding qualifications (all tests performed on 2-inch XXS).
summary: At the employer's discretion, welders dispatched to a job must already possess valid 'B' Pressure and Carbon TIG welding qualifications.
logical_representation: IF employee_skill == 'welding' AND dispatch_status == 'dispatched' -> CONDITION(employer_may_require_B_Pressure_and_Carbon_TIG_qualification)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition of employment that determines eligibility for a job and, by extension, eligibility to be paid. It's a prerequisite for any pay rule applying, thus categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Welding Test Incentive Fee and Conditions
rule_text:
A welder (Journeyman or Apprentice) who is required by the Employer or the Employer's client to perform on any Gas Tungsten Arc Welding (GTAW) test or Gas Metal Arc Welding (GMAW) test or Flux-Core Arc Welding (FCAW) test for pressure welding will be paid a testing fee of one hundred  and  seventy-five  ($175.00)  dollars  effective  May  1,  2013  providing  they  meet  the following criteria:
- (a) The welder must successfully pass the relevant test.
- (b) The welder remains on the project a minimum of thirty (30) days or until lay off, whichever occurs first
- (c) The welder cannot refuse to utilize the tested procedure while employed on the project.

Providing these criteria are met, the welder incentive test fee will be paid after the thirty days of employment or upon lay off, whichever occurs first.
summary: A welder who takes a specific pressure welding test (GTAW, GMAW, FCAW) receives a $175 fee if they pass, stay on the project for 30 days (or until layoff), and don't refuse to use the procedure. The fee is paid after 30 days or at layoff, whichever is first.
logical_representation: IF test_type IN ['GTAW', 'GMAW', 'FCAW'] AND test_result == 'pass' AND (employment_duration >= 30 OR layoff_status == true) AND refused_procedure == false -> PAY(175.00_after_30_days_or_at_layoff)
reasoning: This rule outlines a specific monetary payment (a fee) and its multi-part conditions, functioning as a special allowance tied to a work-related task, which falls under general pay calculation rules of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Definition of Alloy Welding
rule_text: For the purpose of this agreement, Alloy welding shall be defined as any welding done on material other than ASME P-1 regardless of process.
summary: For this contract, 'Alloy welding' is defined as any welding performed on materials other than ASME P-1.
logical_representation: DEFINITION(alloy_welding) := (welding_material_type != 'ASME P-1')
reasoning: This definition is a prerequisite for the alloy premium pay rule and is therefore integral to pay calculation, placing it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Alloy Welder Premium (Dispatch Requirement)
rule_text: Welders with a valid alloy welding certificate will be paid an additional premium of $3.25 per hour worked if certification was a requirement for dispatch.
summary: If being certified for alloy welding was a requirement for the job, the welder will receive a premium of $3.25 for every hour worked.
logical_representation: IF has_alloy_certificate == true AND is_cert_dispatch_requirement == true -> PREMIUM($3.25)
reasoning: This rule establishes a wage premium, which is a direct modification of the hourly pay rate for worked time, a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Alloy Welder Premium (On-site Re-classification)
rule_text: If a welder on site who was not dispatched as an alloy welder, but has the certification, or is requested to be certified by the employer and is requested to perform alloy welding, the worker will be re-classified as an alloy welder and paid the alloy welder premium for all hours worked during the applicable work cycle.
summary: A welder not originally dispatched for alloy work, who is then asked to perform it, will be re-classified and paid the alloy premium for all hours in that work cycle.
logical_representation: IF was_dispatched_as_alloy_welder == false AND is_requested_to_perform_alloy_welding == true -> ACTION(reclassify_as_alloy_welder) AND PAY(alloy_premium_for_all_hours_in_work_cycle)
reasoning: This rule describes a condition for re-classification that triggers a wage premium, directly affecting pay calculation for worked hours and fitting within LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Alloy Welder Re-classification Escalator
rule_text: The worker may only be reclassified to a maximum of 2 times in a calendar year, if the worker is reclassified a 3rd time within the calendar year the worker is entitled to the premium for all hours worked from the date of the employee being reclassified a 3rd time, until the worker is laid off or terminated.
summary: A worker can be re-classified to an alloy welder up to twice a year. If re-classified a third time in one year, they will earn the alloy premium for all hours worked from that point until they leave the job.
logical_representation: IF reclassification_count_in_year == 3 -> PAY(alloy_premium_on_all_hours_from_reclass_date_until_termination)
reasoning: This rule sets a threshold that permanently alters a worker's pay rate for the remainder of their employment, which is a complex pay calculation rule under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Apprentice Pay Rate with Provisional 'C' Ticket
rule_text: When an apprentice in the employ of an employer acquires a Provisional 'C' Welders ticket that allows them to perform pressure welds for that employer that apprentice will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate while engaged in that work for their employer.
summary: An apprentice who gets a Provisional 'C' Welder ticket will be paid at the 'Journeyman Welder without CWB' rate when performing pressure welds.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'Apprentice' AND has_provisional_c_ticket == true AND work_type == 'pressure_welds' -> SET PAY_RATE('Journeyman Welder without CWB')
reasoning: This rule defines the specific pay rate for an employee based on their certification and the type of work performed, which is a core calculation rule of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Out-of-Province Journeyman Pay Rate with Provisional 'C' Ticket
rule_text: A journeyman pressure welder from another jurisdiction outside of Alberta who is working under a Provisional 'C' Welders ticket will be paid at the UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder rate.
summary: A journeyman pressure welder from outside Alberta working with a Provisional 'C' ticket will be paid at the 'UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder' rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_class == 'Journeyman' AND jurisdiction != 'Alberta' AND has_provisional_c_ticket == true -> SET PAY_RATE('UA Journeyman Steamfitter and B Pressure Welder')
reasoning: This rule defines a specific pay rate based on an employee's origin and certification, directly relating to pay calculation and LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Recognized Holiday Pay Rate
rule_text: All work performed on the following recognized holidays...shall be paid for at the rate of double time
summary: Work performed on any of the specified recognized holidays is paid at double the regular rate (double time). The holidays are: New Year's Day, Family Day, Good Friday, Victoria Day, Canada Day, Heritage Day, Labour Day, National Day for Truth & Reconciliation, Thanksgiving Day, Remembrance Day, Christmas Day, and Boxing Day.
logical_representation: IF work_date IN recognized_holiday_list -> PAY(DT)
reasoning: This rule defines a special pay rate (double time) for hours worked on specific calendar days (holidays), which is a core function of categorizing and compensating worked time.

name: Declared Government Holiday Pay Rate
rule_text: All work performed on...any general holiday declared by the level of government with jurisdiction, either the Federal or Provincial, shall be paid for at the rate of double time
summary: If the Federal or Provincial government declares a new general holiday, any work performed on that day must be paid at double the regular rate (double time).
logical_representation: IF is_declared_gov_holiday == TRUE -> PAY(DT)
reasoning: This rule establishes a special pay rate for a category of day (government-declared holidays), directly relating to how worked time is compensated.

name: Shift Differential on Holidays
rule_text: All work performed on the following recognized holidays...shall be paid for at the rate of double time, plus any applicable shift differential
summary: When working on a recognized holiday, employees receive double time pay plus any shift differential they are also entitled to for those hours.
logical_representation: IF work_date IN recognized_holiday_list AND has_shift_differential == TRUE -> PAY(DT) + PAY(shift_differential)
reasoning: This rule specifies how pay is calculated for worked time on a holiday by adding a premium on top of the base rate, which is a key aspect of time categorization and payment.

name: Holiday Observance Date
rule_text: Each of the general holidays listed in clause 14.01 shall be observed on the calendar date on which it occurs, premiums will apply for hours worked
summary: Recognized holidays are observed on their actual calendar date, and premium pay for working on them applies only to that specific date.
logical_representation: IF work_date == holiday_calendar_date -> APPLY(holiday_premiums)
reasoning: This rule defines the specific day on which special pay rules apply, which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

name: Labour Day Work Prohibition
rule_text: No work shall be performed on Labour Day, except for the preservation of life or imminent danger to property.
summary: Work is strictly prohibited on Labour Day unless it is an emergency situation required to save a life or prevent immediate damage to property.
logical_representation: IF work_date == 'Labour Day' AND is_emergency_work == FALSE -> CONSTRAINT(NO_WORK_PERMITTED)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition on when work is permitted, which is a primary component of defining schedules and categorizing labor time.

name: Holiday Pay In Lieu
rule_text: In lieu of pay for the above recognized holidays the Employer shall pay an additional 4% to the Employee's total hourly earnings each week, including overtime hours and premium time hours.
summary: Instead of receiving paid days off for recognized holidays, employees receive an extra 4% of their total weekly hourly earnings as holiday pay.
logical_representation: FOR each_pay_period -> PAY(total_hourly_earnings * 0.04) AS holiday_pay
reasoning: This rule defines a specific pay calculation (4% of earnings) that serves as compensation for statutory holidays, directly relating to how an employee's time and entitlements are monetized.

name: Vacation Pay Rate
rule_text: Employees annual Vacation Pay shall be 6% of the Employee's total hourly earnings.
summary: Employees are entitled to vacation pay calculated at 6% of their total hourly earnings.
logical_representation: FOR each_pay_period -> PAY(total_hourly_earnings * 0.06) AS vacation_pay
reasoning: This rule establishes the calculation rate for vacation pay based on earnings from worked time, which is a fundamental aspect of labor compensation.

name: Vacation and Holiday Pay Calculation Base
rule_text: Such total hourly earnings shall be deemed to include straight time hours, overtime hours, premium time hours
summary: The 6% vacation pay and 4% holiday pay are calculated based on total hourly earnings, which includes earnings from straight time, overtime, and any other premium hours.
logical_representation: DEFINE total_hourly_earnings = straight_time_earnings + overtime_earnings + premium_time_earnings
reasoning: This rule defines the components of the earnings base used to calculate other pay entitlements (vacation/holiday pay), which is a core rule for calculating compensation for worked time.

name: Default Vacation Pay Payout Schedule
rule_text: and shall be paid each pay period with the Employee's regular pay.
summary: By default, the 6% vacation pay is paid out to the employee on every paycheque along with their regular wages.
logical_representation: FOR each_pay_period -> PAY(vacation_pay_amount)
reasoning: This rule dictates the timing and frequency of a payment entitlement derived from labor, which falls under the administration of compensation for worked time.

name: Calgary 496 VHP/SHP Payout Options
rule_text: For the Calgary 496 jurisdiction only, for Commercial/Institutional work only, the Employer shall have the option to pay V.H.P. and S.H.P. with each pay cheque, or as follows:  at the time vacation is taken;  on the last payday prior to December 31st;  on termination.
summary: For employees in the Calgary 496 jurisdiction doing Commercial/Institutional work, the employer can pay Vacation and Holiday Pay (VHP/SHP) either on each paycheque, when vacation is taken, on the last payday of the year, or at termination.
logical_representation: IF jurisdiction == 'Calgary_496' AND work_type == 'Commercial/Institutional' -> PROVIDE(payout_method_options)
reasoning: This rule provides geographically and work-type specific options for the timing of pay entitlements, which is a key part of administering compensation for worked time.

name: Calgary 496 Payout Method Determination
rule_text: Whether the Employees receive the above noted holiday and vacation pay each pay period, or whether the vacation and holiday pay are to be retained by the Employer and paid to each Employee at the time of the Employee's vacation or on the last pay day in the calendar year or upon termination of the Employee's employment (whichever occurs first), shall be determined by a majority vote of the Employees of that Employer.
summary: For applicable employees (Calgary 496 jurisdiction), the decision whether to receive vacation and holiday pay on each cheque or in a lump sum is determined by a majority vote of the employees of that specific employer.
logical_representation: IF jurisdiction == 'Calgary_496' -> payout_method = RESULT_OF(employee_vote_majority)
reasoning: This rule outlines the process for deciding how compensation (vacation and holiday pay) is disbursed, which is a rule governing the administration of pay for time worked.

name: Standard Lunch Break
rule_text: The lunch break will consist of a one-half hour unpaid break taken approximately mid-way during the regular workday.
summary: Employees receive a 30-minute unpaid lunch break around the middle of their regular workday.
logical_representation: IF is_regular_workday -> PROVIDE(LUNCH_BREAK(0.5_HOURS, UNPAID))
reasoning: This rule defines a standard period within the workday that is unpaid, directly impacting the calculation of total paid hours.

name: Delayed Lunch Break Penalty
rule_text: If the lunch break is delayed such that it starts more than one-half hour after the completion of the normal lunch break, the Employee will be paid an additional one-half hour at their applicable straight time rate for the one-half hour lunch break.
summary: If an employee's lunch break starts more than 30 minutes late, they will be paid for the 30-minute break at their straight-time rate.
logical_representation: IF lunch_break_start_delay > 0.5_HOURS -> PAY(0.5_HOURS_ST)
reasoning: This rule creates a condition under which an otherwise unpaid period (a lunch break) becomes paid, which is a core function of worked time classification.

name: Standard Coffee Breaks
rule_text: All Employees covered by this agreement shall be permitted ten (10) minutes in the first half and ten (10) minutes in the second half of a shift for a coffee break on the job during regular working hours.
summary: Employees are entitled to two paid 10-minute coffee breaks, one in the first half and one in the second half of their shift.
