logical_representation: IF shift_type == REGULAR_WORKDAY -> PROVIDE(BREAK(10_MINUTES, FIRST_HALF)) AND PROVIDE(BREAK(10_MINUTES, SECOND_HALF))
reasoning: This rule defines paid non-working time within a shift, which is a component of calculating total paid hours for a day.

name: Overtime Coffee Breaks
rule_text: If extended overtime is required, additional coffee breaks shall be permitted during such overtime after each two (2) hours following each overtime meal break.
summary: During extended overtime, employees get an additional paid coffee break for every two hours worked after an overtime meal break.
logical_representation: IF overtime_type == EXTENDED -> AFTER(overtime_meal_break) AND AFTER(2_HOURS_OT) -> PROVIDE(BREAK)
reasoning: This rule establishes an entitlement to additional paid breaks based on the number of overtime hours worked, directly affecting the ratio of paid work to paid rest time.

name: Compressed Work Week Coffee Breaks (Industrial)
rule_text: However, for INDUSTRIAL WORK ONLY and on a compressed work week scheduled pursuant to Article 17.00, Employees shall be permitted a break of fifteen (15) minutes in the first half and fifteen (15) minutes in the second half of such shifts.
summary: For employees on a compressed work week on industrial projects, the two paid coffee breaks are extended to 15 minutes each.
logical_representation: IF work_type == INDUSTRIAL AND schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> PROVIDE(BREAK(15_MINUTES, FIRST_HALF)) AND PROVIDE(BREAK(15_MINUTES, SECOND_HALF))
reasoning: This rule modifies the standard paid break duration based on the work schedule and job type, which falls under the definition of how time is categorized and paid.

name: 10-Hour Shift Paid Break Option
rule_text: When ten (10) hour shifts are worked, in lieu of the work breaks and lunch breaks provided herein, the Employer shall have the option of scheduling two breaks of one half (½) hour each, paid at the applicable rate, approximately equally spaced in the ten (10) hour shift.
summary: On 10-hour shifts, the employer can choose to replace the standard coffee breaks and unpaid lunch with two 30-minute paid breaks.
logical_representation: IF shift_duration == 10_HOURS AND employer_option_exercised == TRUE -> PROVIDE(BREAK(0.5_HOURS, PAID)) AND PROVIDE(BREAK(0.5_HOURS, PAID))
reasoning: This rule provides an alternative schedule for paid breaks and converts an unpaid lunch into paid time, directly impacting the total paid hours for the shift.

name: Missed Break Penalty
rule_text: In the event an employee is not able to take a break, the employee shall be paid at applicable overtime rates for the missed break.
summary: If an employee cannot take a scheduled break, they must be paid for the missed break time at overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF break_taken == FALSE -> PAY(break_duration, APPLICABLE_OT_RATE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a financial penalty for a missed entitlement. The payment is calculated based on time (the break duration) and a specific rate (overtime), which is a core concept of worked time rules.

name: Missed Break Rate During Straight Time
rule_text: When the hour before and the hour following the missed break are at straight tine, time and one half (1 ½ x) shall be paid for the missed break.
summary: Specifically, if a missed break occurs during a straight-time period, the penalty pay for that break is 1.5 times the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF break_taken == FALSE AND surrounding_time_rate == ST -> PAY(break_duration, 1.5x_ST)
reasoning: This rule clarifies the 'applicable overtime rate' under specific circumstances, defining how a particular block of time is to be paid.

name: 10-Hour Shift Paid Break Option Exclusion
rule_text: This option shall not be applicable to compressed work weeks for which workdays are regularly scheduled in excess of ten (10) hours.
summary: The option to have two 30-minute paid breaks does not apply to compressed work week schedules where shifts are regularly longer than 10 hours.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK AND scheduled_daily_hours > 10 -> CONSTRAINT(10_HOUR_SHIFT_BREAK_OPTION_UNAVAILABLE)
reasoning: This rule sets a boundary condition on the applicability of another worked time rule, making it a rule about how time is structured and paid.

name: Paid Wait Time for Negative POCT
rule_text: If an employer requests a worker to participate in a POCT risk assessment pursuant to 4.8.5 of the Canadian Model , and the worker provides the urine sample, and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall be paid for any time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result, except for such discipline that was justified by the worker's conduct in respect to the incident or reasons for the test request.
summary: An employee will be paid for time spent waiting for a laboratory drug test result if they agreed to an initial screening test (POCT) and the final lab result is negative.
logical_representation: IF test_type == POCT_RISK_ASSESSMENT AND poct_sample_provided == TRUE AND lab_result == NEGATIVE -> PAY(waiting_time, APPLICABLE_RATE)
reasoning: This rule dictates when non-productive waiting time becomes compensable, which is a key aspect of defining and categorizing paid hours.

name: Forfeiture of Wait Time Pay (POCT Declined)
rule_text: If the worker declines to provide the sample for the POCT risk assessment and the laboratory drug test result is negative, the worker shall not be entitled to any pay for time the worker would have otherwise worked while waiting for the laboratory result.
summary: If an employee declines the initial screening test (POCT) but the subsequent lab test is negative, they will not be paid for the time spent waiting for the lab result.
logical_representation: IF test_type == POCT_RISK_ASSESSMENT AND poct_sample_provided == FALSE AND lab_result == NEGATIVE -> FORFEIT(waiting_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition under which waiting time is explicitly not paid. Defining what constitutes unpaid time is a core function of worked time rules.

name: Normal Daily Hours and Schedule
rule_text: The maximum of eight (8) hours shall constitute a normal day's work beginning at 8:00 AM and ending by 5:00 PM (except when one-half (½) hour lunch is taken in which case the normal day will end at 4:30 PM).
summary: A normal workday is a maximum of 8 hours, typically from 8:00 AM to 5:00 PM, or 4:30 PM if a 30-minute lunch is taken.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | daily_hours <= 8 AND daily_schedule == '8:00-17:00' OR daily_schedule == '8:00-16:30'
reasoning: This rule defines the standard hours and schedule for a workday, which is a core component of categorizing worked time.

name: Normal Weekly Hours and Schedule
rule_text: The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 8:00 AM and ending Friday at 5:00 PM.
summary: A normal work week is a maximum of 40 hours, scheduled from Monday 8:00 AM to Friday 5:00 PM.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | weekly_hours <= 40 AND weekly_schedule == 'Mon-Fri'
reasoning: This rule establishes the standard weekly hours and days, which is fundamental for determining when overtime thresholds are met.

name: No Guarantee of Work Hours
rule_text: The above schedule is intended to represent a  normal workday or work week and is not to be construed as a guarantee of hours of work per day or per week or with respect to days in a week.
summary: The standard work schedule does not guarantee that an employee will be provided with a specific number of hours or days of work.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | is_guaranteed_hours == False
reasoning: This rule clarifies the nature of the work schedule, stating it is not a minimum guarantee, which affects pay and entitlement calculations.

name: Employer Start Time Variance
rule_text: The Employer may vary the start/quit times by changing the scheduled starting time up to one hour at their option.
summary: The employer can unilaterally change the daily start and end times by up to one hour.
logical_representation: IF employer_initiates_schedule_change -> MAX(1_hour_variance)
reasoning: This rule governs modifications to the standard work schedule, which is integral to defining what constitutes a regular workday.

name: Mutual Agreement for Major Schedule Variance
rule_text: Variances beyond one (1) hour shall be agreed mutually by the Employer and the Business Representative of the Union and the consent to variance will not be unreasonably withheld.
summary: Any change to the start and end times greater than one hour requires mutual agreement between the employer and the union.
logical_representation: IF schedule_variance_hours > 1 -> requires_mutual_agreement == True
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for significant changes to the work schedule, impacting how daily hours are defined and tracked.

name: Consistent Application of Schedule Changes
rule_text: A  change  in  start/quit  times  shall  be  applied  consistently  on  the  jobsite...
summary: Any changes to start or end times must be applied consistently across the entire jobsite.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | schedule_change_application == 'consistent_jobsite_wide'
reasoning: This rule governs how work schedules are implemented, ensuring consistency, which is a key aspect of defining standard work time.

name: Split Shift Prohibition
rule_text: ...in  no circumstances shall split shifts be created, unless mutually agreed between the parties.
summary: Split shifts are not allowed unless the employer and union mutually agree to them.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT | is_split_shift_allowed == False UNLESS mutual_agreement == True
reasoning: This rule prohibits a specific type of work schedule (split shifts), directly defining the structure of the workday.

name: Weekly Overtime Trigger
rule_text: Forty (40) hours shall constitute a work week, Monday through Friday. All other time worked shall be considered overtime and shall be paid for at the applicable overtime rate of pay.
summary: Any time worked beyond 40 hours in the Monday-to-Friday work week is classified as overtime and must be paid at overtime rates.
logical_representation: IF weekly_hours > 40 AND day IN ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri'] -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the primary threshold for when weekly straight time ends and overtime begins, a fundamental rule for time categorization.

name: Daily Overtime Tier 1 (Mon-Fri)
rule_text: The first two (2) hours of overtime per day, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at one and one half (1½) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday-Friday), the first two hours of overtime worked per day are paid at 1.5 times the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF daily_overtime_hours <= 2 AND day IN ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri'] -> PAY(1.5x)
reasoning: This rule specifies the pay rate for a specific bucket of overtime hours, which is a key function of classifying worked time.

name: Daily Overtime Tier 2 (Mon-Fri)
rule_text: All other overtime hours, Monday through Friday inclusive, shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On weekdays (Monday-Friday), any overtime hours worked beyond the first two are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF daily_overtime_hours > 2 AND day IN ['Mon', 'Tue', 'Wed', 'Thu', 'Fri'] -> PAY(2.0x)
reasoning: This rule establishes the pay rate for a secondary tier of overtime hours, which is a direct rule about categorizing and paying for worked time.

name: Weekend and Statutory Holiday Pay Rate
rule_text: All hours worked on Saturday, Sunday and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at two (2) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: All hours worked on Saturdays, Sundays, and Statutory Holidays are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF day IN ['Sat', 'Sun'] OR is_stat_holiday == True -> PAY(2.0x)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for specific days of the week and holidays, which is a special condition for categorizing worked time.

name: Commercial/Institutional Overtime Definition and Rate
rule_text: All hours worked in excess of eight (8) hours per day or forty (40) hours per week will be considered to be overtime hours and will be paid at the rate of one and one-half times the applicable rate of pay...
summary: For Commercial/Institutional work, any hours over 8 per day or 40 per week are considered overtime and are paid at 1.5 times the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'Commercial/Institutional' AND (daily_hours > 8 OR weekly_hours > 40) -> TRANSITION(OT) AND PAY(1.5x)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific overtime threshold and pay rate for a particular category of work, directly relating to the classification of worked time.

name: Commercial/Institutional Sunday and Holiday Rate
rule_text: ...except for work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays which will be paid at double time.
summary: For Commercial/Institutional work, all hours worked on Sundays and Statutory Holidays are paid at double the regular rate.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'Commercial/Institutional' AND (day == 'Sun' OR is_stat_holiday == True) -> PAY(2.0x)
reasoning: This rule is an exception that defines a special pay rate for specific days under a particular work category, which is a core aspect of worked time classification.

name: Overtime Calculation Timing
rule_text: For  the  purposes  of  calculating  overtime  hours,  overtime  shall  normally  be  paid  upon  the completion  of  the  regular  days  shift.
summary: Overtime is typically calculated and paid for hours worked after the end of the regular daily shift.
logical_representation: IF hours_worked > regular_shift_hours -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule clarifies the standard trigger for daily overtime calculation, which is essential for categorizing hours worked during a day.

name: Pre-Shift Work as Overtime
rule_text: When  an  Employee  is  required  to  work  prior  to  the commencement of their regular shift, such time shall be considered as overtime.
summary: Any time an employee is required to work before their regular shift starts is automatically considered overtime.
logical_representation: IF work_start_time < scheduled_start_time -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies a special condition where hours worked are categorized as overtime regardless of the daily total, directly impacting time classification.

name: CWW Normal Day Definition
rule_text: The maximum of ten (10) hours shall constitute a normal day's work beginning at 7:00 AM and ending by 6:00 PM (except when one-half (½) hour lunch is taken in which case the normal day will end at 5:30 PM).
summary: For a compressed work week, a normal day is a maximum of 10 hours, typically scheduled between 7:00 AM and 6:00 PM. The end time is adjusted for a 30-minute lunch break.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> DEFINE(normal_day_hours, MAX(10)) AND DEFINE(normal_day_schedule, {start: '07:00', end: '18:00', end_with_lunch: '17:30'})
reasoning: This rule defines the standard hours and schedule for a workday within a specific work arrangement (Compressed Work Week), which is fundamental to categorizing worked time.

name: CWW Normal Week Definition
rule_text: The maximum normal work week shall be forty (40) hours beginning Monday at 7:00 AM and ending Thursday at 6:00 PM.
summary: For a compressed work week, the normal work week is a maximum of 40 hours, scheduled from Monday morning to Thursday evening.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> DEFINE(normal_week_hours, MAX(40)) AND DEFINE(normal_week_schedule, {start_day: 'Monday', start_time: '07:00', end_day: 'Thursday', end_time: '18:00'})
reasoning: This rule defines the standard weekly hours and schedule for a Compressed Work Week, which is a core component of how worked time is categorized and paid.

name: No Guarantee of Hours
rule_text: The above schedule is intended to represent a normal workday or work week and is not to be construed as a guarantee of hours of work per day or per week or with respect to days in a week.
summary: The defined work schedules are not a guarantee of work; the employer is not obligated to provide a specific number of hours or days of work.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(guaranteed_hours, FALSE)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition on the provision of work hours, clarifying that there is no minimum guarantee, which affects how time and pay are administered.

name: Minor Start Time Variation
rule_text: The Employer may vary the start/quit times by changing the scheduled starting time up to thirty minutes at their option.
summary: The employer has the right to change the scheduled start time by up to 30 minutes.
logical_representation: IF schedule_start_time_variance_minutes <= 30 -> ALLOW(employer_discretion)
reasoning: This rule pertains to the definition and modification of a work schedule, which is a key aspect of managing and categorizing worked hours.

name: Major Start Time Variation
rule_text: Variances beyond thirty minutes shall be agreed mutually by the Employer and the Business Representative of the Union.
summary: Any change to the start time greater than 30 minutes requires mutual agreement between the employer and the Union Representative.
logical_representation: IF schedule_start_time_variance_minutes > 30 -> REQUIRE(mutual_agreement)
reasoning: This rule establishes the conditions under which a work schedule can be significantly altered, directly impacting the definition of worked time.

name: Consistent Application of Schedule Changes
rule_text: A change in start/quit times shall be applied consistently on the jobsite
summary: Any changes to start or quit times must be applied consistently across the entire jobsite.
logical_representation: IF is_schedule_change == TRUE -> REQUIRE(consistent_application_on_jobsite)
reasoning: This rule governs the implementation of work schedules, ensuring fairness and consistency in how worked hours are structured.

name: Split Shift Prohibition
rule_text: in no circumstances shall split shifts be created, unless mutually agreed between the parties.
summary: Creating split shifts is prohibited unless both the employer and the union mutually agree to it.
logical_representation: IF is_split_shift == TRUE -> REQUIRE(mutual_agreement)
reasoning: This rule places a constraint on the types of work schedules that can be implemented, which is a fundamental aspect of defining worked time.

name: 4x10 CWW Schedule
rule_text: The Employer may schedule the regular work week in four (4) consecutive ten (10) hour days, at straight time rates, provided only that the four (4) ten (10) hour days are scheduled during the Monday through Thursday period unless varied by mutual consent between the Employer and the Union.
summary: The employer can implement a 4-day, 10-hour/day compressed work week at straight time, scheduled Monday to Thursday, unless a different schedule is mutually agreed upon.
logical_representation: ALLOW(schedule_4x10) | IF schedule_4x10 -> PAY(hours_0_to_10, ST) AND DEFINE(work_days, ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday']) UNLESS mutual_agreement
reasoning: This rule defines a specific, pre-approved work schedule (4x10) and its associated pay rate (straight time), which is a core function of categorizing worked time.

name: Consent for Schedule Variation
rule_text: Such consent will not be unreasonably withheld.
summary: When mutual consent is required to vary a work schedule, it cannot be unreasonably denied by either party.
logical_representation: IF is_consent_required == TRUE -> CONSTRAINT(withholding_consent, 'must_be_reasonable')
reasoning: This rule places a condition on the process of modifying work schedules, which is integral to defining how worked time is structured.

name: Friday Pay on a 4x10 Schedule
rule_text: On a four (4) ten (10) schedule, when Friday is worked, the first ten hours shall be paid at one and oneha1f (1½x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If an employee on a 4x10 (Mon-Thurs) schedule works on a Friday, the first 10 hours are paid at time-and-a-half.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '4x10' AND day_of_week == 'Friday' -> PAY(hours_0_to_10, 1.5)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific overtime rate for a particular day (Friday) under a defined schedule (4x10), directly impacting worked time calculations.

name: 10-4 CWW Schedule Definition
rule_text: A ten (10) on and four (4) off schedule may also be established as a compressed work week schedule and when utilized, the straight time days will be Tuesday through Friday in one week followed by Monday through Thursday in the subsequent week.
summary: A 10-days-on, 4-days-off compressed work week is a valid schedule. The straight-time days are Tuesday-Friday in the first week and Monday-Thursday in the second week.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' -> DEFINE(straight_time_days, {week_1: ['Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday', 'Friday'], week_2: ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday']})
reasoning: This rule defines the structure of an alternative compressed work week, including which days are considered standard workdays. This is a primary rule for categorizing worked time.

name: 10-4 CWW Days Off Pay Rate
rule_text: Should an employee work on the scheduled days off, the Friday and Monday will be paid at time and one half (1½x), and the Saturday and Sunday will be paid at double time (2x).
summary: On a 10-on, 4-off schedule, work on the scheduled days off is paid at 1.5x for Friday and Monday, and 2x for Saturday and Sunday.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND is_scheduled_day_off == TRUE -> IF day_of_week IN ['Friday', 'Monday'] -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, 1.5); IF day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule specifies distinct premium pay rates for working on scheduled days off within a specific schedule, directly impacting labor cost calculations for worked time.

name: 10-4 CWW Optional Weekend Overtime
rule_text: When a ten (10) on and four (4) off schedule is utilized, overtime on the Saturday and Sunday that fall in the middle of the schedule will be optional.
summary: For a 10-on, 4-off schedule, working overtime on the Saturday and Sunday that occur mid-schedule is optional for the employee.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == '10_on_4_off' AND day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] -> overtime_work == OPTIONAL
reasoning: This rule defines a condition on the obligation to work, making certain overtime hours optional. This is a key aspect of scheduling and managing worked time.

name: Notice to Decline Optional Overtime
rule_text: Employees will be required to give seventy-two (72) hours' notice of their intention not to work such overtime.
summary: To decline optional weekend overtime on a 10/4 schedule, employees must provide 72 hours' notice.
logical_representation: IF intent_to_decline_optional_overtime == TRUE -> REQUIRE(notice_period_hours, 72)
reasoning: This rule establishes a procedural requirement for managing optional work hours, which is part of the overall system for scheduling worked time.

name: Consequence for No-Show on Optional OT
rule_text: Failure to provide the required notice and report for work shall be considered absenteeism.
summary: If an employee fails to give 72 hours' notice and does not show up for the optional weekend overtime, it will be treated as an absence.
logical_representation: IF declined_optional_overtime_notice_given == FALSE AND reported_for_work == FALSE -> CLASSIFY(event, 'absenteeism')
reasoning: This rule defines the consequence of failing to follow the procedure for optional work, classifying the event as absenteeism, which affects an employee's work record.

name: Declining Optional OT Does Not Preclude Other OT
rule_text: Exercising this option will not preclude an employee's opportunity to work other premium days when available.
summary: Choosing not to work optional weekend overtime does not prevent an employee from being offered other overtime opportunities.
logical_representation: IF declined_optional_overtime == TRUE -> CONSTRAINT(future_overtime_opportunity, 'not_precluded')
reasoning: This rule protects an employee's eligibility for future overtime work, which is a condition related to the administration of worked hours.

name: CWW Daily Overtime Rate
rule_text: Where these options are worked, all hours in excess of ten (10) hours per day Monday through Thursday, shall be paid for at two (2x) times the applicable rate of pay.
summary: On a compressed work week schedule, any hours worked beyond 10 per day from Monday to Thursday are paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK AND day_of_week IN ['Monday', 'Tuesday', 'Wednesday', 'Thursday'] AND daily_hours > 10 -> PAY(hours_after_10, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific daily overtime threshold and a premium pay rate (double time) for compressed work weeks, a core component of calculating pay for worked time.

name: OT Rate, Commercial/Institutional Projects
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, all overtime hours on Commercial/Institutional projects shall be paid for at the rate of time and one-half
summary: As an exception, all overtime hours on Commercial or Institutional projects are paid at 1.5 times the regular rate, overriding other overtime rules.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['Commercial', 'Institutional'] -> PAY(OT, 1.5)
reasoning: This rule sets a specific overtime pay rate based on the type of project, directly impacting the calculation of labor costs for worked time.

name: OT Rate Exception, Local 488 Jurisdiction
rule_text: except for work in Local 488's jurisdiction where work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays shall be paid at double time.
summary: On Commercial or Institutional projects within Local 488's jurisdiction, work on Sundays and Statutory Holidays is paid at double time.
logical_representation: IF project_type IN ['Commercial', 'Institutional'] AND jurisdiction == 'Local_488' AND day_of_week IN ['Sunday', 'Statutory_Holiday'] -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, 2.0)
reasoning: This rule defines an exceptional pay rate for specific days and a specific location, overriding other rules. It is a core rule for worked time calculation.

name: Notice of Schedule Change
rule_text: When job circumstances merit a change in the hours of work, the Employer shall notify the Union office at least seven (7) calendar days, where practical, before such change becomes effective.
summary: If job conditions require a change in work hours, the employer must notify the Union office at least 7 calendar days in advance, whenever practical.
logical_representation: IF is_schedule_change == TRUE AND is_practical == TRUE -> REQUIRE(union_notice_days, 7)
reasoning: This rule establishes a notification requirement for altering work schedules, which is a procedural aspect of managing worked time.

name: Mutual Agreement for Industrial Schedules
rule_text: The Union and the Employer will mutually agree to a work schedule to meet job conditions.
summary: On industrial job sites or under special conditions, the Union and Employer will mutually agree on a work schedule tailored to the job's needs.
logical_representation: IF project_type == 'Industrial' OR special_conditions == TRUE -> REQUIRE(mutual_agreement_on_schedule)
reasoning: This rule dictates that for certain job types, work schedules are not pre-defined but must be established by agreement, which is a fundamental rule for defining worked time in those situations.

name: Implementing Owner-Requested Schedules
rule_text: If a work schedule that is not currently addressed in the collective agreement is requested by the owner, the Parties' agreement to implement the work schedule as per the Owner's request which will not be unreasonably withheld.
summary: If a client (owner) requests a work schedule not covered in the agreement, the Union and Employer must agree to implement it and cannot unreasonably refuse.
logical_representation: IF is_owner_requested_schedule == TRUE AND is_schedule_in_agreement == FALSE -> REQUIRE(mutual_agreement) AND CONSTRAINT(withholding_agreement, 'must_be_reasonable')
reasoning: This rule provides a mechanism for creating new, ad-hoc work schedules based on client needs, directly impacting how worked time is structured and categorized.

name: Personal Leave Entitlement
rule_text: An employee who has not been absent, including late arrivals or early quits, or granted leave in the previous calendar 30 days, and who gives the Employer at least three working days' notice of a request for leave of up to one day, will be granted the requested leave.
summary: An employee is entitled to a personal leave day if they have a clean attendance record for the past 30 days and provide at least 3 working days' notice for the request.
logical_representation: IF perfect_attendance_prior_30_days == TRUE AND leave_request_notice_days >= 3 AND requested_leave_duration_days <= 1 -> ACTION(grant_leave)
reasoning: This rule defines an entitlement to time off from work, which directly relates to an employee's schedule and availability for worked hours.

name: Denial of Personal Leave
rule_text: Requests for time off that meet the above conditions will not be unreasonably denied subject to operational requirements.
summary: An employer cannot unreasonably deny a personal leave request that meets all conditions, but can deny it based on operational needs.
logical_representation: IF is_leave_request_valid == TRUE -> CONSTRAINT(denial_of_leave, 'must_be_reasonable_and_subject_to_operational_requirements')
reasoning: This rule places a condition on the employer's ability to manage employee schedules and time off, a key aspect of administering worked time.

name: OT Eligibility on Personal Leave Day
rule_text: A worker who is preauthorized to take personal time off pursuant to the above procedure, will qualify for overtime premiums for any work performed either preceding or following the normal scheduled hours of work on the day they take their personal absence regardless of whether or not they have worked the full eight or ten hours as scheduled for that shift.
summary: If an employee with pre-approved personal time off works extra hours on that same day, those hours qualify for overtime pay, even if they didn't work a full shift.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized == TRUE AND hours_worked_on_leave_day > 0 -> PAY(hours_worked_on_leave_day, OT)
reasoning: This rule specifies how overtime is calculated when an employee takes authorized leave, creating an exception to the standard daily threshold requirement. It is a specific calculation rule for worked time.

name: OT Eligibility on CWW Day Off with Leave
rule_text: In the case of a worker on a compressed work week schedule they would also be paid normal overtime premiums for any hours worked on the compressed work weekday off.
summary: For an employee on a compressed work week, any hours worked on their scheduled day off (e.g., Friday) will be paid at overtime rates, especially in the context of taking pre-authorized leave.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK AND is_cww_day_off == TRUE -> PAY(ALL_HOURS, OT)
reasoning: This rule clarifies the pay rate for working on a specific day within a compressed work week schedule, directly impacting the calculation of pay for worked time.

name: Weekly OT Eligibility with Personal Leave
rule_text: It is also understood that, provided such absences conform to these conditions, the absence will not disqualify the worker from working overtime scheduled for that week.
summary: Taking a pre-approved personal day off does not disqualify an employee from working other scheduled overtime during that same week.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized == TRUE -> CONSTRAINT(weekly_overtime_eligibility, 'not_disqualified')
reasoning: This rule ensures that authorized leave does not negatively impact an employee's eligibility for overtime work, which is a key condition for managing worked time.

name: Standard Daily OT Threshold
rule_text: Overtime premiums as specified in this Collective Agreement will be paid for all hours worked in excess of eight hours in a day.
summary: For a standard work schedule, overtime pay applies to all hours worked beyond eight in a single day.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == STANDARD -> IF daily_hours > 8 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the fundamental daily threshold for overtime on a standard schedule, which is a primary determinant in categorizing worked time.

name: CWW OT Thresholds
rule_text: In the case of a compressed work week, overtime premiums will be paid for hours worked in excess of ten in a day or forty in a week.
summary: For a compressed work week, overtime is paid for hours worked over 10 in a day or over 40 in a week.
logical_representation: IF schedule_type == COMPRESSED_WORK_WEEK -> (IF daily_hours > 10 -> TRANSITION(OT)) OR (IF weekly_hours > 40 -> TRANSITION(OT))
reasoning: This rule specifies the daily and weekly thresholds that trigger overtime pay for a compressed work week, a core calculation for worked time.

name: Consequences of Unexcused Absence
rule_text: A worker that is absent from work without pre-authorization as per the above procedure, including late arrivals or early quits will be subject to discipline in accordance with their employer's policies and may also be disqualified from working scheduled overtime in the week the absence occurs.
summary: An employee with an unexcused absence (including being late or leaving early) may face disciplinary action and may lose the opportunity to work scheduled overtime for that week.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized == FALSE -> ACTION(may_be_disciplined) AND ACTION(may_forfeit_weekly_overtime)
reasoning: This rule links attendance (a component of worked time) to eligibility for future work (overtime), establishing a condition for earning premium pay.

name: OT Qualification After Unexcused Absence (Daily)
rule_text: Workers who are absent from work without pre-authorization, must work the minimum normal hours as stipulated above prior to overtime premiums being paid.
summary: After an unexcused absence, an employee must first work their full normal shift hours (e.g., 8 or 10) before any subsequent hours on that day can be paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_preauthorized == FALSE -> REQUIRE(work_hours_for_ot_eligibility, daily_st_threshold)
reasoning: This rule establishes a condition for earning daily overtime pay, requiring employees with unexcused absences to 'make up' straight time hours first. It's a direct calculation rule for worked time.

name: Weekly OT with Excusable Absences
rule_text: All overtime hours per the work week will be payable if the scheduled straight time hours and overtime hours are worked as per the work week schedule, excluding excusable absences hours missed.
summary: Weekly overtime is paid if the employee works all their scheduled hours; hours missed due to an excusable absence do not count against meeting the weekly threshold.
logical_representation: IF (weekly_hours_worked + excusable_absence_hours) >= weekly_hours_scheduled -> PAY(weekly_ot)
reasoning: This rule defines how absences affect the calculation of weekly overtime, specifying that 'excusable' absences do not penalize the worker. This is a key calculation rule for worked time.

name: OT Qualification After Unexcused Absence (Weekly)
rule_text: If scheduled straight time hours are missed due to unexcused absences the worker must work their straight time hours scheduled before overtime hours are earned.
summary: If an employee has an unexcused absence during the week, they must work their full scheduled number of straight-time hours before any weekly overtime is paid.
logical_representation: IF is_absence_unexcused == TRUE -> REQUIRE(work_hours_for_weekly_ot_eligibility, weekly_st_threshold)
reasoning: This rule creates a condition for earning weekly overtime pay, stating that unexcused missed time must be made up first. This directly impacts the calculation and categorization of worked time.

name: Excusable Absence Definition
rule_text: The employee will notify the employer prior to shift start time, to be accepted as an excusable absence when circumstances arise beyond the workers' control.
summary: For an absence to be considered excusable, the employee must notify the employer before their shift starts, and the reason must be beyond their control.
logical_representation: IF absence_reason == 'beyond_control' AND notification_timing == 'before_shift_start' -> CLASSIFY(absence, 'excusable')
reasoning: This rule defines the criteria for an 'excusable absence,' a status that directly affects overtime calculations and other worked time entitlements.

name: Call Out Eligibility
rule_text: Employees who have completed the day's scheduled hours of work and left the jobsite to return home or to camp and who respond to a request to work additional time, shall be compensated as follows.
summary: This rule defines the conditions for an employee to be eligible for call-out pay: they must have finished their regular shift, left the jobsite, and then be asked to return for more work.
logical_representation: IF scheduled_hours_completed == true AND has_left_jobsite == true AND is_requested_to_return == true -> QUALIFY(CALL_OUT_PAY)
reasoning: This rule establishes the prerequisite conditions for a work period to be classified and paid as a 'Call Out'. This classification of time is a core function of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Call Out Minimum, No Work Commenced
rule_text: Employees who do not commence work shall be paid for two (2) hours at the applicable overtime rate, and any travel and transportation applicable.
summary: If an employee is called out but does not actually start working, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours of pay at the overtime rate, plus any applicable travel costs.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out == true AND work_commenced == false -> PAY(MIN(2_HOURS_OT)) AND PAY(TRAVEL_TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule specifies a minimum pay guarantee for a specific work scenario (a call out where no work is performed). Minimum guarantees for hours worked fall under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Call Out Minimum, Work Commenced
rule_text: Employees who are called in and commence work shall be paid for a minimum of three (3) hours at the applicable overtime rate and any travel and transportation applicable.
summary: If an employee is called out and begins working, they are guaranteed a minimum of three hours of pay at the overtime rate, plus any applicable travel costs, even if they work for less than three hours.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out == true AND work_commenced == true -> PAY(MIN(3_HOURS_OT)) AND PAY(TRAVEL_TRANSPORTATION)
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for hours worked during a call out. Rules about minimum paid hours are a key aspect of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Call Out Exceeding Minimum
rule_text: Where an Employee works more than the three (3) hours set out in 18.01 (b) above, the Employee shall receive remuneration for the hours actually worked at the applicable overtime rates and any travel or transportation applicable.
summary: If an employee on a call-out works longer than the three-hour minimum, they will be paid for the actual number of hours they worked at overtime rates, not just the minimum.
logical_representation: IF is_call_out == true AND actual_hours_worked > 3 -> PAY(actual_hours_worked * OT_RATE)
reasoning: This rule dictates how hours are calculated and paid when they exceed a specified minimum. This calculation and categorization of worked time is central to the LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Mandatory Rest Period After Call Out
rule_text: In the event that an Employee, responding to a call out does not get an eight (8) hour break, prior to the commencement of their regular workday, the Employee(s) shall be allowed an eight (8) hour rest break and be paid for a normally scheduled workday.
summary: If a call-out ends less than eight hours before an employee's next regular shift, they are entitled to a full eight-hour rest break and will still be paid for their missed regular shift.
logical_representation: IF hours_between_call_out_end_and_next_shift < 8 -> PROVIDE(8_HOUR_REST_BREAK) AND PAY(NORMAL_SCHEDULED_WORKDAY)
reasoning: This rule concerns rest periods and the payment for a regular shift that is not worked due to that rest period. The payment for non-worked scheduled time is a specific rule about time categorization, fitting it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Rest Period Pay Qualification
rule_text: To qualify for the normally scheduled days pay the Employee shall be available for work at the end of the eight (8) hour break.
summary: To receive pay for the regular shift missed due to a mandatory rest break, the employee must be ready and available to work immediately after their eight-hour rest period is over.
logical_representation: IF received_paid_rest_break == true AND is_available_for_work_after_break == false -> FORFEIT(NORMAL_SCHEDULED_WORKDAY_PAY)
reasoning: This is a condition tied directly to the payment for a scheduled workday, as described in the previous rule. Since it governs the entitlement to pay for a block of time, it falls under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Work, Minimum Requirements
rule_text: when shift work is performed at least two (2) full shifts must be worked in any twenty-four (24) hour period and each of these shifts must continue for at least five (5) consecutive regular working days, or four (4) consecutive regular working days where the four (4) ten (10) hour day option is being utilized.
summary: To be considered official 'shift work', there must be at least two full shifts within a 24-hour period, and these shifts must run for at least 5 consecutive days (or 4 days on a 4x10 schedule).
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: is_shift_work == TRUE REQUIRES (shifts_in_24h >= 2) AND ((work_schedule_type == '5x8' AND shift_consecutive_days >= 5) OR (work_schedule_type == '4x10' AND shift_consecutive_days >= 4))
reasoning: This rule defines the conditions under which a work schedule is classified as "shift work," which directly impacts how hours are categorized and paid.

name: Shift Work, Penalty for Short Duration
rule_text: Should each of the shifts outlined above not continue for a period of four (4) or five (5) consecutive working days, all hours worked shall be deemed overtime and paid at the applicable rates contained in this Agreement.
summary: If a shift schedule does not last for the required minimum of 4 or 5 consecutive days, all hours worked on that shift must be paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF is_shift_work == TRUE AND has_mutual_agreement_for_short_shift == FALSE AND ((work_schedule_type == '5x8' AND shift_consecutive_days < 5) OR (work_schedule_type == '4x10' AND shift_consecutive_days < 4)) -> TRANSITION(ALL_HOURS_OT)
reasoning: This rule dictates a specific condition under which all worked hours must be re-categorized from straight time to overtime.

name: Shift Work, Premium on Partial Weeks
rule_text: Where a shift is commenced and has run for at least the four (4) or five (5) consecutive days referred to above, should the shift terminate in the middle of the week, or an Employee hires on in a week in which a shift ends, affected Employee(s) shall only be entitled to shift premium on regular hours of work.
summary: If a valid shift ends mid-week or an employee starts during a week when a shift ends, the shift premium is only paid on their regular, non-overtime hours.
logical_representation: IF (shift_ends_midweek == TRUE OR employee_hires_on_shift_end_week == TRUE) AND hours_type == 'ST' -> PAY(SHIFT_PREMIUM)
reasoning: This rule specifies how a pay premium (shift differential) is applied to different categories of hours (regular vs. overtime) under specific circumstances.

name: Shift Work, Short Duration by Mutual Agreement
rule_text: By mutual agreement, shifts may be established for periods of less than four (4) or five (5) consecutive regular working days and in such an event, the deemed overtime that would otherwise be payable shall not apply.
summary: If both the employer and employees agree, shifts can be set up for less than the usual 4 or 5-day minimum without triggering the penalty that turns all hours into overtime.
logical_representation: IF is_mutual_agreement == TRUE -> FORFEIT(ALL_HOURS_OT_PENALTY_FOR_SHORT_SHIFT)
reasoning: This rule provides an exception to a time categorization rule (the overtime penalty), which is a core function of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Shift Work, First Shift Overtime
rule_text: The first shift shall work a normal shift as set out in Clause 16.01 and/or 17.01 of this Agreement, with the applicable overtime rate after eight (8) hours of work or in excess of ten (10) hours per day during a compressed work week.
summary: The first shift (day shift) is paid overtime for hours worked beyond 8 hours on a standard schedule, or beyond 10 hours on a compressed work week schedule.
logical_representation: IF shift_number == 1 AND ((work_schedule_type == '5x8' AND daily_hours > 8) OR (work_schedule_type == '4x10' AND daily_hours > 10)) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the daily thresholds for when straight time transitions to overtime, which is a fundamental aspect of categorizing worked time.

name: Shift Work, Alternate Shift Start Times
rule_text: Shift work other than the normal shift as outlined in Clause 19.03 may be utilized provided such shift(s) commence between 3.00 PM and 6.00 AM.
summary: Any shift other than the normal day shift must start between 3:00 PM and 6:00 AM to be considered a valid alternate shift.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: shift_type == 'alternate' REQUIRES shift_start_time BETWEEN '15:00' AND '06:00'
reasoning: This rule defines the parameters of a specific work schedule (alternate shift), which is essential for categorizing the time worked within it.

name: Shift Work, Alternate Shift Premium 2025
rule_text: The hourly rate for Employees on any alternate shift(s) as outlined above shall be $4.00 per hour effective May 4 th , 2025... greater than the applicable day time rate of pay.
summary: Starting May 4, 2025, employees working on an alternate shift receive a premium of $4.00 per hour on top of their regular daytime pay rate.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'alternate' AND effective_date >= '2025-05-04' AND effective_date < '2026-05-03' -> PREMIUM($4.00)
reasoning: This rule defines a pay premium applied to hours worked under specific conditions (alternate shift), which falls under worked time and pay calculation.

name: Shift Work, Alternate Shift Premium 2026
rule_text: ...($4.50 effective May 3, 2026) greater than the applicable day time rate of pay.
summary: Starting May 3, 2026, the premium for employees working on an alternate shift increases to $4.50 per hour on top of their regular daytime pay rate.
logical_representation: IF shift_type == 'alternate' AND effective_date >= '2026-05-03' -> PREMIUM($4.50)
reasoning: This rule defines a pay premium applied to hours worked under specific conditions (alternate shift), which falls under worked time and pay calculation.

name: Shift Work, Rate Cap
rule_text: In no event shall this hourly rate be greater than the applicable overtime rate plus shift differential.
summary: The total hourly pay for an alternate shift cannot exceed the standard overtime rate plus the shift differential.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: alternate_shift_hourly_rate <= (overtime_rate + shift_differential)
reasoning: This rule establishes a ceiling on the calculation of pay rates for worked hours, a key aspect of labor worked time rules.

name: Shift Work, One ST Shift per 24 Hours
rule_text: No Employee shall work more than one (1) straight time shift in each consecutive twenty-four (24) hour period.
summary: An employee cannot work more than one regular, straight-time shift in any 24-hour period.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT: straight_time_shifts_in_24h <= 1
reasoning: This is a rule governing work schedules and the categorization of shifts (as straight time), which is a LABOR_WORKED_TIME topic.

name: Shift Work, Insufficient Rest Period
rule_text: An Employee shall continue to receive the overtime rate, plus shift differential, after each shift until a break of eight (8) consecutive hours occurs, exclusive of travel allowance.
summary: If an employee does not get at least an 8-hour break between shifts, all hours they work until that break is taken must be paid at the overtime rate plus shift differential.
logical_representation: IF break_between_shifts_hours < 8 -> PAY(OT + SHIFT_DIFFERENTIAL)
reasoning: This rule re-categorizes hours from straight time to overtime based on the duration of the rest period between work periods.

name: Shift Work, Pay for Lost Day on Schedule Change
rule_text: When an Employee loses a regular day through the implementation or termination of shift work, then the Employee shall be paid a regular days pay for the day lost.
summary: If an employee loses a scheduled workday because a shift schedule is starting or ending, they must be paid for that lost day.
logical_representation: IF workday_lost_due_to_shift_change == TRUE -> PAY(REGULAR_DAY_PAY)
reasoning: This rule provides a pay guarantee under specific scheduling conditions, which relates to how time and compensation are handled.

name: Shift Work, Irregular Single Shift Premium
rule_text: Where the owner/client may require work to be done on a single shift basis at start/quit times that may be at variance with the start/quit for a regular shift, single shift operations shall be permitted subject to the payment of shift differential. The shift differential shall be paid on all hours worked.
summary: If the client requires a single shift with non-standard start and end times, this is allowed, but a shift differential must be paid for all hours worked on that shift.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift == TRUE -> PAY(SHIFT_DIFFERENTIAL_ON_ALL_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay conditions (application of a premium) for a specific type of work schedule, which is a LABOR_WORKED_TIME classification.

name: Irregular Single Shift, Daily Overtime
rule_text: Overtime shall be payable on all hours in excess of eight (8) hours per day, or in excess of ten (10) hours per day during a compressed work week...
summary: For irregular single shifts, overtime is paid for all hours worked beyond 8 in a day, or beyond 10 in a day if it's a compressed work week.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift == TRUE AND ((work_schedule_type == '5x8' AND daily_hours > 8) OR (work_schedule_type == '4x10' AND daily_hours > 10)) -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the daily hour threshold for when work transitions from straight time to overtime.

name: Irregular Single Shift, Weekly Overtime
rule_text: Overtime shall be payable on all hours in excess of... forty (40) hours per week...
summary: For irregular single shifts, overtime is paid for all hours worked beyond 40 in a week.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift == TRUE AND weekly_hours > 40 -> TRANSITION(OT)
reasoning: This rule defines the weekly hour threshold for when work transitions from straight time to overtime.

name: Irregular Single Shift, Special Day Overtime
rule_text: Overtime shall be payable on all hours... on Saturdays, Sundays, or Statutory Holidays.
summary: For irregular single shifts, all hours worked on Saturdays, Sundays, or Statutory Holidays are paid as overtime.
logical_representation: IF is_irregular_single_shift == TRUE AND (day_of_week IN ['Saturday', 'Sunday'] OR is_statutory_holiday == TRUE) -> TRANSITION(ALL_HOURS_OT)
reasoning: This rule defines specific days on which all hours worked are automatically categorized as overtime.

name: Overtime Meal Provision
rule_text: Where Employees are required to work in excess of ten (10) hours in a single shift, they shall be provided immediately after ten (10) hours, with a suitable meal (hot where possible) and every four (4) hours thereafter until the shift is ended.
summary: If an employee works more than 10 hours, the employer must provide a meal right after the 10th hour, and then another meal every 4 hours after that until the shift ends.
logical_representation: IF shift_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(MEAL) AND AFTER(10_HOURS) MEAL_TRIG(EVERY_4_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule specifies the conditions and frequency for providing a meal, which is a core entitlement under meal allowances.

name: Paid Meal Break
rule_text: The cost of the meal(s) and the time consuming same shall be paid for at the straight time rates contained in this Agreement, to a maximum of one half (½) hour in duration.
summary: The time taken to eat a provided overtime meal is paid at straight time rates for up to 30 minutes.
logical_representation: IF MEAL_PROVIDED -> PAY(MAX(0.5_HOURS_ST))
reasoning: This rule dictates that a specific period of time (the meal break) is paid, which directly relates to how worked time is accounted for and compensated.

name: Subsistence and Meal Clause
rule_text: Where the Employer is paying subsistence, this clause shall also apply.
summary: The overtime meal rules apply even when an employee is receiving subsistence pay.
logical_representation: IF is_receiving_subsistence == true -> APPLY_CLAUSE(20.01)
reasoning: The rule explicitly links the state of receiving subsistence to the application of the meal allowance clause, making it a condition for the meal entitlement.

name: Meal Allowance in Lieu of Meal
rule_text: On projects when it is impractical for the contractor to provide a meal the employee shall be paid a 15-minute paid break at the applicable rate of pay and the employer shall pay a meal allowance of $45.00 in lieu of the meal and the time to consume the meal.
summary: If it's not practical to provide a meal, the employee gets a $45.00 meal allowance and a 15-minute paid break instead.
logical_representation: IF is_meal_provided == false -> MEAL_AMT($45) AND PAY(0.25_HOURS)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific monetary allowance ($45.00) to be paid under certain conditions, which is the primary function of a meal allowance rule.

name: Meal Allowance Exception (Camp)
rule_text: Where a shift in excess of 10 hours but not longer than 12 hours is worked, when camp accommodations are provided and a full course hot supper is provided at the end of the shift, no meal allowance shall be payable.
summary: For shifts between 10 and 12 hours, if the employee is in a camp and gets a hot supper after the shift, no overtime meal or allowance is provided.
logical_representation: IF shift_hours > 10 AND shift_hours <= 12 AND is_camp_provided == true AND is_supper_provided == true -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific condition under which an employee forfeits their entitlement to a meal allowance, making it a direct modification of meal allowance rules.

name: Break Time Adjustments (Camp)
rule_text: When such shifts are worked, break times may be adjusted for efficiency and reasonableness. In such cases the Union will be notified prior to the breaks being adjusted.
summary: On 10-12 hour shifts with camp accommodations, break times can be adjusted for efficiency after notifying the Union.
logical_representation: IF shift_hours > 10 AND shift_hours <= 12 AND is_camp_provided == true -> ALLOW(ADJUST_BREAKS) AND NOTIFY(UNION)
reasoning: This rule concerns the scheduling and adjustment of break times during the workday, which falls under the category of labor worked time.

name: Unscheduled Overtime Meal Exception
rule_text: Recognizing emergency or unplanned situations may arise intermittently, if the Contractor has not scheduled in excess of the ten (10) hour shift, the Contractor shall be granted a one (1) hour extension where the Contractor need not supply a hot meal or make payment in lieu of
summary: If overtime is unscheduled and the shift extends up to 11 hours (a one-hour extension), the employer does not have to provide a meal or pay an allowance.
logical_representation: IF is_overtime_scheduled == false AND shift_hours > 10 AND shift_hours <= 11 -> FORFEIT(MEAL_ALLOWANCE)
reasoning: This rule creates an exception that directly negates the meal or meal allowance obligation under specific circumstances (unscheduled overtime).

name: Paid Break for Unscheduled Overtime
rule_text: however; a fifteen (15) minute rest break paid at the applicable rate will be taken at the tenth (10 th ) hour.
summary: During the one-hour extension for unscheduled overtime (between 10 and 11 hours), employees must receive a 15-minute paid rest break at the 10-hour mark.
logical_representation: IF is_overtime_scheduled == false AND shift_hours > 10 -> PROVIDE(PAID_BREAK(0.25_HOURS))
reasoning: The rule mandates a paid rest break, which is an element of compensated work time, fitting the LABOR_WORKED_TIME classification.

name: Hard Limit on Meal Exception
rule_text: Under no circumstance shall any Employee work more than eleven (11) hours without adherence to Clause 20.01.
summary: The exception for not providing a meal during unscheduled overtime ends at 11 hours. If work continues past 11 hours, the standard meal rules (Clause 20.01) must be followed.
logical_representation: IF shift_hours > 11 -> APPLY_CLAUSE(20.01)
reasoning: This rule sets a strict boundary on an exception to the meal allowance rules, thereby enforcing the meal allowance entitlement after a specific threshold.

name: Supervisor Meal Provision Exception
rule_text: Where a supervisor is required to; (i) start up to one (1) hour earlier, or (ii) finish up to one (1) hour later, or (iii) start up to one half (½) hour earlier and finish up to one half (½) hour later than the supervisor's crew, for the purposes of organizing work or facilitating a transition to another shift, the provisions of 20.01 will not apply
summary: Supervisors who work slightly longer than their crew for prep or handover (e.g., up to an hour early/late) are not entitled to overtime meals under the standard rule (20.01).
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'supervisor' AND supervisor_extra_hours <= 1 -> FORFEIT(PROVISIONS_20_01)
reasoning: This rule specifically exempts a class of employee (supervisors) from the meal allowance provisions under defined conditions.

name: Supervisor Exception Override
rule_text: unless those provisions are applicable to the rest of the crew.
summary: The supervisor's exemption from overtime meals is voided if the rest of their crew also qualifies for and receives overtime meals.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'supervisor' AND crew_meal_eligibility == true -> APPLY_CLAUSE(20.01)
reasoning: This rule acts as a condition that restores the meal allowance entitlement for supervisors, making it a rule governing meal allowances.

name: Show Up Time Minimum Pay
rule_text: When an Employee reports to work at the regular starting time and such Employee is not put to work,  the  Employee  so  affected  shall  be  entitled  to  a  minimum  of  two  (2)  hours  pay  at  the applicable rate of pay.
summary: If an employee reports for their regular shift but is not given work, they are guaranteed a minimum of two hours' pay.
logical_representation: IF reports_to_work_at_regular_start_time AND not_put_to_work -> PAY(MIN(2_hours_at_applicable_rate))
reasoning: This rule establishes a minimum pay guarantee for reporting to work, which is a form of worked time compensation.

name: Show Up Time Qualification Condition
rule_text: In  order  to  qualify  for  show  up  time,  Employees  must  remain  on  the  jobsite  unless  otherwise directed by the Employer.
summary: To receive show-up pay, employees must stay at the jobsite unless told to leave by the employer.
logical_representation: IF qualifies_for_show_up_time -> CONSTRAINT(must_remain_on_jobsite)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition (remaining on site) for an entitlement related to worked time (show-up pay), making it fall under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Extended On-Site Wait Time Pay
rule_text: Where the Employee(s) are directed to remain at the jobsite for more than two (2) hours, including wait times for company supplied transportation to leave site, they shall be paid for such time at the applicable rate.
summary: If an employee is required to wait on the jobsite for more than two hours (including waiting for company transport), they must be paid for that entire waiting period.
logical_representation: IF directed_to_remain_on_jobsite AND time_on_jobsite > 2_hours -> PAY(time_on_jobsite_at_applicable_rate)
reasoning: This rule dictates how employees are paid for time spent waiting on a jobsite, which is a direct rule about compensable work time.

name: Show Up Time Travel and Subsistence
rule_text: Employee(s)  affected  shall  be  paid  daily  travel,  transportation,  subsistence  or  receive  camp accommodation as is applicable.
summary: Employees who qualify for show-up pay are also entitled to receive their applicable daily travel, transportation, or subsistence allowances, or camp accommodation.
logical_representation: IF qualifies_for_show_up_time -> PAY(applicable_daily_travel) OR PAY(applicable_transportation) OR PAY(applicable_subsistence) OR PROVIDE(camp_accommodation)
reasoning: The core of this rule is the entitlement to subsistence, travel, or camp benefits. Although triggered by a work-time event (show-up), the benefit itself falls under the category of subsistence and travel allowances.

name: Show Up Time Forfeiture by Prior Notice
rule_text: An Employee is not entitled to show up time if the Employer notifies the Employee that no work is available at least two (2) hours prior to the commencement of the normal workday.
summary: An employee does not get show-up pay if the employer tells them not to come in at least two hours before their shift starts.
logical_representation: IF employer_notifies_no_work AND notification_time >= 2_hours_prior_to_start_time -> FORFEIT(show_up_time_pay)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition under which a worked time entitlement (show-up pay) is forfeited, directly classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Show Up Time Forfeiture for Camp Employees
rule_text: Employees working on a jobsite where they are accommodated in a camp facility will not be entitled to show up time if they are notified that no work is available, at breakfast time, and notices are posted on the bulletin boards in the camp kitchen.
summary: Employees living in a camp do not get show-up pay if they are notified at breakfast, and a notice is posted in the camp kitchen, that there is no work.
logical_representation: IF is_camp_employee AND notified_at_breakfast AND notice_is_posted -> FORFEIT(show_up_time_pay)
reasoning: This is a specific exception to a worked time entitlement for a particular class of employee, making LABOR_WORKED_TIME the correct classification.

name: Show Up Time Shift Premium Inclusion
rule_text: When an Employee reporting for work qualifies for show up time such time shall include the regular shift premium when applicable.
summary: If an employee qualifies for show-up pay and would have normally received a shift premium, that premium must be included in the show-up pay calculation.
logical_representation: IF qualifies_for_show_up_time AND shift_premium_is_applicable -> PAY(show_up_time_with_shift_premium)
reasoning: This rule details the calculation of a worked time entitlement (show-up pay), specifically how premiums are applied, which is a core concept of LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Local Resident Definition
rule_text: A local resident is an individual who resides within a seventy-five (75) kilometer radius of the  centre  of  a  job  site  which  is  beyond  daily  commuting  distance  from  Edmonton  or Calgary or other locations where a hiring hall is located and, has resided within such radius of the site for a period of not less than six months prior to being engaged on the project.
summary: Defines a 'local resident' as someone living within a 75 km radius of a remote job site for at least six months before starting the project.
logical_representation: IF DIST <= 75km AND residency_duration >= 6_MONTHS AND job_site_is_remote == TRUE -> LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE)
reasoning: This rule defines the primary condition for eligibility for various travel and subsistence allowances, making it a foundational rule for that topic.

name: Entitlement Forfeiture, Local Resident < 45km
rule_text: Local Residents residing within a forty-five (45) km radius of the job site shall not be entitled to receive transportation or vehicle allowance, travel allowance, initial and return travel allowance, room and board, subsistence, camp accommodations, or rotational leave provisions.
summary: Local residents who live within a 45 km radius of the job site do not qualify for any travel, accommodation, or subsistence benefits.
logical_representation: IF LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST <= 45km -> FORFEIT(transportation_allowance) AND FORFEIT(vehicle_allowance) AND FORFEIT(travel_allowance) AND FORFEIT(initial_return_travel) AND FORFEIT(room_and_board) AND FORFEIT(subsistence) AND FORFEIT(camp_accommodations) AND FORFEIT(rotational_leave)
reasoning: This rule explicitly removes entitlement to various subsistence-related allowances based on a geographic condition.

name: Entitlement Forfeiture, Industrial Local Resident 45-75km
rule_text: Local residents residing between a forty-five (45) km radius and a seventy-five (75) km radius of the job site shall not be entitled to receive initial and return travel allowance, room and board or subsistence, or camp accommodations, or rotational leave provisions
summary: On industrial projects, local residents living between 45 and 75 km from the site do not qualify for initial/return travel, room and board, subsistence, camp, or rotational leave benefits.
logical_representation: IF project_type == INDUSTRIAL AND LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST > 45km AND DIST <= 75km -> FORFEIT(initial_return_travel) AND FORFEIT(room_and_board) AND FORFEIT(subsistence) AND FORFEIT(camp_accommodations) AND FORFEIT(rotational_leave)
reasoning: This rule explicitly removes entitlement to specific subsistence-related allowances based on a geographic condition and project type.

name: Travel Allowance, Industrial Local Resident 45-75km
rule_text: Local residents residing between a forty-five (45) km radius and a seventy-five (75) km radius of the job site ... shall be paid a travel allowance of thirty-three dollars ($33.00) per day worked ($36.00 per day worked effective May 4/09) to cover transportation expenses and travel allowance
summary: On industrial projects, local residents living between 45 and 75 km from the site receive a daily travel allowance of $33.00 ($36.00 after May 4, 2009).
logical_representation: IF project_type == INDUSTRIAL AND LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST > 45km AND DIST <= 75km AND effective_date < '2009-05-04' -> ALLOWANCE($33.00) | PER_DAY_WORKED || IF project_type == INDUSTRIAL AND LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST > 45km AND DIST <= 75km AND effective_date >= '2009-05-04' -> ALLOWANCE($36.00) | PER_DAY_WORKED
reasoning: This rule provides a specific monetary allowance for travel, a type of subsistence benefit, based on geographic conditions.

name: Reduced Travel Allowance (Employer Transport), Industrial Local Resident 45-75km
rule_text: if transportation is supplied by the Employer, a daily travel allowance of seventeen dollars ($17.00) ($19.00 per day worked effective May 4/09) will be paid for each day worked.
summary: On industrial projects, if the employer provides transportation for local residents living 45-75 km away, the daily travel allowance is reduced to $17.00 ($19.00 after May 4, 2009).
logical_representation: IF project_type == INDUSTRIAL AND LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST > 45km AND DIST <= 75km AND employer_transport_provided == TRUE AND effective_date < '2009-05-04' -> ALLOWANCE($17.00) | PER_DAY_WORKED || IF project_type == INDUSTRIAL AND LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND DIST > 45km AND DIST <= 75km AND employer_transport_provided == TRUE AND effective_date >= '2009-05-04' -> ALLOWANCE($19.00) | PER_DAY_WORKED
reasoning: This rule modifies a monetary travel allowance, a subsistence benefit, based on a specific condition (employer-provided transport).

name: Residency Definition, Anzac/Saprae Creek for North Fort McMurray Projects
rule_text: For the purposes of determining local residents in the Fort McMurray area, residents of Anzac and Saprae Creek will be considered to be residents of Fort McMurray for projects north of Fort McMurray
summary: When working on projects north of Fort McMurray, residents of Anzac and Saprae Creek are considered to be residents of Fort McMurray for determining local status.
logical_representation: IF project_location == NORTH_OF_FORT_MCMURRAY AND residence_location IN ['Anzac', 'Saprae Creek'] -> SET(residence_location, 'Fort McMurray')
reasoning: This is a definitional rule that directly impacts eligibility for subsistence and travel allowances by redefining an employee's residency location for calculation purposes.

name: Residency Definition, Fort McKay for South Fort McMurray Projects
rule_text: residents of Fort McKay will be considered to be residents of Fort McMurray for projects located south of Fort McMurray
summary: When working on projects south of Fort McMurray, residents of Fort McKay are considered to be residents of Fort McMurray for determining local status.
logical_representation: IF project_location == SOUTH_OF_FORT_MCMURRAY AND residence_location == 'Fort McKay' -> SET(residence_location, 'Fort McMurray')
reasoning: This is a definitional rule that directly impacts eligibility for subsistence and travel allowances by redefining an employee's residency location for calculation purposes.

name: Noon Meal for Local Residents (Camp Kitchen)
rule_text: Where a Camp Kitchen is established, and where all workers generally on the project who are not Local Residents attend at the Camp Kitchen to eat their lunches a Local Resident Employee shall be provided the same noon meal without cost to himself.
summary: If a camp kitchen provides lunch to non-local workers, local resident employees must also be given the same noon meal for free.
logical_representation: IF LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND camp_kitchen_exists == TRUE AND camp_kitchen_provides_lunch_to_non_locals == TRUE -> PROVIDE(noon_meal)
reasoning: This rule directly provides a meal entitlement under specific conditions, which is the core of the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Hot Soup for Local Residents (Bagged Lunches)
rule_text: In those instances where bagged lunches are provided to camp residents and hot soup is delivered to the jobsite, local residents shall be entitled to pick up hot soup as well.
summary: If camp residents get bagged lunches and hot soup is delivered to the site, local residents are also entitled to get the hot soup.
logical_representation: IF LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND bagged_lunches_provided_to_camp_residents == TRUE AND hot_soup_delivered_to_jobsite == TRUE -> PROVIDE(hot_soup)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific food item (hot soup) under certain conditions, making it a meal entitlement rule.

name: Overtime Meals for Local Residents
rule_text: Where a Local Resident Employee is required to work overtime, he shall be entitled to overtime meals in accordance with this Agreement.
summary: A local resident employee required to work overtime is entitled to overtime meals as specified elsewhere in the agreement.
logical_representation: IF LOCAL_RESIDENT(TRUE) AND overtime_worked == TRUE -> ENTITLED(overtime_meals)
reasoning: This rule establishes the right to overtime meals for a specific group of employees, directly falling under the LABOR_MEAL_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Process for Determining Local Status
rule_text: Where a question arises as to whether a candidate for employment qualified as a local resident, the designated representatives of the Employer and the Union shall determine the individual's  acceptability  as  to  residency  only.
summary: If there is a question about an individual's local resident status, designated representatives from the Employer and the Union will make the final determination on residency.
logical_representation: IF local_status_questioned == TRUE -> ACTION(employer_rep_and_union_rep_determine_residency)
reasoning: This rule defines the process for verifying eligibility for subsistence-related benefits, making it relevant to that topic.

name: Guidelines for 'Real Residency' Test
summary: To determine if someone is truly a 'local resident', several factors are considered, including family location, community ties, other residences, and various forms of documentation like utility bills, driver's licenses, and tax records.
logical_representation: IF determining_local_resident_status == TRUE -> CONSIDER(spouse_dependents_dwelling, property_social_ties, other_residential_ties, purpose_of_residence, documentation_proof)
reasoning: This rule lists the specific criteria used to determine eligibility for subsistence and travel benefits, placing it squarely within the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Chain of Command
rule_text: On all work coming under the terms of this Agreement, where General Foremen and Foremen are employed, orders shall normally be given in the following sequence: General Foremen to Foremen, Foremen to Journeymen. Where practical, orders will be submitted through respective Foremen.
summary: On any job with Foremen and General Foremen, the chain of command for giving orders is from General Foreman to Foreman, and then from Foreman to Journeyman.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(communication_flow == 'general_foreman_to_foreman_to_journeyman')
reasoning: This rule defines the operational structure and conditions under which work is directed and performed. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it is a foundational rule governing the organization of labor, which is a prerequisite for how worked time is managed and recorded.

name: Union Membership, Industrial
rule_text: General  Foremen,  Foremen,  Journeymen,  and  Apprentices  must  be  members  of  the appropriate Union.
summary: For industrial work, all General Foremen, Foremen, Journeymen, and Apprentices are required to be members of the correct union.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' AND employee_role IN ['General Foreman', 'Foreman', 'Journeyman', 'Apprentice'] -> CONSTRAINT(union_membership == True)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition of employment. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it defines who is eligible to perform work under the agreement, a fundamental aspect of managing labor and their worked hours.

name: Foreman Certification, Industrial
rule_text: It is further recognized that all the Steam Fitter-Pipe Fitter General Foremen and Foremen must be a UA certified Journeymen as designated by the Joint Educational Trust Fund Trustees.
summary: All Steam Fitter-Pipe Fitter General Foremen and Foremen on industrial projects must hold a UA Journeyman certification as determined by the training fund trustees.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' AND employee_role IN ['General Foreman', 'Foreman'] AND trade == 'Steam Fitter-Pipe Fitter' -> CONSTRAINT(certification == 'ua_certified_journeyman')
reasoning: This rule establishes a mandatory qualification for supervisory roles. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it is a prerequisite for certain individuals to be paid at a supervisory rate for their worked hours.

name: Union Cooperation During Labor Shortages
rule_text: During periods of labour shortages, the Union will work with the contractors to insure an adequate supply of supervision
summary: In times of labor shortages, the Union is obligated to cooperate with contractors to ensure there are enough supervisors available for the work.
logical_representation: IF is_labor_shortage == True -> OBLIGATION(union_cooperates_on_supervision_supply)
reasoning: This rule outlines an obligation related to staffing levels, which is essential for project continuity and the management of worked time. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it pertains to ensuring the necessary labor structure is in place for work to be performed and hours to be logged correctly.

name: Foreman Wage Premium, Industrial
rule_text: The minimum rate of wages for a Foreman shall be $5.50 per hour above the basic UA Journeyman Industrial rates as listed in Article 8.01 of this Agreement.
summary: On industrial projects, a Foreman must be paid a minimum of $5.50 per hour more than the basic industrial Journeyman rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'Foreman' AND work_type == 'Industrial' -> PREMIUM($5.50)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific wage calculation for a role. It directly relates to the rate of pay for hours worked, which is a core component of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category, specifically as a 'calculation rule'.

name: General Foreman Wage Premium, Industrial
rule_text: The minimum rate of wages for a General Foreman shall be $7.50 per hour, above the basic UA Journeyman Industrial rates as listed in Article 8.01 of this Agreement.
summary: On industrial projects, a General Foreman must be paid a minimum of $7.50 per hour more than the basic industrial Journeyman rate.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'General Foreman' AND work_type == 'Industrial' -> PREMIUM($7.50)
reasoning: This rule defines a specific wage calculation for a role. It directly relates to the rate of pay for hours worked, which is a core component of the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category, specifically as a 'calculation rule'.

name: ICCS Premium, Industrial
rule_text: Foremen and General Foremen who are Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor (ICCS) designated will be paid additional premiums of one ($1.50) dollar and fifty cents per hour.
summary: Foremen and General Foremen with an Industrial Construction Crew Supervisor (ICCS) designation receive an additional premium of $1.50 per hour.
