reasoning: This rule specifies an additional premium based on a qualification, which alters the rate of pay. It is classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it is a 'calculation rule' for determining the pay for worked hours.

name: ICCS Premium Rate Cap
rule_text: In no event shall this hourly rate be greater than the applicable overtime rate plus the ICCS premium
summary: The total hourly pay rate for a supervisor, including any premiums, cannot exceed the applicable overtime rate plus the ICCS premium.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(total_hourly_rate <= applicable_overtime_rate + iccs_premium)
reasoning: This rule sets a ceiling on the calculation of hourly wages, which is a 'calculation rule' concerning pay for worked time. This falls directly under the LABOR_WORKED_TIME category.

name: Apprentice Restriction from Foreman Role, Industrial
rule_text: Apprentices shall not be elevated to the position of Foremen or be authorized to direct any portion of the working force.
summary: On industrial projects, Apprentices cannot be promoted to Foreman or be given authority to supervise any other workers.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' AND employee_role == 'Apprentice' -> CONSTRAINT(can_be_foreman == False) AND CONSTRAINT(can_direct_workforce == False)
reasoning: This rule defines role limitations and workforce structure. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it dictates the composition of the workforce, which is a foundational element for managing and assigning worked time.

name: Apprentice Role Definition, Industrial
rule_text: An Apprentice shall be deemed to be a member of the crew and take their directions from the Foreman.
summary: On industrial projects, an Apprentice is considered a regular crew member who must follow instructions from the Foreman.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' AND employee_role == 'Apprentice' -> CONSTRAINT(reports_to == 'Foreman')
reasoning: This rule clarifies the reporting structure for Apprentices. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it relates to the organization of labor and the proper direction of work, which are preconditions for the execution and tracking of worked time.

name: Average Foreman Crew Size, Industrial
rule_text: The average number of Journeymen under the supervision of a Foreman shall be twelve (12).
summary: On industrial projects, the average crew size for one Foreman is twelve Journeymen.
logical_representation: CONSTRAINT(avg_journeymen_per_foreman == 12)
reasoning: This rule specifies staffing ratios, which govern the structure of the workforce. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME because these ratios are a fundamental constraint on how labor is organized and how worked time is supervised and managed on a project.

name: Second Foreman Requirement, Industrial
rule_text: The Employer agrees that there shall be two (2) Foremen once there are fourteen (14) Journeymen on the job.
summary: On an industrial job, a second Foreman must be added as soon as the number of Journeymen reaches fourteen.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'Industrial' AND journeyman_count >= 14 -> MIN(foreman_count, 2)
reasoning: This rule is a specific staffing trigger based on workforce size. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it dictates a required change in labor composition, which directly impacts labor management, supervision, and potentially cost calculations for worked hours.

name: Welder Foreman Requirement at 15 Welders
rule_text: On projects requiring a minimum of fifteen (15) Welders; there shall be a Qualified 'A' or 'B' Welder employed as a Welder Foreman when fifteen (15) welders are employed.
summary: On projects with at least fifteen welders, a qualified Welder must be appointed as a Welder Foreman once fifteen welders are on the job.
logical_representation: IF welder_count >= 15 -> MIN(welder_foreman_count, 1)
reasoning: This rule establishes a specific staffing requirement based on the number of tradespeople. It is classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it defines the necessary supervisory structure under which worked hours for a specific trade are performed and managed.

name: Additional Welder Foreman Requirements
rule_text: An additional Welder Foreman will be employed when twenty-five (25) welders are employed and  one  (1)  Welder  Foreman  for  every  twenty  (20)  Welders  employed  thereafter.
summary: An additional Welder Foreman is required when the welder count reaches twenty-five, and another Welder Foreman must be added for every subsequent group of twenty welders.
logical_representation: IF welder_count >= 25 -> MIN(welder_foreman_count, 2) AND IF welder_count > 25 -> welder_foreman_count = 2 + FLOOR((welder_count - 25) / 20)
reasoning: This rule outlines a progressive staffing formula. It is classified as LABOR_WORKED_TIME because it directly governs the required supervisory labor based on the volume of trade labor, impacting how worked time for a large crew is managed.

name: Welder Foreman Training Preference
rule_text: Whenever  possible  such  Welder  Foreman  shall  have  taken  and  passed  the  'Welder Foreman Training Program' as developed between the Parties.
summary: It is preferred that Welder Foremen have completed the official 'Welder Foreman Training Program' whenever possible.
logical_representation: IF employee_role == 'Welder Foreman' -> PREFERENCE(has_passed_training_program == True)
reasoning: This rule specifies a preferred qualification for a supervisory role. It is classified under LABOR_WORKED_TIME as it pertains to the standards and conditions for the supervision of labor, which is integral to the management of worked time.

name: Daily Travel Free Zone
rule_text: A forty-five (45) kilometer radius free zone from the center of the cities of Edmonton or Calgary; (Geodetic Monument) or around any place in which Employees are temporarily domiciled by the Employer shall be established. The location of the Geodetic Monument for Edmonton is 101 Street and Jasper Avenue and for Calgary, the Calgary Tower. No transportation or travel allowance shall be applicable within the free zone
summary: A 45km 'free zone' exists around the centers of Edmonton, Calgary, or any temporary employee housing. No travel or transportation allowance is paid for work within this zone.
logical_representation: IF project_location_distance_from_center <= 45 -> FORFEIT(travel_allowance) AND FORFEIT(transportation_allowance)
reasoning: This rule defines a geographic area where travel-related financial entitlements are not applicable, which falls under the scope of subsistence and travel allowances.

name: Major Project Transportation Discussion
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, on major construction projects located within the free zone, around the cities of Edmonton and Calgary, but beyond the city bus transportation system of those cities, where it is expected that the total construction workforce will exceed 500, the  affected  parties  shall  meet  to  discuss  the  viability  of  implementing  a  system  of providing transportation to the site.
summary: For major construction projects (over 500 workers) inside the free zone but outside public transit areas, the parties must meet to discuss providing transportation to the site.
logical_representation: IF project_location_in_free_zone == TRUE AND is_beyond_city_bus_system == TRUE AND workforce_size > 500 -> OBLIGATION(meet_and_discuss_transportation)
reasoning: This rule outlines a condition that triggers a process for providing transportation, which is a form of travel benefit related to subsistence and remote work policies.

name: Travel Time Allowance for Long Bus Commutes
rule_text: Workers shall be paid an allowance for time regularly and routinely in excess of forty five minutes each way, for travel within the applicable free zone. The allowance shall be calculated on the regular straight time base rate of each worker. The allowance will be paid only to workers who ride on the provided buses, and only for the days on which they ride the buses.
summary: If a worker's bus commute between a camp and a site within the free zone exceeds 45 minutes each way, they will be paid for the excess time at their regular straight-time rate. This only applies on days they actually use the bus.
logical_representation: IF bus_transit_time_each_way_minutes > 45 AND uses_provided_bus == TRUE -> PAY((bus_transit_time_each_way_minutes - 45) * 2 / 60 * employee_base_rate)
reasoning: This rule dictates payment for time spent traveling, which is a form of paid time, thus fitting under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Employer Options for Daily Travel Beyond Free Zone
summary: For projects requiring daily travel beyond the 45km free zone, the employer can either provide transportation plus a travel allowance, or pay employees a vehicle allowance per kilometer plus a travel allowance.
logical_representation: IF project_location_distance_from_center > 45 AND daily_travel_required == TRUE -> OPTION(PROVIDE(transportation) AND PAY(travel_allowance)) OR OPTION(PAY(vehicle_allowance) AND PAY(travel_allowance))
reasoning: This rule outlines employer obligations for providing travel benefits (allowances and transportation), which is central to subsistence policies. It also involves a travel time allowance, hence the secondary topic.

name: Travel Allowance Calculation
rule_text: The travel allowance shall be calculated based on traveling at 80 km per hour, at the Employee's applicable base rate, from the point where the edge of the 45 km radius free zone intersects the road which takes the shortest, most appropriate route, to the project and return to the intersecting point.
summary: The travel allowance is calculated as paid time. The time is determined by the distance from the edge of the 45km free zone to the project and back, assuming a travel speed of 80 km/h, and is paid at the employee's base rate.
logical_representation: CALCULATE travel_allowance = (distance_from_free_zone_edge_km * 2 / 80) * employee_base_rate
reasoning: This rule specifies how to calculate a payment based on travel duration, making it a rule about paid time, categorized under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Vehicle Allowance Rate Determination
rule_text: The Coordinating Committee and the Alberta Building Trades Council shall examine, during January of each year of the Collective Agreement, the information published by Canada Revenue Agency respecting the vehicle allowance amounts that will not be treated as taxable income, and that will be permitted as business expenses for Employers. Such information normally establishes a maximum rate for the first 5,000 km, and a lower rate for additional kilometres. The Coordinating Committee and the Council shall determine a rate that is midway between those two rates. The above vehicle allowance rate shall be adjusted, effective on the first pay period following May 1 of each year, to the rate so determined by the Coordinating Committee and the Council.
summary: The per-kilometer vehicle allowance rate is reviewed and set annually. It is calculated as the midpoint between the two standard Canada Revenue Agency rates (the initial km rate and the subsequent km rate) and takes effect after May 1st each year.
logical_representation: ONCE_PER_YEAR(January) -> SET vehicle_allowance_rate = (cra_rate_first_5000km + cra_rate_additional_km) / 2 | EFFECTIVE(first_pay_period_after_may_1)
reasoning: This rule governs the calculation of a monetary allowance for using a personal vehicle, which is a type of subsistence or travel expense reimbursement.

name: No Vehicle Allowance with Provided Transport
rule_text: Where the Employer provides the transportation the travel allowance would be paid but the vehicle allowance would not be payable.
summary: If the employer provides transportation to a job site, the employee still receives the travel allowance (paid travel time) but does not receive the vehicle allowance (for use of a personal car).
logical_representation: IF employer_provides_transportation == TRUE -> PAY(travel_allowance) AND FORFEIT(vehicle_allowance)
reasoning: This rule clarifies the conditions for receiving the vehicle allowance, which is a form of subsistence/travel reimbursement.

name: Denial of Travel Pay for Labor Disputes
rule_text: Employees who are transported to a job site but who refuse to start work at the prescribed time due to a picket line or other form of labour relations dispute will not be paid transportation or travel allowance for that day.
summary: If an employee is brought to the job site but refuses to work because of a picket line or labor dispute, they will not receive any transportation or travel allowance for that day.
logical_representation: IF refusal_to_work == TRUE AND reason_for_refusal == 'labor_dispute' -> FORFEIT(transportation_allowance) AND FORFEIT(travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule sets a condition for forfeiting travel-related entitlements, which fall under both subsistence (vehicle allowance) and paid time (travel allowance).

name: Pay for Transportation Delays
rule_text: When the transportation provided by the Employer for the conveyance of Employees is delayed by circumstances that are reasonably within the control of the Employer or the bussing company, the Employees shall be paid for all such time, providing the delay is in excess of 15 minutes, beyond the scheduled arrival time, up to a limit of two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rate.
summary: If employer-provided transportation is delayed by more than 15 minutes for controllable reasons, employees will be paid for the delay at their straight-time rate, for up to a maximum of two hours.
logical_representation: IF transportation_delay_minutes > 15 AND delay_is_controllable == TRUE -> PAY(MIN(delay_minutes, 120) / 60 * employee_straight_time_rate)
reasoning: This rule provides for payment for time spent waiting due to a delay, which is a form of paid non-productive time, thus fitting under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Travel Between Jobs During Work Hours
rule_text: If an Employee is required by the Employer to move from one job to another during working hours, the Employer shall provide the transportation or pay vehicle allowance at the rate established by the formula in 29.02 (a) above per kilometre traveled if the Employee uses their own vehicle. The Employee shall not suffer any loss of pay as a result of transferring between projects during working hours.
summary: If an employee has to move between job sites during their work shift, the employer must provide transportation or pay a vehicle allowance. The employee's pay will not be docked for the time spent traveling.
logical_representation: IF transfer_between_jobs == TRUE AND during_working_hours == TRUE -> (PROVIDE(transportation) OR PAY(vehicle_allowance)) AND PAY(travel_time_as_worked_time)
reasoning: This rule ensures that time spent traveling between sites is paid as regular work time, classifying it under LABOR_WORKED_TIME. It also includes a vehicle allowance, which is a subsistence component.

name: Travel After Shift Before Break
rule_text: Employees required to travel out of a city or town to another job after working a shift, and before an eight (8) hour break occurs, shall be paid for all time traveled at the rate of time and one-half the normal rate.
summary: If an employee must travel to another job after their shift ends and before they've had an 8-hour break, all of that travel time is paid at time and a half.
logical_representation: IF travel_after_shift == TRUE AND time_since_shift_end < 8_hours -> PAY(travel_hours * 1.5 * normal_rate)
reasoning: This rule specifies a premium pay rate for time spent traveling under specific conditions, clearly falling under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Continued Travel on Following Day
rule_text: If still traveling the following day, the Employee shall be paid the normal rate for time traveled during the regular working day only.
summary: If travel from the previous day continues into the next day, the employee is paid for travel time at their normal rate, but only for the hours that fall within their regular working day schedule.
logical_representation: IF travel_continues_next_day == TRUE -> PAY(travel_hours_during_regular_schedule * normal_rate)
reasoning: This rule defines the pay rate for time spent traveling, making it a LABOR_WORKED_TIME rule.

name: Payment for Moving Rooms in Camp
rule_text: Should an Employee residing in camp accommodation be requested by the Employer or the client's designated camp management personnel to move to another room or camp, they shall be paid two (2) hours at the applicable straight time rates to carry out the move.
summary: If an employee living in a camp is required to move rooms or to another camp, they must be paid for two hours at their straight-time rate for the inconvenience.
logical_representation: IF is_residing_in_camp == TRUE AND is_requested_to_move_room_or_camp == TRUE -> PAY(2 * straight_time_rate)
reasoning: This rule provides a specific payment of hours at a certain rate for an activity, which is a form of paid time, fitting under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Travel Allowance with Remote Subsistence
rule_text: When an Employee is being paid subsistence allowance in accordance with Article 29.04 and when there is no suitable accommodation available within 45 km. of the project on which the Employee is engaged, the Employer shall determine the location of the nearest available suitable accommodation and shall determine the number of road kilometers beyond a 45 kilometer radius of the project that would be required to travel each way from the nearest available suitable accommodation, and shall calculate the travel allowance in accordance with those provisions as identified in Article 29.02.
summary: If an employee receives a subsistence allowance but cannot find suitable accommodation within 45km of the project, the employer must pay an additional travel allowance. This allowance covers the travel from the edge of that 45km radius to the nearest available accommodation.
logical_representation: IF is_paid_subsistence == TRUE AND no_accommodation_within_45km == TRUE -> PAY(travel_allowance_from_45km_radius_to_accommodation)
reasoning: The rule is triggered by a subsistence condition and provides a travel-related monetary benefit. Since the benefit itself is a 'travel allowance' calculated based on time (per 29.02), it spans both topics.

name: C/I Daily Travel Beyond Free Zone
rule_text: For projects beyond the forty-five kilometre (45 km) free zone for which daily travel is required, then the Employer will provide transportation, plus a travel allowance to be negotiated in consultation with the Union, however, in the event no Agreement is reached with the Union then a decision shall be made by the Registered Employers' Organization, which decision shall be final and binding.
summary: For Commercial/Institutional projects requiring daily travel beyond the 45km free zone, the employer must provide transportation and a travel allowance. The allowance amount is negotiated with the Union, but if no agreement is reached, the Employers' Organization makes a final decision.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'COMMERCIAL_INSTITUTIONAL' AND project_location_distance_from_center > 45 AND daily_travel_required == TRUE -> PROVIDE(transportation) AND PAY(negotiated_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule outlines obligations for transportation and travel allowances for a specific work type, which is a core subsistence/travel policy. The travel allowance itself is paid time, hence the secondary topic.

name: Application of Industrial Rules to C/I Work
rule_text: Clauses 29.02 (c), (d), (e), (f), (g) & (h) are also applicable to Commercial & Institutional work.
summary: Several daily travel rules from the industrial section also apply to Commercial & Institutional work. These include rules on denial of pay for labor disputes, pay for transport delays, travel between jobs, travel after shifts, payment for moving camp rooms, and travel allowance for remote subsistence.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'COMMERCIAL_INSTITUTIONAL' -> APPLY_RULES(29.02c, 29.02d, 29.02e, 29.02f, 29.02g, 29.02h)
reasoning: This rule incorporates multiple other rules that cover both subsistence (allowances, accommodation issues) and worked time (pay for delays, travel between shifts).

name: Out-of-Town Accommodation Options (within 475km)
rule_text:
When an Employee is directed or dispatched to work on an out-of-town job, the Employer will provide:
(i) camp accommodation, which shall be available seven days per week; or
(ii) mutually agreed room and board; or
(iii) for each day worked, reimbursement toward the expense of the Employee's board and lodging... by way of a subsistence allowance...
summary: For out-of-town jobs within a 475km radius of Edmonton or Calgary, the employer must provide one of the following: camp accommodation (available 7 days/week), mutually agreed-upon room and board, or a daily subsistence allowance for each day worked.
logical_representation: IF is_out_of_town_job == TRUE AND job_location_radius_km <= 475 -> OPTION(PROVIDE(camp_accommodation)) OR OPTION(PROVIDE(room_and_board)) OR OPTION(PAY(daily_subsistence_allowance))
reasoning: This rule directly defines the employer's obligation to provide or pay for living expenses on remote jobs, which is the definition of a subsistence allowance.

name: Extra Subsistence for Distant Projects
rule_text: On a project/jobsite located over two hundred and fifty (250) radius kilometers from the geographic centers of either the City of Edmonton or Calgary (as applicable) one additional day's subsistence shall be paid for the use of accommodation for the night following the last day worked, provided that the Employee presents a bona-fide commercial receipt to their Employer for each occasion the accommodation is used.
summary: For projects over 250km from Edmonton or Calgary, employees receive an extra day of subsistence allowance to cover accommodation for the night after their last shift, as long as they provide a valid commercial receipt.
logical_representation: IF project_location_radius_km > 250 AND provides_receipt == TRUE -> PAY(1_additional_day_subsistence)
reasoning: This rule provides an additional monetary allowance for lodging under specific conditions, which is a subsistence allowance.

name: Exception to Extra Subsistence
rule_text: Where the Employer or their client is providing a free bus trip back to the city on the same day as the last shift of the week, this provision shall not be applicable.
summary: The rule for an extra day's subsistence allowance does not apply if the employer provides a free bus ride back to the city on the employee's last day of the week.
logical_representation: IF employer_provides_free_bus_home == TRUE -> FORFEIT(1_additional_day_subsistence)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition under which a subsistence allowance is forfeited, directly relating it to that topic.

name: Subsistence for Statutory Holidays
rule_text: Board and room will be supplied, or the daily expense allowance will be paid for any Statutory Holiday which falls on a scheduled workday other than a first or last day of a scheduled shift provided the Employee reports for work on the workday immediately preceding and following the Statutory Holiday.
summary: Employees receive their regular room and board or subsistence allowance for a Statutory Holiday if it falls on a scheduled workday. To qualify, they must work the scheduled days immediately before and after the holiday.
logical_representation: IF is_stat_holiday == TRUE AND is_scheduled_workday == TRUE AND worked_day_before == TRUE AND worked_day_after == TRUE -> PROVIDE(room_and_board) OR PAY(daily_subsistence_allowance)
reasoning: This rule governs the payment of subsistence allowance on non-worked days (Statutory Holidays), making it a rule about subsistence continuity.

name: Out-of-Town Accommodation (Beyond 475km)
rule_text:
Applicable beyond a 475-kilometer radius of the Cities of Edmonton and Calgary ... When an Employee is directed or dispatched to work on an out-of-town job which will last at least five days, the Employer will provide, on a seven (7) days per week basis:
(i) camp accommodation; or
(ii) Mutually agreed room and board, or subsistence allowance...
summary: For out-of-town jobs lasting at least five days and located more than 475km from Edmonton or Calgary, the employer must provide one of the following on a 7-day-per-week basis: camp, mutually agreed room and board, or a subsistence allowance.
logical_representation: IF job_location_radius_km > 475 AND job_duration_days >= 5 -> (OPTION(PROVIDE(camp_accommodation)) OR OPTION(PROVIDE(room_and_board)) OR OPTION(PAY(subsistence_allowance))) | BASIS(7_days_per_week)
reasoning: This rule defines the employer's obligation for providing living expenses on long-distance remote jobs, which is a core subsistence rule.

name: Weekend/Holiday Subsistence Attendance Requirement
rule_text: Employees failing to report for work on the workday immediately preceding and following a weekend or Statutory Holiday will receive the above for days worked only.
summary: For jobs beyond 475km, if an employee misses work on the day before or after a weekend or statutory holiday, they will only receive subsistence allowance for the days they actually worked, not for the days off.
logical_representation: IF worked_day_before_break == FALSE OR worked_day_after_break == FALSE -> PAY(subsistence_for_days_worked_only)
reasoning: This rule ties the continuity of subsistence payments to work attendance, which is a common feature of subsistence allowance policies.

name: Options for High-Cost Areas
rule_text:
In certain situations, Employees may be dispatched or directed to work on projects which are in an area where the cost of available suitable single room accommodation and/or meals may be in excess of the daily rate of subsistence set out in this Article. In such a case, the Employer shall provide one of the following options:
 provide suitable room and board; or
 directly pick up the cost of the room and pay a meal allowance to be determined as is set out in this Article; or
 the subsistence allowance shall be reviewed and, if necessary, adjusted by the following procedure:
summary: If the standard subsistence allowance is not enough to cover lodging and meals in a high-cost area, the employer must choose one of three options: provide room and board directly, pay for the room and provide a meal allowance, or enter a process to review and adjust the subsistence rate.
logical_representation: IF local_cost > subsistence_rate -> OPTION(PROVIDE(room_and_board)) OR OPTION(PROVIDE(room) AND PAY(meal_allowance)) OR OPTION(TRIGGER(subsistence_review_process))
reasoning: This rule details procedures and options for adjusting subsistence due to high local costs, clearly placing it within the LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE topic.

name: Subsistence During Work Stoppage
rule_text: Employees unable to work due to legitimate illness, material shortage, job site conditions, or inclement weather and for whom it is not practical to return to their respective primary Alberta residence (or the Union Hall in the case of non-Alberta residents) shall receive their board and room or daily allowance for those work days they were scheduled to work, during the period such circumstances continue, up to a maximum of three (3) days.
summary: If employees cannot work due to legitimate reasons like illness or bad weather and cannot reasonably go home, they will continue to receive their room and board or daily allowance for up to three scheduled workdays.
logical_representation: IF unable_to_work == TRUE AND reason IN ('illness', 'shortage', 'conditions', 'weather') AND is_practical_to_return_home == FALSE -> (PROVIDE(room_and_board) OR PAY(daily_allowance)) | MAX(3_days)
reasoning: This rule dictates the continuation of subsistence payments during periods of non-work, making it a rule about subsistence eligibility and continuity.

name: Prorated Subsistence for Early Departure
rule_text: If an Employee who is being provided with subsistence allowance chooses to leave a jobsite prior to the normal quitting time without receiving consent from their Employer, the Employee will receive a prorated amount of subsistence based upon the number of hours the Employee worked in the workday, compared to the regularly scheduled hours of work for the day.
summary: If an employee on subsistence leaves work early without the employer's permission, their daily subsistence allowance for that day will be prorated based on the hours they actually worked versus the scheduled hours.
logical_representation: IF leaves_early == TRUE AND has_employer_consent == FALSE -> PAY(PRORATED(subsistence_allowance, hours_worked / scheduled_hours))
reasoning: This rule defines a condition that modifies the amount of the daily subsistence allowance, tying payment directly to hours worked on a given day.

name: Full Subsistence for Approved Early Departure
rule_text: If the Employee leaves prior to the normal quitting time with the consent of the Employer they will receive the normal daily subsistence allowance for that day.
summary: If an employee leaves work early with the employer's permission, they will still receive their full daily subsistence allowance for that day.
logical_representation: IF leaves_early == TRUE AND has_employer_consent == TRUE -> PAY(full_daily_subsistence_allowance)
reasoning: This rule specifies a condition under which the full daily subsistence allowance is paid, making it a rule about subsistence eligibility.

name: Initial and Return Transportation Allowance
rule_text: Employees directed or dispatched to a project/jobsite from which they do not return daily shall be paid travel allowance for initial travel and transportation to the project and return, upon termination of the job or their employment, based upon a radius from the cities of Edmonton or Calgary, as applicable, as follows: ...
summary: For industrial jobs where employees do not commute daily, they receive a fixed travel allowance for their initial trip to the site and their return trip upon termination. The amount is based on the distance from Edmonton or Calgary.
logical_representation: IF work_type == 'INDUSTRIAL' AND daily_commute == FALSE -> PAY(initial_travel_allowance) AND PAY(return_travel_allowance)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary allowance to cover the expense of getting to and from a remote worksite, which is a form of subsistence/travel reimbursement.

name: Election of Transportation or Allowance
rule_text: When transportation is provided by the employer by way of air, bus, or other acceptable surface transportation, prior to the commencement and following the conclusion of a work cycle ... an employee, at the time of dispatch, will be allowed to elect to use the such employer provided transportation or to receive collective agreement initial/return/rotation allowances.
summary: When the employer provides transport (like a bus or flight) for initial, return, or rotational trips, the employee can choose at dispatch to either use that transport or receive the cash allowances specified in the agreement instead.
logical_representation: IF employer_provides_transportation == TRUE -> AT_DISPATCH(employee_election = 'use_transport' OR employee_election = 'receive_allowances')
reasoning: This rule gives employees a choice between a direct benefit (transport) and a monetary allowance, both of which fall under the category of subsistence and travel benefits.

name: Reimbursement When Elected Transport is Unavailable
rule_text: Notwithstanding the foregoing, an employee who has elected to use employer provided transportation and who is hired, laid off, or terminated on a day when such transportation is not available shall be reimbursed the cost of a one-way commercial bus ticket to Edmonton or Calgary, whichever is applicable, and transportation from the site to the nearest commercial bus terminal, or equivalent taxi fare.
summary: If an employee chose to use employer-provided transport but is hired or laid off on a day when it's not running, the employer must pay for a one-way commercial bus ticket to Edmonton or Calgary and get them to the bus station.
logical_representation: IF employee_election == 'use_transport' AND transportation_availability == FALSE -> PAY(one_way_bus_ticket_cost)
reasoning: This rule ensures a travel benefit is provided when the primary method fails, making it a subsistence/travel rule.

name: Initial Transportation Allowance Vesting
rule_text: Employees will qualify for, and receive initial transportation allowance to the job site after being employed at the site for either fifteen (15) calendar days or completion of the job, whichever is the lesser.
summary: To receive the initial transportation allowance, an employee must work for 15 calendar days or until the job is finished, whichever comes first.
logical_representation: IF calendar_days_employed >= 15 OR job_completed == TRUE -> ENTITLED(initial_transportation_allowance)
reasoning: This rule sets the time-based condition for an employee to become entitled to a travel allowance, which is a subsistence benefit.

name: Return Transportation Allowance Vesting
rule_text: Should the Employee remain on the job until completion of thirty (30) calendar days, or until completion of the dispatched job requirement, whichever may be the lesser, they shall receive the return transportation allowance to be paid with their final pay cheque.
summary: To receive the return transportation allowance, an employee must work for 30 calendar days or until their dispatched job is complete, whichever comes first. It is paid with their final pay.
logical_representation: IF calendar_days_employed >= 30 OR job_completed == TRUE -> ENTITLED(return_transportation_allowance)
reasoning: This rule sets the time-based condition for an employee to become entitled to a travel allowance, which is a subsistence benefit.

name: Rotational Leave Allowance (300-475km)
rule_text: On jobs located beyond a Three Hundred (300) km radius to a maximum of Four Hundred and Seventy-five (475) km from the centre of Edmonton or Calgary or other hiring hall location, the Employer shall: (i) Pay an allowance of (See Travel Allowance Memo at www.clra.org) after thirty-five (35) calendar days of employment on the job and thereafter for each subsequent thirty-five (35) calendar days of employment on the job.
summary: For industrial jobs between 300km and 475km from the hiring location, the employer must pay a set rotational leave (turnaround) allowance for every 35 calendar days of employment.
logical_representation: IF job_location_radius_km > 300 AND job_location_radius_km <= 475 -> FOR_EACH(35_calendar_days_employed) -> PAY(rotational_allowance)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary allowance to facilitate travel home on rotation, which is a form of subsistence or remote work benefit.

name: Rotational Leave Time Off
rule_text: Allow employees five (5) working days leave after each thirty-five (35) calendar days of employment on the job.
summary: In addition to the allowance, employees on rotational jobs are entitled to five working days of leave for every 35 calendar days they are employed on the job.
logical_representation: FOR_EACH(35_calendar_days_employed) -> ENTITLED(5_working_days_leave)
reasoning: This rule grants an entitlement to time off from work based on time served, which is a rule governing work schedules and time, fitting under LABOR_WORKED_TIME.

name: Rotational Leave Allowance (>475km)
rule_text: On jobs located beyond a four hundred and seventy-five (475) kilometre radius from the centre of Edmonton or Calgary or other hiring hall location, the Employer shall: (i) Provide a negotiated transportation allowance, not to exceed scheduled airline air fare where scheduled air service is available, or pay an allowance of (See Travel Allowance Memo at www.clra.org) where airline service is not available, after thirty-five (35) calendar days of employment on the job and thereafter for each subsequent thirty-five (35) calendar days of employment on the job.
summary: For industrial jobs over 475km from the hiring location, after every 35 calendar days, the employer must provide a rotational leave allowance. This will be a negotiated amount (up to the cost of airfare if available) or a set amount if there's no air service.
logical_representation: IF job_location_radius_km > 475 -> FOR_EACH(35_calendar_days_employed) -> PAY(rotational_allowance)
reasoning: This rule provides a monetary allowance for rotational travel from very remote sites, clearly falling under subsistence and travel benefits.

name: Annual Allowance Adjustment
rule_text: The Initial and Return Transportation Allowances and the Rotational Leave Allowances [applicable to Industrial work] set out herein shall be subject to review in January of each year of the Collective Agreement. In the event that there is an adjustment in the vehicle allowance, pursuant to Clause 29.02 (a), each allowance amount shall be adjusted by the same percentage adjustment as the vehicle allowance adjustment, effective the first pay period following May 1st of the respective year.
summary: The Initial, Return, and Rotational Leave allowances for industrial work are adjusted annually. The percentage increase or decrease will be the same as the adjustment made to the vehicle allowance, and it takes effect after May 1st.
logical_representation: ONCE_PER_YEAR -> ADJUST(initial_return_rotational_allowances) BY vehicle_allowance_adjustment_percent | EFFECTIVE(first_pay_period_after_may_1)
reasoning: This rule describes the mechanism for updating several monetary allowances related to remote work, which is a core function of subsistence allowance policies.

name: Exclusion of Time for Turnaround Accumulation
rule_text: Time spent away from a jobsite due to a jobsite closure or scheduled vacation of one work week (5 days or 4 days as the case may be) or longer will not be credited towards the accumulation of calendar days for earning a turnaround leave.
summary: If an employee is away from the job site for a week or more due to a site closure or vacation, that time does not count toward the 35 calendar days needed to qualify for a turnaround leave and allowance.
logical_representation: IF time_away_from_jobsite_duration >= 1_week AND reason_for_absence IN ('closure', 'vacation') -> EXCLUDE(time_away_from_turnaround_accumulation)
reasoning: This rule specifies what time counts towards earning a subsistence-related benefit (turnaround allowance), making it a rule governing subsistence eligibility.

name: Rotational Leave for Commercial/Institutional Work
rule_text: For COMMERCIAL and INSTITUTIONAL Work, the allowance for the Turnaround Leave is to be negotiated between the Employer and the Union. (based on the Industrial format in Clause 29.07(a)(i)&(b)(i)), however in the event that no agreement is reached between the Employer and the Union a decision shall be made by the Registered Employers Organization, which decision shall be final and binding.
summary: For Commercial and Institutional work, the turnaround (rotational) leave allowance is to be negotiated between the employer and the union. If they cannot agree, the Registered Employers Organization will make a final and binding decision.
logical_representation: IF work_type IN ('COMMERCIAL', 'INSTITUTIONAL') -> SET(turnaround_allowance) BY NEGOTIATION | IF no_agreement -> SET(turnaround_allowance) BY REO_decision
reasoning: This rule outlines the process for determining a rotational leave allowance, a key component of subsistence and travel policy for remote work.

name: SPNA Template for Remote Projects
rule_text: If the project gate is beyond daily commuting distance (beyond 125 km of the city centre of either Calgary or Edmonton) the SPNA for the project shall be in the form attached as Template A.
summary: For projects located more than 125 km from the city center of either Calgary or Edmonton, a specific set of rules, referred to as 'Template A', must be used for the Special Project Needs Agreement (SPNA).
logical_representation: IF project_gate_distance_from_calgary_centre_km > 125 OR project_gate_distance_from_edmonton_centre_km > 125 -> APPLY(SPNA_TEMPLATE_A)
reasoning: This rule establishes the condition for applying a specific project agreement template (Template A) based on a project's remote location. Remote location, defined by a distance threshold, is the primary trigger for subsistence allowance eligibility, making LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE the most relevant topic.

name: SPNA Template for Local Projects
rule_text: If the project gate is within daily commuting distance (within 125 km of the city centre of either Calgary, or Edmonton or within 45 km of the city centre of Red Deer) the SPNA for the project shall be in the form attached as Template B.
summary: For projects located within 125 km of Calgary or Edmonton city centers, or within 45 km of Red Deer city center, a specific set of rules, referred to as 'Template B', must be used for the Special Project Needs Agreement (SPNA).
logical_representation: IF project_gate_distance_from_calgary_centre_km <= 125 OR project_gate_distance_from_edmonton_centre_km <= 125 OR project_gate_distance_from_red_deer_centre_km <= 45 -> APPLY(SPNA_TEMPLATE_B)
reasoning: This rule dictates the use of a specific project agreement template (Template B) for projects considered within daily commuting distance. This condition is key for determining the inapplicability of remote work entitlements like subsistence, making LABOR_SUBSISTENCE_ALLOWANCE the most relevant topic as it defines the boundary for such benefits.
